When you're in your car—Braydon drives a beat up old sedan that was maybe a luxury vehicle in the early oughts but is now just one cut above "junker"—you text Gillian back. something up this afternoon meet at 8? She ripostes with 4?; you compromise on 6:30 at Besandwitched.

You rub your eye with the heel of your hand. Gillian Kiefer is going to be a serious distraction.

She's already a serious distraction to Braydon Delp.

Oh, he doesn't think of her as a distraction. He thinks of her as the most wonderful thing in his life. But she really does like to keep him off balance.

Take the way she talks about him. Delp isn't her boyfriend. He's her "hubby," and she talks to other people as though he and she are already married but are content to live apart.

Well, that's for the best. They shouldn't be moving in together, not while they're both still in high school, and maybe not for a couple of years yet, even if they do wind up attending the local university, as they both plan.

But Gillian really is content to live apart from Braydon. And there are days when, if he doesn't go looking for her at school, he won't see her at all. Sometimes they never so much as exchange a text over a weekend. Well, Braydon will send her texts. She'll ignore them.

And she likes to flirt with other guys. Hard. She even goes on dates with them. Braydon has asked her if they have an "open relationship." She only laughs and says that if he wants an open relationship he'll have to have it with girls not named Gillian because she won't stand for that. Once, when he got jealous of all the time she was spending with Aaron Flood, he asked her if she thought she got to have multiple SOs while he (Braydon) didn't. She just told him not to be sulky.

And then sometimes she will practically move in with him, not leaving his bedroom for hours and hours at a time, and giggling and playing with his ... appendages.

You sink back with a groan. Gillian really knows how to keep a guy entertained and feeling good, even without touching the magic spots.

But she seems to have a gift for knowing when he wants to do some serious studying, particularly of the occult stuff, for that's when she likes to pounce and make him pay attention to her.

At least you've carved out an afternoon for yourself. Braydon hasn't got any homework, so you'll have five or more hours to start acquainting yourself with his library.

* * * * *

Thirty minutes after you get home, and are just settling in on Braydon's bed with a glass of OJ and a peanut-butter sandwich, the doorbell rings. You set your lunch aside with a sigh: Mrs. Delp is at work, and you're home alone.

Gillian beams at you through the screen door when you answer the bell. "Hi."

"Uh, hi."

"Let me in? I notice your mom's not here."

"She's at work."

"Perfect. Let me in?"

You unlatch the screen door. "I thought we weren't meeting until six-thirty."

"Oh, we're meeting at six-thirty. But no one said anything about not meeting before then."

Gillian Kiefer is only slightly shorter than Braydon, and Braydon is pretty short as it is. She has soft brown hair that she wears in a bob that curls out just under her earlobes. She has chipmunk cheeks and pert lips that curve naturally into a secretive smile, and her brown eyes glint and glimmer with mischief. Her bare arms are downed with light brown hair, and her wrists are wrapped with flimsy leather friendship bracelets. She has the cutest little overbite that she likes to play up when she's feeling puckish.

She is obviously feeling very puckish now, for she has her hands clasped behind her back. "When's your mom get off?"

"Five-thirty."

"Plenty of time. You hanging out in your room?"

"Yeah. Listen, Gillian—" You rub your forehead. It has gotten very hot where you're standing, like a blast furnace has opened up right behind you, and parts of you are getting rigid in a way that bodes ill for your willpower. "I'm working on some stuff—"

"Homework? I can help you."

"I don't need your help."

"Don't you want me to help you?"

"Well, sure, but—"

"So show me?" She sways from side to side, like a little girl trying to tease her elders. "I won't come in if you don't invite me."

Your resistance doesn't fold so much as it flops to the floor into a limp heap, like linen slipping off a clothesline. "Come on." You pull her inside and close the door after her.

She leans against you, cradling her head on your shoulder, so you have to half support and half tug her toward the staircase. "What are you working on?"

"My books. You know the ones."

"Are you ever going to make me a love potion?"

"What do you need one for?"

"Silly. There's a guy that I want to use it on."

You stiffen, and not in a pleasant way. "You don't need to use one on me."

"Good, 'cos it's for another guy. I want him to be sadly, sadly in love with me," she goes on as you tense all over. "I want him to be so sadly in love with me that he can't even eat. I want him to waste away, sighing and sighing until there's nothing left of him but a ghostly sigh that lingers in the air." You're upstairs now, and she hops into your bedroom and onto your bed. "A sigh that lingers like a stain in the air over his bed."

"Who is the guy?"

"I haven't decided yet. But wouldn't it be poetical and tragical and romantical?"

"You wouldn't feed me that kind of potion, would you?"

She scrunches her nose, and does a double-take at your sandwich. "You don't eat enough as it is." She picks it up and peels back the bread to study the insides, then starts eating it. "I worry about you sometimes, Braydon," she mumbles around the peanut butter as she sits on your bed.

"I give my food rations to starving children. Karmic investment to counterbalance the black magic." You fall onto the bed next to her and stroke her calf. "What are you gonna do while I read?"

She chews carefully, and swallows, and sucks on her teeth before answering. "I could go down on you while you study. Would that help? It seems to me that having sex while studying black magic is a pretty natural combination."

You roll onto your back with a groan. "I really am pursuing a project, Gillian."

"You always are."

"No, this time is serious. It's for someone else. They want me to do some research for them." It's the only way you can think of to maybe give you some space and time.

"Who?"

"That's confidential."

"Bullshit."

"It's true. They don't want me—"

"How come? Who is it?"

You sigh. "Just some guys."

Her tone turns sour and skeptical. "You're not an expert on this stuff, Braydon."

"I'm more of an expert than anyone else."

"So what are they asking you about, and how come you can't tell me who it is?"

"They're embarrassed."

"You should be embarrassed."

"It's just a couple of guys from school. They found this book and they want to know what it's all about, so they asked me to read it and explain it to them."

"What book? Is it this one?" She picks up the paperback—Van Dunkel's Elements of Natural Magic—that you were starting to peruse. "This is yours, Braydon, I've seen you with it a hundred times—"

"It overlaps with this other book. This other one is, like, more advanced or something."

"Hmph. Well, how much are they paying you?"

"Paying?" You blink.

"Oh, God, Braydon! You're not doing someone else's work for free are you?"

"I'm getting something out of it too! This other book, it's got stuff in it that's—!"

"Well, I need to get paid, if it's going to be worth my time!"

"Your time?" You can only gape like a landed fish.

That chipmunk smile flashes onto her face. "Sure! I'm going to help you!"

* * * * *

She's finally exasperated you enough that you force her off your bed and out of your bedroom. "I said I was going to meet you at six-thirty, Gillian, and I'm going to meet you at six-thirty," you tell her at the door.

"But—"

"I really have to buckle down on this stuff. I'll have homework next week, and—"

"Don't you love me anymore?"

You pull her to yourself long enough to kiss her while fondling her butt.

"I love you more than ever," you say when you let go of her. "So why don't you go make me jealous or something with another guy while I do this? That way we can both be mad at each other." You push her gently away and shut the door on her.

Not till you're halfway up the stairs do you realize what you just said.

"Braydon, sweetie." You cup his chin in your hand and kiss him. "Mommy's talking. I only know what she told you, Caleb."

"If I'm eye-fucking anyone in Gladstone's class," he grumbles, "it's Andrea Varnsworth."

"Huh. So does Susie sit between you and Andrea?"

"Fuck if I know, I only notice Andrea." He frowns at Susie, then shrugs. "Eh, I guess she'll do."

"She'll have to do. If she wakes up and she isn't you, she's going to be a very unhappy girl. You got your mask and the golem stuff?" Caleb pats the satchel hanging from his shoulder. "Good." You look around and smile brightly at the day and at your friends. "This is fun, we should do it more often."

* * * * *

Braydon cradles Susie's head in his lap while you check your phone for texts. Danielle Davis is talking about a giant pizza-and-a-movie thing (but without volunteering her place) and Emma Witkin wants to know if anyone is up for a thing at the river, on account of yesterday's rains ruined that location for a Saturday night thing. You like both ideas, and you show them to Caleb, but he only shrugs and bobs and swivels his head while watching the nearby houses with bulging eyes.

Finally, the mask comes out of Susie. You watch from under lowered brows as Caleb fumbles the golem stuff into it. He makes it a sloppy affair, almost certainly on account of nerves. When he's done, you pull it from his grasp and yourself set it on Susie, as Caleb would likely jab her in the lip or eye with a sharp corner.

"Caleb," you tell him as Susie opens her eyes and looks around with puzzlement. "Tell her not to talk or scream, and to follow you out to the basement."

But his jaw just hangs open and his eyes bug out as Susie scoots back from him. "Gillian," she stammers, "what the hell—?"

"Caleb, you better do something," you murmur.

"Gyuh?" he says.

Susie scrambles to her feet. Losing all patience, you kick Caleb in the ribs. "Ow!" he yells. "Quit it!"

"Don't yell at me, yell at her, your new— Oh, shit! There she goes!" And sure enough, Susie has gone sprinting off.

"Muh?" Caleb says.

"Tell her to stop, you moron!"

"Stop!"

"Call her by name, you fucking—!"

"Susie! Stop!" Caleb yells.

Susie trips and falls. Caleb, like a gooney bird trying to take flight, galumphs over to where she sprawls.

"You know what I love about you, sweetie," you tell Braydon who has been watching Caleb's contretemps with a smirk. "You come when I call and stay when I tell you." You nuzzle at his ear.

Whatever Caleb says to the Susie-golem manages to work, for both of them, looking nervous and aghast, stumble off toward the basement door. You watch until they disappear. Then, as there won't be any excitement for awhile, you hook an arm around Braydon and pull him down to the grass. "Pay attention to me," you tell him. "All over." He obliges while you graze on his hair and watch the basement door over the crown of his head.

Maybe five minutes pass before a figure appears: Caleb, looking as distracted and embarrassed as when he vanished under the school. You raise up with a frown, but after flashing you a sour look he lopes over to his car and gets in. He has some trouble starting it, it looks like, but after it roars to life he turns around and drives slowly away.

But Susie doesn't come out.

And she doesn't come out, and she doesn't come out.

You're on the verge of mounting a rescue mission when the door finally opens. Susie Lekuawehe, in her burgundy sweater and tight jeans and leather boots, and her hair draping softly around her shoulders, comes out and pulls the door shut. She looks around, and advances on you with the gait of one who is trying to navigate in bare feet a floor scattered with fish hooks.

"Hey girl!" you call out to her, but she winces. "What's wrong?" She doesn't answer.

She takes long enough reaching you that you have plenty of time to notice how clumsily she wobbles on her feet. She also twists about, as though trying to get comfortable in her clothes.

"Caleb?" you say as she comes up, and "Yeah," she replies.

"Susie?" you prompt, and "I guess," she mutters back. With a sigh and another wince she lower herself to the grass. She digs through her hair with long fingers. "What's wrong?" you ask.

"Nothing?" But still she frowns, and pulls at the front of her sweater. She flushes as she accidentally tweaks a boob. (And a fine, large cluster they are, too.) "Just taking awhile to get used to things."

"Well, what do you want to do tonight?" You pull Braydon up so that you can sit in his lap with your arms dangled about his neck. "So who did you make out with last night?" you ask when she doesn't answer. "So you can find someone new or else go back for seconds."

You laugh at your tease, but Susie shoots you a dirty look. "What's wrong?" you ask. "Just because Susie thinks you're a creep—"

"Does she?" Susie bursts out. "'Cos I don't know what she thinks!"

* * * * *

Caleb's expostulation surprises you, but it doesn't alarm you when he goes on to say that he hasn't got any of Susie's memories. "Maybe you should just relax," you suggest, and shrug when he asks how long it took for you to get into Braydon's and Gillian's and your dad's memories, because they seem to have come to you instantly. For a quarter hour you tease him while he looks around with a grumpy expression on Susie's very pretty face.

But after twenty minutes, at the end of which he professes not to remember a goddamn thing about her—such as her birthday, address, family, or classes—you become alarmed enough to suggest something has gone wrong with the mask. It's an awful sight when you pull the mask off Caleb, leaving him inside Susie's clothes, but the inside of the mask looks okay: SUSAN KIRA LEKUAWEHE. It has golem goop inside it, so you can't get in to check it out yourself, but you pull at Braydon's face—revealing Gillian—and pop Susie's mask onto her long enough to confirm that golem-Susie knows all about Susie's life.

"I can't go home if I don't know where I live!" Caleb exclaims after he's fitted out in Susie's mask again.

"I know where she lives," you assure him. "That's not a problem."

"That's not what I mean!" For a minute you think he's going to hit you. "I mean, if I don't have her memories, if I don't know how to act like her—"

"So we keep you out of her house," you say, and you dig through Susie's purse after her phone. "That's not a problem either. Susie's never home that much anyway." Caleb reaches for the phone, but you pull it away. You ignore the texts that are piling up to send one to her mom: What tiime u need me home? "If it's still a problem tonight," you tell him, "you'll just have to go home as yourself and send the golem home for Susie instead."

"You're taking this awfully well, Will," Caleb says.

"It's not my problem," you retort. "Besides, Gillian's good at not panicking."

Meanwhile, it looks like plans are piling up: Danielle Davis has got commitments for a small party at her place, but others like the sound of a thing down by the river. Whatever you do, though, you don't want to leave Caleb to fend for himself.

111111211221121113211134112.content:
"Come on." You pull Caleb to his feet. "Sweetie," you tell Braydon. "You can go home. Read that book, the one you were reading when I came over and, you know—" You poke and tickle him. "Yesterday. Takes lots of good notes."

"What are you going to do?"

"Susie and me are going to go have fun." You pull Caleb— now Susie Lekuawehe—close. She stiffens in your embrace. "She needs to loosen up."

"What kind of fun?" Caleb asks. He sounds frightened.

"Out by the river kind of fun. There's a bunch of people—"

"Oh, God, Will! I can't go out with—"

"You'll be fine! You're so pretty! Isn't she pretty, Braydon?" you ask, for your hubby is still lingering. You stroke Susie's bangs.

"She's very pretty," Braydon agrees, but he's looking everyplace but at you and Caleb as he says it. He's so cute when he's embarrassed! you think. But you dismiss him with a firmer order to go home.

"If you think I'm so pretty," Caleb grumbles, "maybe you and me should go off and have a party by ourselves."

You giggle. "That would be fun, but I want to see if you can swim. That's what you're supposed to do with someone, right? Throw them in the deep end? If you have to act like Susie, maybe that'll get you acting like her."

"But—!"

"But nothing. Come on, you drive."

* * * * *

Your destination is a long strip of low riverbank on Mohegan River. It's a grassy stretch with the gurgling river on one side and a fringe of trees on the others, where kids like to park and party and make out. Susie moans all the way out, which gets on your nerves until you snap at her to "stop acting like Johansson." She gets very quiet after that, which isn't much better, since Susie is a bubbly, voluble girl who loves to flirt and tease and laugh and joke.

There are a lot of cars when you arrive, for there's a mile or more of places to park, and lots of people have apparently had the same idea about a Sunday hangout after the rains of Saturday. But finally you spot the cars of the people you're looking for, and tell Susie to squeeze in next to them.

It's impossible to tell where this party stops and the next-door parties start, as they're all clumps of people strung out along the bank with beers and colas, some standing and others leaning against or sitting atop cars. As Susie pulls into a space, Eric Harlen waves at you without dropping his other arm from around Rebecca Sykes. Tim Gerard is standing in a circle with Brianna Kirschke and Dean Stratton; he's talking intently, and he makes a face every time Dean puts his cigarette to his lips. Jack Li and Wendy Terrill are guarding a Styrofoam chest while Eric Murphy, Tim Ryan and Jason Church crouch around the hibachi, arguing intently.

And in and among these wander couples with their arms around each other: Parker Stott and Kristin Townes; Andrew Harding and Brianna Gould; Lee Reynolds and Katie Byrd; Spencer Osbourne and Emma Witkin; Gabriel Diaz and Fatima Zahedi.

Gillian's antennae quiver at the sight of some of these. Spencer and Emma? Interesting! Gabriel and Fatima? No! Really? OMG!

Susie grabs your wrist. "I don't know any of these people!"

"Sure you do. These are your best friends. They know {i]all about you, Susie." You titter into your hand. "All your secrets and dreams and crushes and hideous embarrassments." You titter again at the horrified face Susie turns on you. "So you better get your game on!"

"Will!" Susie hisses, but with a laugh you're out of the car and running over to Eric and Rebecca.

"You have to hide me from Susie," you gasp at them. "She's in a weird mood!" You put them between you and your advancing friend.

"You two dykes just need to do it with each other," Eric chortles. "Break the sexual tension once and for all." Rebecca slaps him.

"Hey, where's Braydon?" Tim calls at you. "I got a story I want him to read."

"One of yours?" You push Eric at Susie (who has run up) and dart off to join Gerard and his two friends. "Is there anything to eat?" you ask them.

"Chips and pretzels. Yeah, I wrote it last Friday, it's got a black magician in it and I wanna see what Braydon thinks."

"Braydon doesn't like it when people write about warlocks, he thinks everyone's prejudiced against them. Tell your story to Susie, she'd love to hear it." You jump away as Susie catches up, and snatch the joint from Spencer's fingers as you pass. You take a short hit, return it to him, and tell him to share it with Susie, who is still pursuing you.

Down the line you go in this way. At the hibachi you ask about the bratwurst they're cooking, and when Tim bluntly asks you for a contribution you tell them to talk to Susie, as she's paying for everything today on account of you won a bet with her. You ask Brianna about her tiger-print jacket while secretly rolling your eyes at the bad henna dye she's given herself. (No professional could have possibly left her hair looking so limp and lifeless). You ask Katie what Gabriel and Fatima are doing together; she tells you it's because Fatima is mad at someone.

Susie finally corners you at the far end of the gauntlet, and Parker and Kristin watch with glinting eyes as she drags you back behind a Jeep so you can have a quiet consultation. It took Caleb almost ten minutes to catch up to you because he kept getting snagged by the others.

"So," you snicker. "Did anyone figure out you're a fake?"

"I can't do this," she whines.

"Sure you can. Susie's an airhead. She's almost as bad as Emma." You peer around the corner of the Jeep at the girl who had the idea for the party. She's a vacant-eyed giggler with a halo of reddish-brown hair that floats about her ears. She wears black onyx jewelry, and Gillian has always suspected that if she and Braydon ever broke up, her hubby would make straight for Emma despite the way she can't get more three sentences out without gasping "Oh my God!"

"But I'm not going to know what they're talking about!"

"You don't have to. That's the great part about being an airhead. Look, just go over to the ice chest and talk to Jack and Wendy. Flirt with him."

"I'm not gonna flirt with a guy!"

"You're be totally safe, he's gay."

Still Caleb protests, but you poke and poke until just get away from you he totters over to Jack and Wendy.

In addition to being gay, Jack Li is Chinese-American, which would put him at something of a double-disadvantage at Westside if his family wasn't also pretty rich. But at the moment, stretched out lazily on the grass in his long-sleeve t-shirt and jeans with Wendy sitting beside him, he just looks like another clean-cut senior. He grins up at you and Susie. "So tell me about your Saturday," he says to your friend.

And for the first time, your own heart skips a beat in sympathy with Caleb.

"I had fun." A ghastly grin spreads across her face. Gently, you grasp her by the elbows and kick at the back of her knees, so that she falls down next to Jack. He helps her down, and you feel Caleb stiffening all over. "Um," she says once she's on the grass with him. "Yeah, I had fun, even though it rained."

"Oh, did you get wet?"

"A little bit." Her grin is a rictus. You don't bother keeping a straight face as you settle in next to Wendy, but you fight to keep from laughing out loud.

"Yeah, they need to fix the roof," Jack says. "Which one had the leak?"

"Don't answer that," Wendy butts in. "It's none of his business."

"It might be, one of these days," Jack protests. "You don't know." He turns back to Susie. "It wasn't the last one, was it?"

"No, more toward the middle." She turns a terrified look on you.

"Gillian!" a voice calls. You look over. It's Brianna Kirschke. You wave, but she gestures you to come over.

"You stay here." You press a fingertip into Susie's thigh as you get your feet under you. "Jack," you tell him, "keep her here, but don't scare her."

"I'm like bears," he tells Susie as you trot off. "I'm more scared of you than you are of me."

Brianna smiles at your approach and says, "Good, I wanted it just you. How's Susie doing?"

"Fine, I guess. Maybe a little weirder than usual," you add, for you've decided that maybe Caleb needs a little cover. You twitch the cigarette from Dean, take a hit, then drop it to the ground and crush it beneath your toe.

Brianna looks past your shoulder. "She's not freaked out or anything, is she?"

"Why would she be—?"

You break off, for now you're worried that there's something going on that Gillian should know about.

Tim says, "Good, 'cos I just got word he's on his way here," while Brianna says, "Don't you know?"

"Know what?" A cold spot envelops your heart.

Brianna covers her gasp with the palm of her hand. "She didn't tell you? About ...?"

"About what?"

Brianna glances around, and leans close to you. Before she can speak, Dean snorts, "It's not a big-ass secret, Brianna." She spares him a brief glare before clutching you and pulling you close.

"Susie was at the Warehouse last night," she says in a low voice. "She wound up upstairs."

Upstairs? As in—? "No!"

"She didn't tell you!"

"No! Who with?"

"Some Eastman guy," Tim says. He waggles his cell phone at you. "And I just got word he's on his way out here."

"So I wanna know how she's doing," Brianna says. "In case, you know—" Her brows bunch up. "She doesn't want to see him."

That's probably a good idea. But hell— It would also be a lot of fun to see Caleb try to interact with the guy. And Susie is such an airhead he might get away with it!

1111112112211211132111341123.content:
As fun as it would be to stick around and watch Caleb squirm, it would be better if you left. For starters, you do have work that you need to get back to—the work that Gillian distracted you from. And if you stayed, Caleb would just try hiding out with you, and badgering you into rescuing him.

He's still preoccupied with Jack Li at the moment. He says he hasn't got any of Susie's memories or personality, but the expression of terror on his—on Susie's—face isn't out of character for her. Maybe it's something about her facial muscles, but even when Susie is happy she looks faintly worried, and even when she's partying it's like there's an undercurrent of panic. Oh my God! is Susie's favorite exclamation, and she doesn't so much walk anywhere as much as she scampers.

So you decide there's little chance of him blowing his cover. When he sees you looking in his direction, you motion at him to stay put. Then, when he isn't looking, you sneak away to your car and drive off without him.

It's going to be so funny when he catches up to you and is all, like, totally furious with you!

* * * * *

But you're not going to make it easy for him. On your way back into town you stop to text Braydon, ordering him to meet you again out at the Westside parking lot. There are almost a dozen cars there, parked up next to the gym, and from the far side of the parking lot you see that the tennis courts are occupied. You can't tell who's there, though. Since the tennis team is stocked with rich fucks like Kelsey Blankenship who could just as easily get a court up at the country club, it must be regular kids with nothing else to do on a Sunday evening. Losers.

When Braydon pulls up you crawl into his back seat with him. You're about to wrap yourself with a blanket when, on an impulse, you pull yourself up to him and kiss his chest through his shirt. "I'm going to leave you alone for the next week," you find yourself saying. "So I'm going to need— Rrngh!" You bite one of his nipples, and he jumps.

"What are you going to be doing?" he asks. It comes out as a sigh.

"I don't know. I'll distract myself with someone. Probably Susie."

"Hot."

"I know, right?" You pull him into a tighter embrace. "But I need you to— Mm. Fill me up? To hold me? Until then?"

"Fill you up?" His brows peak in the middle of his forehead. Like Susie, Braydon has a constant look of worry, but this look of worry means Do you really mean what it sounds like you mean?

"Make me feel good, Braydon," you murmur. Being inside Gillian is like being inside a hot steam bath, and you can't help relaxing into her personality and her instincts, especially now when you're about to abandon her. You pull the blanket up over yourselves. "Make me feel like you're going to miss me, and you need to— Rrrmmmhm. Tear off little chunks of me that you'll keep through winter."

And Braydon obliges. He leans over, like an overgrown child suckling at his mother's breast, and you cradle him your arms as he nuzzles at the tops of your breasts. Bit by bit, with your help, he loosens your top and peels it back, and lifts and pushes away your bra. For a quarter hour, at least, he nips at and tickles your breasts—including the tips— with his teeth and tongue. You relax all over, like your very bones are liquefying and puddling in your joints, and your fingers are like floppy rubber when you undo and pull off your skirt. Braydon puts his face between your thighs, and his tongue flicks in and out.

Relaxed is as far as you get, though, and not long after you've pulled off all of Gillian's clothes you force Braydon back so you can pull off the mask. You're still relaxed, though, after you're awake, and only the terror of being caught—as a naked Will Prescott—in the backseat of Braydon's car gets you moving. Braydon disrobes under the blanket with you (much to your distaste), and when he's got everything off you pull his face off and replace it with Gillian's.

Her mouth twists up in a half smile, and she peers at you from under her lashes. "That was nice," she says. "You wanna pick up where Braydon left off?"

That would be nice, but it's getting dark, and you also feel kind of strange being naked with her. (You also still feel her personality bumping around inside you, and Gillian would not be much interested in making out with herself.) Also, her cell phone has been vibrating, probably with messages from Caleb, and you should probably get her off and away so she can distract Susie.

So you grunt a negative and tell her to get dressed. "After that you can go home," you tell her.

"I can?" There's a mischievous note in her voice.

"Go home," you order her. "And stay away from me. From Braydon, I mean." You hesitated. "Go flirt with other guys."

"I guess I can do that." She doesn't sound disappointed. She's already getting into her underthings as she speaks.

You linger a bit with her, waiting to see if she has anything else to add. She doesn't, and when she's dressed again she just gives you a long, silent smile before getting out of the car. You huddle up inside the blanket and with gritted teeth try to squeeze the erection out of your cock without touching it. It doesn't want to go down, though, so after Gillian has driven off you press Braydon's mask back to your face.

The erection is still there—though it's Braydon's—when you wake again.

* * * * *

Back at Braydon's you get much less done than you would have hoped. His mom sends you to pick up a pizza, and she asks you to watch TV with her while the two of you eat it. You let Braydon's sense of guilt drag you along. His father ran off with another woman when Braydon was little, and his mom still holds something of a grudge against the male of the species as a result, so she doesn't have much of a social life. Fortunately, she got everything in the divorce, and her job as a restaurant manager at the IHOP keeps them comfortable, even if her hours are long and varied. You do get some reading done, but it leaves you restless, for there's nothing obviously and immediately useful in the Cornelius Agrippa, and you've no idea if it could lead to anything useful in the long run.

Gillian, at least, obeys your orders, and the next day at school, even in the classes you share with her, she only twinkles at you with a secret smile. You hide from Braydon's friends, and connect with Christian Knouse only long enough to tell him that you're going to have to miss the RPG session scheduled for that afternoon up at King Kong Komics. He doesn't sound broken up by your confession, though there is a snappishness to his reply, "Fine, it's just what this country needs, a lot more anti-social deviant fuckoffs." But maybe he's pissed about something else, because he's glaring around your shoulder when he says it.

You have Susie for fourth-period English, though—a class that you and she share with Will Prescott and Caleb Johansson. The person who looks like Caleb ignores you as you slither into Ms. Gladstone's classroom, but Will perks up and watches you all the way back to your desk. He only slumps when Susie comes in, but Caleb sits up sharply, and she flinches and crimsons as she squeezes past his desk. His golem, you notice, turns and stares at her ass as she passes. "You son of a bitch," she mutters when she passes your desk.

So Christian isn't the only one with a case of the Mondays. "You on the rag or something?" you ask her after class, as you're both on your way to the cafeteria.

"Fuck you. Bad enough you left me at the river with— Fuck you! But then I went to find you at Gillian's, and she only giggled at me while I spent a whole hour yelling at her, and only then did she tell me she wasn't you anymore. I called her a lying cunt, and it wasn't until I wrestled her down and pulled her face off—"

"You didn't!" you laugh.

"Fuck you. I almost went over to your place—Braydon's, you know—and put a rock through your window."

"Did you ever get Susie's memories?" You've paused just outside the door to the cafeteria, and there's enough noise and bother about that you're not worried about being overheard.

She snorts. "Yes. I woke up with them this morning."

"So why are you pissed off?"

"Fuck you," she says, and stomps into the cafeteria.

* * * * *

It's in sixth period—AP Latin II—as you are contemplating the dumpy Morgana Hollis—a would-be Wiccan—that you get an idea so obvious that you can't believe you didn't have it before.

"Sure I remember it," Ted Arnholm snorts as he examines the grimoire. "Hard to forget a hundred bucks that—" He looks momentarily startled as he opens the book and finds that the first few pages easily turn. He shoots you a dirty look which you return with an innocent one of your own.

"Aubrey Blackwell," he says, in answer to your next question. "It was in a batch we bought off him a few weeks ago."

Aubrey Blackwell. That's the anthropology professor you found earlier when looking up experts in magic. Interesting, you think as the small hairs on your back start to rise. "Why did he sell it?" you ask.

"Why don't you go ask him yourself?"

Why not indeed?

11111121122112111321113411232.content:
It's probably not a good idea to directly approach the former owner of the grimoire. You're even less inclined to approach him directly when you learn from Ted Arnholm of Arnholm's Used Books that the former owner is not only a university professor but is one of the experts that you turned up when you went Googling for help a couple of days ago. A man like that probably isn't an idiot.

In fact—

But you leave off puzzling over the matter when, in your distracted state, you almost run a red light.

* * * * *

"So what did I miss?" you ask as you saunter into the game room at King Kong Komics. Technically, it's a sandwich shop, with its own front door and everything in the strip center. But no one ever eats there, so Eric Kim, who operates it and the connected comics shop, lets Christian and his friends use it for their gaming sessions.

"Get out!" Christian snarls. "You said you had someplace else to be!"

"And I was there and I got it done." You hook a foot around the leg of a chair and pull it out. "Are we still sitting in the middle of that bog," you ask as you drop your bony ass into it, "or did you guys figure out a way to carry Tiny around?" "Tiny" is your character in this quest: a half-elf, half-giant.

"Someone wouldn't let us wake him up." Christian glares at Howie Baylor, who is running the campaign. "So we left him. That's how come you can just turn around and— Whhhttt!" He whistles through his teeth and points at the door.

"I didn't not let you pick him up," Howie retorts. "I let you roll. It's not my fault you're better at getting laid than at rolling a ten or higher."

Christian snatches up a die and shakes it menacingly under Howie's nose.

"Come on, let him catch up," Darrell Parton sighs. "We didn't get that far out of the bog." He squints at Hugh Flake. "That's one good thing about having an incompetent Ranger for a guide."

"He'd have to find his way out too," Christian retorts. "How many saving throws would you make him cast against getting lost?" he asks Howie.

"Shut up," Hugh mutters at Christian out of the side of his mouth. "You're trying to make things harder."

"Howie doesn't even let us pick our noses without rolling for the effect."

Howie looks hurt.

"Tell you what," you say. "Instead of saving throws, let's do it this way. It's practically the same thing. Darrell, think of a number between one and twenty-one. If I guess it right," you tell Howie, "Tiny gets out of the bog and catches up."

"The odds aren't the same," Howie protests.

"You're right. They're worse. One chance out of twenty-one instead of— What? Fifty-fifty? One out of three, at making a wrong turn?"

"But you'd have to make at least six saving throws. That's what I made the other guys do." Howie pulls on his lip, but a light comes into his eye.

Christian groans. "Oh God, look at that!" he exclaims as Howie takes up a pencil and starts flipping through the rule book. "He's going to do a statistical analysis! We could'a rolled you out of the bog by now! And you still won't make it, even if you—"

"Bet?" you taunt Christian.

"Three throws," Howie says. "I mean, three separate guesses. Uh—"

"Okay, Darrell," you say before Howie can start adding conditions. "Pick a number between one and twenty-one. Is it seventeen?"

Darrell's brow crinkles, and you kick him hard under the table. He gasps and sits up. You kick him again, and his jaw drops.

"Oh!" he says. "Yeah! It was! Er, seventeen."

"Cool. Nine?"

"Huh? Oh. Yeah, nine!"

"Seventeen again?" you ask. Howie's eyes pop, and a purple flush creeps up his cheeks.

"Wow. Yeah! You're, like, psychic!"

"That's! Not! Fair!" Howie howls. "You needed to write the numbers down!"

"No one said anything about writing anything down," you retort. "I just said I'd ask Darrell to think of a number between one and twenty-one. You went along with it, even calculated the odds we'd need to—"

"But—!"

"Fuck it, man, he got you," Christian says. He squints at you. "Fucking clever-ass son of a bitch."

Howie makes a noise like he's gargling rocks, but yields. Tiny joins the others, and the company proceeds on its quest.

But you're silent most of the rest of the session, preoccupied as you are with trying to be clever about something else.

You want to get a mind-band onto the forehead of Professor Aubrey Blackwell. The man's knowledge could be crucial to reviving your father. He is not only a putative expert on magic but was the previous owner of the grimoire. But a warlock—and that's what it sounds like he is—is not someone to be approached directly or carelessly.

* * * * *

"So send a fake," Susie Lekuawehe says. "You've got enough of them." She glances up from her cell phone long enough to shoot Gillian a dirty look.

It's ten o'clock, but The Crystal Cave is still open, and that's where your trio is hanging out. Your girlfriend—still remembering your orders—is playfully keeping her distance, and is curled up on the bench opposite you with her feet tucked under her. But though she has no words for you, she will still stare at you with twinkling eyes, and will gnaw provocatively on a cardboard stir stick. It serves her right when part of it comes off in her mouth, and she makes a face as she peels it off her tongue.

"Anyway," Susie continues, "why don't you go meet this guy yourself? Or are you too much of a chicken-shit?"

"Yes. The guy's an expert on this stuff. And he used to own the book, he's probably an expert on it too. Look at what we got up to with it. I'm not just gonna walk up to a guy who's probably made, like, all kinds of masks and things and ask him to explain it all to me."

"How smart can he be if he lost the book?"

That is a point, but it's not a point that makes you any more confident about approaching Professor Aubrey Blackwell directly. You doubt anyone could be such a butterfingers as to lose that grimoire. It makes you wonder if something happened to him. "Like what?" Susie asks when you voice the thought.

"Who knows? But maybe—" You glance at Gillian. "Maybe the fakes got the upper hand?" you suggest. "Maybe he lost control?"

Susie sucks in her cheeks. "So send in a fake," she suggests again. "Do a recon."

"That's what I'm thinking."

"Then why are you asking me—?"

"Well, who?" you explain to her. "I want ideas. Not you, not me, not my dad, not Gillian. Not anyone connected to us, or, you know, our aliases." Susie frowns at you, so you continue with a sigh. "You were all excited about making masks and having fun with them. Are you having enough fun as Susie?"

"Well I could, if—"

"Do you want a new mask?" you say, giving up on the attempt to be coy. "I'm asking you to suggest someone we could copy to send on the recon. Someone you'd like to have a copy of anyway, someone you'd—"

"Chelsea Cooper."

You rear back. The head cheerleader? "What? No! Be serious!"

"I am serious. Or how about one the Garners? Or Cindy?"

You facepalm. "Is it you or Susie who's being the bubble-brain? It has to be someone who can, like, jump on this professor. Overpower him. So we can get a mind band onto him, copy his brain. I don't think Chelsea could—"

"Chelsea wouldn't have to overpower him. She could just get into his lap and blow in his ear."

Now you bury your whole face in your hands. "Okay, I get what you're saying. But I don't think it's going to be that easy."

"Why not?"

"Well, what if he's gay? Besides, I don't think a professor is just going to let a strange girl get in his lap. There is such a thing as sexual harassment, you know, and I bet a lot of the people at the university would be worried about—"

"So you're saying you want me to think of a guy to use?" Susie says. "Ew!"

"Maybe a guy who has a hot girlfriend?"

"Oh!" She blinks. "Right. That could ... work." You roll your eyes.

"I was thinking someone like the Molester," you tell her. "Someone big and stupid and scary. We've got a mask of him anyway—you saw to that—so we could use that, I guess."

"Ick. No, let's get someone else." Her phone dings, and she makes a face at it. "We could use my brother," she says. "Susie's brother, I mean. I could get him no problem, but I don't think Sam— Well, what do you think? Do you think Susie's brother could get laid? He hasn't got a girlfriend."

"I think we should use someone who's not connected to any of our aliases. Just in case."

"Then what about someone from Eastman? That's about as unconnected to us as you can get."

"You can get someone from there?"

She winces and nods. "Sure. The guy I— That Susie spent the night with Saturday. He's a wrestler or something, and I guess he's pretty good-looking."

* * * * *

An Eastman wrestler sounds like a good idea, but even after you say so Caleb will insist on trying to use a girl, and his suggestions become ever more baroque. Copy one of the girls' soccer players, if you want a jock. Copy a teacher. Copy a girl and use her face to copy a teacher. You brush her ideas aside impatiently.

But once you're home, you decide that he might be on to something, particularly about using a teacher. Maybe a college student?
11111121122112111321113411232.title: The Clever Thing to Do

111111211221121113211134112322.content:
Caleb receives your decision in bad grace when you tell him the next morning. "You know what I'm going to have to do?" he moans. "I'm going to have to sleep with him again!"

You rake your eyes across the school library, which is crowded with students sheltering from the rain. "Why don't you say that a little louder, Susie?" you suggest. "Make sure everyone hears you." Gillian, who is snuggled up close to you, giggles.

"Fuck you!" Caleb hunches over the table. "It's gonna be Friday at the earliest before I do anything!" he hisses. "We could get a teacher or a cheerleader faster than that!"

"Maybe we'll get you one anyway. I'm thinking of you, you know."

"No you're not!"

"I am! If this guy is such a stud, think how you can use him to get laid after you get a copy of him. Then, same as you used Susie to get a copy of him, you could use him to get a copy of—" You roll your tongue around in your cheek.

Caleb's eyes narrow. "That's not what you're thinking!"

"I said it, so I must be thinking it."

"You've got that other plan in mind!"

"Sure I do. I don't want this thing traced back to Westside. And I can stand to wait a couple of days, if it takes you till Friday to meet up with this guy."

Caleb's complexion curdles. "I'd like to know how you got to be the boss."

"Because I'm the one in trouble." Also, you can't help thinking as you twist the ring on your index finger, I got Braydon's magic bling on my side.

* * * * *

But is it effective? You're far from convinced. Anyway, at the moment you want to master magical theory, not magical artifacts.

You left Arnholm's yesterday in a forward-thinking mood: How do I get to Aubrey Blackwell? Today, after school, you return to the bookstore with a different plan: To acquire other of the professor's cast-off books. You doubt that a warlock would really part with anything really valuable. But, you remind yourself as you park behind the bookstore, he did part with that grimoire.

Ted Arnholm doesn't look pleased to see you, and he snorts when you ask him to show you the other books that he bought that day from Professor Blackwell. "It was two months ago!" he reminds you.

"Can you show me the shelves where they might be? I want to buy them. All of them."

Those are the magic words, apparently, for there's no mistaking the glint of cupidity that comes into his eye. "Matt!" he shouts in a cracked voice, and a curly-headed college kid hurries over from the front counter.

"Hey, yeah! Let's check it out!" he enthuses when you tell him you want the titles of the books that Aubrey Blackwell sold the bookshop two months ago. Back at the counter, he opens up a laptop. "Must'a been a pretty big acquisition," he chatters brightly. "Those're the only ones we ever put in the records!" He taps furiously. "And we got a winner!"

He copies down some titles, then—still making meaningless small talk—he leads you around the bookstore. Most of books (no surprise) are lodged in the Occult and Paranormal section, but two of them are in the History section, and one is in the Science section. A search of the Special Collections turns up nothing, though. "Must'a sold that one to a collector," he laughs. You smile to yourself. Libra Personae is the title he has scribbled down for that spot. So that's the thing's name.

The total price for the dozen book or so books is well outside your budgetary range, so you only buy the ones with handwritten notes in the margins or inside the covers. Ted Arnholm comes over to glower at you while the still-burbling clerk checks you out. "Thought you were gonna buy all of them," he says.

"I am," you tell him. "Just not all at once."

The clerk guffaws, but he shuts up quick as Arnholm—a vein throbbing in his forehead—turns a snarling face on him.

* * * * *

The next few days pass normally—or at least with what passes for normality for Braydon Delp. You go to class. You talk with his friends. You attend two more gaming sessions. You get cornered in the boys' bathroom by George Mendoza and Joe Thomason, you taunt you as a queer, a pedophile, and a goat fucker. (You're rescued by Gary Chen, of all people, who barges in to demand why the fuck they're jerking off with you, and chases them out. You're grateful to him for about three seconds—before he grabs you by the neck and shoves you head first into the big bathroom garbage canister.) You spend your nights reading books on the occult. All totally normal experiences for Braydon Delp.

By Thursday night you're feeling antsy for company, so you summon Gillian to your house and drive out to the deserted parking lot of an elementary school, where you peel off her clothes and nibble her all over while she groans and pants and murmurs your name over and over again. You open up your own trousers, and without being ordered to she sucks you off until you cum. After that, you wrap arms around each other and hold each other until she starts to snore softly and your own eyes close. You drive home after she's woken from her cat nap.

Friday afternoon, after school, you meet up special with Susie, to confirm that she's got a special date. "Yes, it's all set up," she groans. "I'm meeting him at a party."

"Awesome." You hand her a mask and a mind-band. "I didn't glue them together," you explain, "'cos I figure it'll be easier to get the mind-band onto him. Like, you can palm it. Then when that's done with him but he's still knocked out, you can drop the mask on him. We can glue them together afterward."

"This better be worth it," she grumbles.

"You should already know if it is." You return her frown with a smirk. "I thought you already sucked him off."

She punches you in the side of the head.

* * * * *

Friday night is another game night with Christian and the guys, but this time there's pizza, and Eric Kim closes up early so he can join you. You have a hard time concentrating, though, for you're distracted by thoughts of Caleb and his mission for you. In fact, you're so distracted that after you've finished your share of the pizza you turn management of Tiny over to Eric and leave. But you can't concentrate back at your house either, and bemuse yourself into boredom by anticipating the adventure to come: Make that mask. Make another mind-band. Put on the mask. Go out to the college. Slap the new mind-band onto the professor. Take it all home. Put on the mind-band. Figure out how to fix my dad ...

You sigh deeply. As. If. Your eye will keep recurring to the books you bought, now piled up on your desk. They haven't done you a lot of good, though one of the margin notes has referenced a book on magic sigils. Unfortunately, a web search only turns up copies kept in the special collections at libraries in places like Oxford, where they are only accessible to scholars.

* * * * *

"Yeah, I didn't manage score a copy of that guy," Susie says with a yawn when you meet her Saturday morning for breakfast. She's not only got the yawns, but also the most impressive case of bed-head you've ever seen. Her mane of hair flies out in all directions, like she brushed it while gripping an electric fence in her free hand. "I think I got you someone just as good, though."

You're sitting in Salvation Donuts, a shop that's owned by the family that runs the Agape Christian Academy. Braydon loves to loiter there with coffee and a donut while wearing his most blasphemous and Satanic-looking gear. You've toned it down this morning, though, and have contented yourself with a vintage Black Sabbath t-shirt (horned skull and dancing skeletons) and the bicycle-chain necklace. "What happened?" you ask as you slurp your coffee.

"My date wasn't interested in me. Can you believe it?" She paws at her hair, and yawns. "Guys can be such shits, you know?"

"Did you get anyone?"

"Sure, I got you someone. One of the guys whose house it was. It was a real rager. House, front yard and back yard all packed. Anyway, I followed one of the guys outside and down the street, 'cos I didn't think I was gonna be able to get anyone without being a total slut about it, and I wasn't gonna do that. I caught up to him, talked to him, got the stuff onto him and then ran off."

"Lemme see."

She pulls the mask and mind-band out of her purse. You whistle at the tongue twister of a name on the band. "The guy's from Italy?"

"Was he?" She peers at the band, then shrugs. "He didn't have an accent. When are you going to use it?"

"Probably Monday after school."

"At least I didn't have to fuck him." She crinkles her nose at someone behind your shoulder, and you glance back to see the fat woman who owns the place scowling at you. "I want a girlfriend," Susie resumes in a loud voice, and she stretches her arms. "Someone with big tits I can suck on."

You smile and scratch your eyebrow, but you also take off soon afterward. Even Braydon has his limits on how far he'll go in taunting the opposition.

* * * * *

You glare at yourself in the bathroom mirror. Braydon's mom is gone, and you've divested yourself of Braydon's mask. You're wearing the mind-band that Caleb got for you—the first step in finding out if the guy he got will work for your plan.

He could work a little too well.
111111211221121113211134112322.title: The Waiting Game (Which Sucks)

choices: Copy another brain, and use it.
1111112112211211132111341123221.content:
You're halfway through the printed briefing before you notice that a muscle in your head has started to throb. You ignore it until you catch yourself rubbing a spot just behind and above your left year. That's when you pad into the kitchen to get an aspirin. Better to pop one pill to kill a migraine before it starts, your brother has told you—one of the few times you've been happy to accept his advice—than to pop two to make it go away.

But as you're shaking a capsule into your hand you hesitate long enough to concentrate on the muscle that's bothering you. That's when you realize it's one of your numinous muscles, not a physical one.

Fuck. Those only act up when there's something bothering you. You drop the capsule back in the bottle and return to the living room, where you sit cross-legged in the middle of the floor and meditate.

Bit by bit your review the major aspects of the assignment: A dead woman. A stolen legacy. A long-lost grimoire. A retrograde Stellae.

Ow. You wince, and surface to feel that muscle throbbing hard.

Bad enough that you and Joe are tasked with tracking down and recovering a book of powerful magic spells. But a book compiled by a renegade member of your own order? That threatens to be very ticklish.

But a grim smile spreads across your face. At least you now know what the throbbing in your head means. It's not a tension that comes from fear. It's a tension that comes from anticipation.

~ ~ ~ ~ ~

You jerk your head up, and with a groan squeeze the bridge of your nose. To your surprise—and discomfiture—you find yourself hunched up on Braydon's bed with your legs and feet tucked under you Indian-style. So powerful was the brain-band you put on that as you sank into its memories you actually began to act them out.

Because those weren't your memories that you were reviewing. They were the memories of a student at Eastman High named Frank Durras.

* * * * *

"Why'd you put it in your satchel?" Howie asks.

"Where else would I put it?" Christian retorts.

"The Fire Pit of Nashkrazubal is just at the far end of the Great Hall. You can carry it over to the fire pit in your hands."

"I thought you said the satchel had a Curse of Biting on it," Darrell says, but Christian's voice rises shrilly over his.

"Why the fuck am I going to drop the most valuable book in the multiverse into a fire pit?" he demands of the game master. "I'm gonna take it back to Minas Fuckburg and sell it!"

Howie's eyes—which even relaxed are as protuberant as a frog's—nearly pop out of his head. "You're gonna sell— You're not gonna destroy the most dangerous magical grimoire in the world?"

"It'll set me up for life. Every wizard back in town will mortgage his staff to get a chance to buy an uber-lich's book of recipes."

Howie gapes at the rest of the table: you (back in Braydon's mask), Darrell, Hugh Flake and his little brother. "Are you guys okay with this?" Howie demands.

"Meh," says Darrell. "It's the end of the campaign anyway, right?" He stretches. Who cares what happens after the curtain falls?"

"I was planning a follow up campaign," Howie says.

"Oh, now I'm definitely keeping and selling Count Mummyface's book," Christian says. "With the coin it'll get me, I won't even have to show up for the sequel."

Howie frowns blackly at him, and you face palm. A magical grimoire loose in the big city, thanks to an adventurer's greed ... It's a natural hook for a sequel storyline, and you can't believe Howie doesn't see it.

But probably Howie's already sketched out a plot line for sending your next group plunging through the Forest of Fuckdiddily and into the Mountains of Masturbation in quest of some giant diamond that's needed to forge the Cosmic Gauntlet of Jerkoffitude, and he'll stubbornly insist on sticking to it.

Howie and Christian are still arguing when the bell over the comic shop's door chimes. Gillian comes in, smiling that tight, mischievous smile she puts on when she's pissed about something but is trying to hide it. She grabs you by the ears and starts fiddling with them. "Hey, are you guys done with my hubby yet?" she asks the table.

"I'm done with them," you reply.

"Point of order," Christian says, and raises a long, skinny finger. "I call for a vote of confidence and the installation of a new game master."

"What?" Howie barks. "I told you, I'm already halfway through developing a follow up—"

"Which is why I'm seconding my own motion."

"You can't do that!"

"Since when do we have votes and stuff?" Hugh asks.

"I nominate Harrison," Gillian says, and Hugh's fourteen-year-old brother jumps in his seat.

"I second the motion," you say. "And with that I have to go," you add, for you've looked around Gillian and spotted a very embarrassed-looking Susie loitering near the register.

"We have to have a vote!" Howie protests.

"No we don't," you retort as you rise. "But if you're going to have a vote, Darrell can cast mine." You clap him on the shoulder.

"That's not part of the rules!"

"Christian," you call back as you lead Gillian back into the comic shop proper, "move for a vote on amending the rules. Hell, move for a vote on having rules." Howie's bellowed protests mix with Christian's barking laugh as you saunter out.

"Did you have fun?" Caleb asks when you're in the parking lot.

"Did you?" you retort. Susie had to do something with her family, which was the only reason you spent this Saturday afternoon and evening with Christian's RPG group. "Oh, did you know that Hugh has a crush on you?"

"On Susie?"

"No, on Johansson," you retort. (You've no idea if Hugh has a crush on Susie, but you feel like stirring up trouble.) "Where are we going? I assume we're meeting up someplace," you add, for Gillian and Susie arrived in one car, while you've got Braydon's. Balducci's Pizza, after a little discussion, winds up being the choice of hang out.

"I thought you had some work to do," Susie says when you're seated in a booth and have ordered. The TV in the corner of the room is blaring out a college football game, and that will cover the sound of your conversation, but you've already scoped out the room for evidence of unwanted potential eavesdroppers. "Instead you went off playing with—"

"I did do some work," you retort. "And I had to do some thinking. In the campaign, our adventuring group was trying to recover and destroy an evil grimoire. I thought maybe it would give me some ideas for dealing with our evil grimoire."

Susie's jaw drops open. "That's the stupidest idea you've come up with yet, Prescott."

"You never know where good ideas will come from," you sniff, and take a sip of your Pepsi.

~ ~ ~ ~ ~

The book is called the Libra Personae, you wrote while wearing Frank Durras's brain-band earlier in the afternoon. It seemed like a good idea to get down on paper a rough idea of what he knew before you had to disentangle his brain from yours and return to Braydon's mask. It was written in the early 17th century by Hieronymous von Gerssdorff, who was a renegade Stellae.

You crossed out "renegade" and replaced it with the more accurate "retrograde." As for what a "Stellae" is ...

The Stellae Errantes is an order of astrologically sensitive people that goes back thousands of years. They possess certain prodigies—

You paused and added "things like superpowers" in parentheses after "prodigies," even though it made Frank's personality wince.

—that they use to hunt and destroy evil creatures, black magicians, magical implements, etc. These they regard as too dangerous to be left laying around. There are only three dozen or so Stellae in the entire world, and two of them are here in Saratoga Falls, enrolled at Eastman. They are still in training, and were sent undercover to find the Libra because the Order got news that it was in Saratoga Falls. This is their first real mission.

Their names are Giovanni Braccioforte and Franz Liebesspruch, but they are living here under the names Frank and Joe Durras. Frank's prodigies come from Mars and Saturn, and Joe's from the Sun and Mercury. Joe is the smart one, and Frank is the strong one.

You spent a long time chewing on the end of your pen before resuming.

Joe is probably smart enough to figure out the Libra, and maybe to figure out a way to fix Dad. There are other Stellae who probably could too. If I showed them the Libra, and Dad, and explained things, they—

Here you stopped, and stopped for good. The Stellae take a very dim view of magicians. They wouldn't kill you—Frank's memories assured you of that—but there wouldn't be any fun times after you came clean with them. At best, they would force you to explain everything to your Dad after they fixed him for you, and that would be horrible enough.

But it would fix things, and wouldn't it be a relief to be rid of the Libra and all the problems that came with it?

~ ~ ~ ~ ~

Almost you yielded. But then Braydon's mother came home, and you had to quickly change into his mask. The influence of Frank's personality vanished, and Braydon's came to the fore. Now you're thinking it would be better—and cooler—to score a copy of Joe's brain, and use his knowledge to fix things yourself while allowing yourself to keep the book.

It would still be dangerous to leave them at large, though. Maybe the very best thing would be to hide them under some masks—as you've hidden Gillian under a mask—so they can't get in your way.

* * * * *

None of this have you told Caleb.
1111112112211211132111341123221.title: When Quest Hooks Cross

11111122.content:
Friday comes, and you take the blank mind band to school so you'll have it with you for your first day at Salopek. You've not forgotten that you need those chemicals for the next spell.

You spend your first hour at Salopek filling out lots of paperwork and receiving a lot more; you don't think you've made a friend of the secretary when you ask if you'll get paid for the hour. (You will.) She then leads you from the front office through wide alleys to an open, hanger-like building at the rear of the complex, where she introduces you to your supervisor, a tall, rangy man with a tanned and crinkly face. "Andy Keyes," he says, giving you a firm handshake. "Nice to meet you, Will."

"Likewise, sir." The man's smile is tight but friendly, and though he seems very businesslike you think you will like him.

He leads you over to a table and has you pick up a hardhat. "Not much of an orientation for this job," he says. "Just do what you're told. I'll put you with one of the boys and you can spend today getting a feel for the place. I'm not around much--they give me a lot of ground to cover--so stick to him and you'll be okay. Sean!" he calls, and a head bobs up from behind some machinery.

Keyes introduces him as Sean Mitchell, another senior at Westside. He's blonde and broad-shouldered, with meaty pecs showing under his tight t-shirt. Instantly you peg him as a football player. But you pay as little attention to the sports teams as you can get away with, so you're not sure.

And that means you're extra surprised when he talks as though he knows you. "Hey Prescott," he says as he crushes your hand in a muscular paw of his own. "Heard you were getting a job out here. Cool." You nod as cheerfully as you can, and mumble something about being glad to have him to hang out with at work.

Keyes doesn't waste much time after introductions, and instructs Sean briefly about what to do with you. Sean nods along enthusiastically, and after he's gone, he slaps you in the stomach. "So, your dad works here too?"

"Yeah. He's put me onto the job. Made me take it. Does your dad work here too?"

Sean's face tightens. "Mm, no."

"You made it sound like he did."

"No. Oh." He nods with sudden understanding. "I just meant, you're working here, and your dad works here too. You're lucky you got an old man who can give you an in."

You shrug. "Well, if you say so. I guess. Though it's not like I really want to be here or anything. I mean—" You stop, for it suddenly strikes you how surly and ungrateful you're sounding. "It is great, but I wasn't asking any favors to come out here, it was more his idea, and I was like, Yeah, sure, that'd be good -- "

Luckily, Sean interrupts this embarrassing babble with a laugh. "No, I get you. Dads can be that way, right? 'Here's something to keep you out of trouble, you lazy sack of shit!' Huh?" He laughs again, and gestures you to follow him into the back of the building.

You relax. Maybe things will be alright.

At the moment, Sean shows you and explains to you, he's been fussing with a big piece of equipment that resembles the unlikely offspring of a hippopotamus and a steam shovel. "They're moving this to another building," he tells you, "but it's bolted to the floor. I'm having a hell of a time finding all the places where it's attached, so I'm really glad you showed up. Crawl under this thing with me and let's find those bolts."

* * * * *

It's dirty, grimy business that takes the better part of forty-five minutes to finish, and before it's done Sean has to fetch something that looks like a small jackhammer in order to remove most of them. But large parts of the table still have to be disassembled before the rest can be removed. "Shit," he says, wiping a streaming forehead with his shirt tail. (You use your hand to wipe your own forehead; Sean has abs that can withstand being glimpsed, but you only have shallow plank that jiggles with a layer of baby fat.) "No way we're getting this done today, and I'll have to talk to Andy about it." He trots over to a phone on the far wall, leaving you alone to take in the hanger.

The ceiling is very high, and the concrete floor is mostly open. But there is lots of machinery and tables and heavy cabinets stacked high by the walls. There are also a couple of open bays in the floor where, you guess, vehicles can be parked and worked on from underneath. You wander around without going far, trying to see if there is anything that looks like it might be useful in that spell. But you don't want to get caught snooping.

As luck would have it, Sean returns with a plan that will let you do all the snooping you could want. "Andy says to leave it for tomorrow. Probably they'll get it taken out in the morning. I'm supposed to just give you a tour of the complex."

After covering the hanger, he leads you out to explore the rest of the grounds. It's a spacious complex spread over many, many acres, surrounded by a high chain link fence topped with hurricane wire. He points out the various buildings and their uses, and telling you which ones you will probably have to do jobs in. "Not a lot of call for brain work in this position," he says. "Mostly you'll be moving things."

"That's what I told Caleb."

"Johansson?"

You're still more surprised to see that he knows Caleb's name. "Yeah, he wanted this job. Thought it would give him an 'in' with the company."

Sean laughs. "Well, unless he can build a working rocket motor from a lot of baling wire and some plywood, I don't think he'd catch anyone's attention."

"Are there, like, explosives and stuff around here?" you ask. It's a wretched segue, but it's the first chance you've had to wrench the conversation around to the subject.

"We got all kinds of shit around here. You won't be touching it, though, so don't worry. You need special training for that. I only know where it is because they tell me where it is so I won't trip over it. They give you a manual at the front office?" You nod. "Study it tonight. It'll have all the warning stuff in it."

You're glad he thought you were afraid of getting close to that kind of stuff, instead of fishing for information so you could steal it.

"Last stop is right here, then we'll knock off," he says, leading you up to a nondescript tan building. "It's our internal distribution center. They'll sometimes send you over to pick things up." He tugs on the door, but it doesn't open. "Jack musta stepped out a moment," he says. He checks his watch and thinks a moment. "Aw, heck, he won't mind if we break in. Stupid."

"What?"

Sean is punching numbers on a keypad. He tries the door, but it still won't budge. He thinks a moment, and curses quietly to himself.

"What is it?"

"Just bullshit." He punches at the keypad again, and this time the door opens. "We had some stuff go missing a few weeks ago, so they stepped up security on this building. Now they're supposed to lock up when there's no one inside." He ushers you in. "They also changed the keypad combo. Which is typical management idiocy, since the burglars came in through a window."

The inside looks a bit like a post office, with a long counter at the front. He leads you around it and through a door into a space filled with metal shelves, most of them empty. "Doors back there," he gestures, "for taking big stuff in and out. This side is for stuff that's come in. The other side is for stuff that has to go out." He grunts. "Not a lot in here now."

"It seems like a big space for not very much."

"When it gets busy we have a lot." He glances down, and kneels to tie his shoe.

Your heart leaps. His head is near one of the shelves. All you have to do is bend behind him and you can put the mind band to his forehead; you can pretend afterward that he cracked his head as he stood up again. Except he's got that hardhat on ...
11111122.title: The New Job

111111221.content:
Fuck it, it's an excellent chance. You pull the band out and lean over Sean. He jerks a little as you put your hand to his forehead. Then he falls forward.

Your heart hammers in your chest as you wait, using the time to roll him over and knock the hardhat off. You hear the outside door open, and footsteps, and you hold your breath, wondering if this Jack person is going to materialize. But no one comes in. When the band reappears some minutes later on Sean's forehead, you sweep it back into your pocket and bend down to slap lightly at his cheeks.

With a groan, he opens his eyes and sits up. "Dude, that sounded like it hurt," you say in a quaking voice.

"What happened?"

"You started to stand up again, and whang--" You tap the edge of the shelf. It rattles lightly. No way it would knock someone out.

He looks up at you suspiciously. "I thought--" He frowns, looks at the shelf, looks down at his hardhat, and blinks. "Huh."

You wince at the way he brushes you off as you try to help him to his feet. "Well, that's enough for today." He leads you back out, nodding briefly at Jack--who turns out to be a portly man in his fifties--and striding purposefully toward the front building. For the rest of the day Sean is very brusque, and most of the friendliness has drained from him.

* * * * *

Your dad is waiting for you at the front office, where he greets you with gruff cheer and asks about your day. You do your best to be enthusiastic, though you are rather daunted at having to talk in front of Sean and the receptionist. He then asks Sean about your first day; Mitchell says good things about you, but both his words and attitude are very muted.

Your dad accompanies you to your truck, and leans in at the window after you've gotten in. "Alright, what did you do?" he growls.

"Do? Nothing!" Your dad bores holes in your denial with his eyes. "What? It was just a first day. You think I screwed up already?"

"Mitchell didn't seem that pleased with you."

"That's just Mitchell," you retort, and twinge internally at the unfairness of what you said.

His eyebrows go up. "You know your supervisor that well already?"

"He's not my supervisor. Look at him. I go to school with him. He knows me."

"Oh, God," he groans.

"Dad! Just give me a chance! Jesus!"

"Watch your language. But keep your nose clean and your hands in your pockets when they're not asking you to use them."

"Okay!" You roll your eyes, and with a snort he turns away.

* * * * *

You finger the band in your pocket after he's gone, but the conclusion to your workday has left you feeling sour, and you want to get your mind off Mitchell, not crawl into his. You don't want to go home and you don't want to see Caleb either, so you go find Keith at his house. "How was your first day at Caleb's job?" he teases.

Fuck. "Shut up. It was lousy."

"Really? After that huge build up Johansson was giving it, I thought you'd see angels blowing trumpets overhead."

"Yeah, well, it's just manual labor. Oh, and you know Sean Mitchell? Get this, he works there, I'll be seeing him every day. Fuck."

His brow furrows. "Sean's a good guy."

"Yeah, but I think he's got a grudge against me now." You give him the airbrushed version of the accident in the warehouse. "He thinks I sucker punched him or something."

"Pfft. With your arms? You couldn't sucker punch a Girl Scout."

"Some of those girls are hard core," you retort, surprising even yourself with the screwball turn. "Like, I saw this twelve-year-old scout the other day, and she looked like a sumo wrestler who got hit with a shrink ray." That marks a permanent evolution in the conversation, and you feel much better by the end of it, good enough to broach the subject of Sean again. "You have Sean for any classes?"

"Yeah, Santiago, first period."

"Can you talk to him tomorrow, tell him I feel really bad about this first day and what happened?"

Keith's expression falls. "Don't you believe in talking to people yourself? You got Caleb trying to find out about Lisa--"

"That's another thing," you exclaim, snapping your fingers. "Chelsea Cooper was-- No, never mind. What were you saying?"

"Chelsea Cooper was what?" You shake your head, and he grips you by the shoulders. "Chelsea Cooper was what?! Naked? Touching herself? Kissing another cheerleader?"

"She was just at my locker the other day, made a smartass comment about me and Lisa."

"Chelsea Cooper talked to you?!"

"To insult me, yeah!"

"I'd let Chelsea Cooper cut off my left nut if she asked me herself."

"And she'd fry it and eat it," you snap. "It wasn't fun. But what were you saying?"

"I dunno." He shrugs.

"Well, will you talk to Sean for me tomorrow?"

"Oh yeah. No, I won't. Talk to him yourself and apologize if you're feeling so bad."

"I will. I just want you softening him up by asking what happened, tell him I was obsessing about screwing up with him. You know, call me a neurotic if you want. Bitch about me, the harder the better so he'll know I feel sincerely horrible about it."

"Do you? Do you feel sincerely horrible about it?"

"I don't give a shit. But it'll be easier working out there if he's not being a dick to me."

* * * * *

You stare in the mirror, and the reflection bores holes back at you. You let your eyes drift over your features: irregular, a little dopey. Stiff blonde hair that sticks out of from under your hat the way straw sticks out of a scarecrow. A nasty patch of zits erupting on your forehead. Your lips are chapped.

Slowly you look down and rub your arm. A thing of no muscle, but you push up your sleeve and grip the bicep. As you flex you press your hand to your weak chest. Not an impressive body. A least you haven't a belly, even if there is no definition to your stomach. You pull up your shirt: oh, a cute little innie. You pull your jeans down slightly so that your boxers show. You like the effect; a baggy-jean look might suit you.

But these aren't baggy. They are very tight as your cock thrusts outward, distending them. Dammit, you're turning yourself on by scoping out your own body!

You shake your head, trying to clear it, and jump back onto the bed, hugging your legs and biting your knees. Damn, being in another body is so exciting, even one as mediocre as Prescott's.

No, as mine! you have to remind yourself. But after putting on Sean's mind band it's been a little hard keeping your identity straight.

His mind had come in a rush after you'd put the band on, and then it had vanished. You opened your eyes and wondered where he had gone. But after you'd sat up and started looking around, a sort of double vision enfolded you. It was your room, something so boring and familiar; but it was also a strange place you'd never seen before. As you flipped through the papers on your desk you felt a small illicit thrill, as though you were snooping. It was much messier than ... than your other desk. You'd blinked hard at that thought.

You knew exactly what Mitchell's bedroom looked like, where he kept his stuff, what the ceiling looked like when he lay back in bed and ... Yikes. You'd probed only a little further, gently, as you strolled around your own bedroom, taking it in with a stranger's eyes. Then your gaze had been caught by the mirror.

You take a deep, ragged breath as you grip your legs more tightly. And you thought you were excited by the discovery of the book. Sean's head would explode ...

Moved by curiosity as to what your secret alter ego is up to, you shift over to the computer and check his email and log into his Facebook account and some of the message boards he frequents. They don't tell you anything you don't already know, though it's gratifying to see the nicely encouraging replies to his latest bit of fiction.

Then you sit back and trawl for the information you intended to find. Yes, some (though not all) of the elements you'll need for the next spell are out at Salopek. Getting them would be no problem for Sean, as, despite what he'd implied, he's checked out to handle them. For Will Prescott, though ...

You glance over at the blank mask that is now fully polished. You can now think of at least one very good use for it.
111111221.title: The Boy with Two Brains

1111112212.content:
Yeah, the safest way to lay your hand on the chemicals would be to go in while pretending to be Sean; that way if anyone caught you there'd be no awkward questions.

Except that Sean would be around, too. Would there be some way of getting him out of the way? Or going in when he's not around?

Ah! He's supposed to go out of town this weekend to visit his grandparents, and as it is an extended trip he's slated to take Friday off. That's when you could go in. But then you'd be the one missing work. Hmmm ...

"Will!" It's your dad's voice.

"Yeah?"

"Don't 'yeah' me, mister. When I call, you come down."

Without bothering to remove Sean's mind band, you rush downstairs. Your father stands glowering in the living room. You gulp a little to see that he's holding the thick binder of work-related material you were given to study. "Have you even looked at this thing?"

"Uh, a little."

"Okay, let's see how much you absorbed," he says acidly. He jerks his head, and you follow him into the dining room with a sinking feeling.

Twenty-five harrowing minutes later he pushes the binder away and stares at you in frank disbelief. "You picked all that up just by looking at it a 'little'?" he says.

You shrug. "Mostly it seems like common sense," you improvise. Thank goodness you still had Sean's mind band on, and that he's an expert on Salopek's many policies and warnings.

Your dad shakes his head. "And yet your school work just seems to bounce off you. Well," he sighs. "Carry on."

* * * * *

"Hey Sean, is there any way I'd be able to miss work on Friday?" you ask him the next day at school.
