He turns to stare, and his manner, though not exceptionally unfriendly, is distinctly cool. "It's not school. You can't skip," he says bluntly.

"I know that. I just mean, if I asked to take the afternoon off, do you think I could get it?"

"You just started, and you're already asking for days off? That's really not gonna go well."

"Thing is, I'm supposed to have a dental appointment, and they called to reschedule and wanted to know if I could come in Friday afternoon," you lie.

He looks skeptical. "You can ask, but even asking isn't going to make you popular." Now he is very frosty.

"Well, thanks for being honest with me," you say, feeling a little desperate to get back in his good graces. "You were just awesome with me yesterday, I really appreciate it. So, um, I guess I'll see you Friday."

"You'll see me this afternoon." The chill, if possible, deepens.

"Of course, I didn't mean that. I'm just saying I'll be there Friday and see you then, too."

His lips purse, and he grunts. Clearly he doesn't want to have to say that he won't be there on Friday. You scuttle away crabwise before things become worse.

* * * * *

Friday. You snap the brim of the ball cap low over your brow and check yourself out in the rearview mirror. Your disguise is as good as you can make it. The face and body and mind of Sean Mitchell are perfect, of course, but you'd had to improvise with the wardrobe, employing one of your rarely used polo shirts and khakis. It should do, however, until you can get into his work locker and change into the extra stuff he keeps there.

Getting the mask had been tricky, and you'd only managed to score it yesterday. Sean had been on his back on the floor of the machine shop, working under some equipment. You werestanding over him with the mask (you'd been carrying it with you for the past few days) wedged against the side of your hip between your underwear and your jeans. You pretended to accidentally knock a heavy hammer off the equipment; Sean winced and looked away as it clanged heavily onto the floor next to his head. In a flash, you had the mask out and pressed to his face. Then you knelt, hiding him from view, until it reappeared. After you'd woken him back up he cursed you out hard as an accident-prone fuck up and said he'd have to report you. It made you feel bad, since you do like Sean and wish he'd like you. For that to happen, of course, you'd have to stop knocking him cold ...

Taking a deep breath, you exit your truck and stride to the front office.

"I thought you had the day off," Debra, the receptionist, says in surprise.

"Things fell through, thought I'd come in and work anyway," you say. "That gonna be a problem?"

"We couldn't find anyone to cover for you," she says, "so Andy'll be happy to see you. Oh, and Will Prescott called, said he'd be late."

You snort. "Guy's just begging to be fired. Well, when he shows up, send him to find me."

Outside, you look around to check that the coast is clear. The alleys aren't crowded, but no one is paying attention to you, so you're able to get to Sean's locker and change into some of his clothes. Then it's off to score some empty containers. You check your shopping list and trot off to your first destination.

Within the thirty minutes you have all but two of the liquids--some quite flammable--that you need, and decided to sneak some of them back out to the parking lot. But on your way out you run into Keyes. "You already finished in the distribution center?" he asks in surprise.

You blink. "Huh? Oh, I had to step out to the head."

"You give Prescott that warning?"

"Sir?"

"Prescott. He showed up?"

"I haven't seen him."

"You said his truck was out front."

You pale. "I did?"

He looks at you over the top of his glasses. "Are you feeling okay?"

"Yes sir. I just haven't seen Prescott. Uh, not yet."

He rolls his eyes, and which then settle on the four containers you're clutching. "What's that?"

"Uh, I'm not sure. I ran into Jorge on the way back and he asked me to step this over to the front gate for him."

"Well, take this with you, give it to Debra for me." He thrusts a manila folder at you and walks away.

Slowly you return to the front office. Debra looks up at you in exasperation. "You here to tell me again you've decided to come in to work?"

You swallow hard. "No, just dropping this off for Andy." You shift items, almost dropping them, and present her with the folder Keyes gave you. "Anything else?"

"You tell me," she says somewhat waspishly. "Oh, but tell Prescott to trot around to see his dad. The man isn't happy."

You slowly walk out into the parking lot. (Luckily, no one challenges you.) It sounds like Sean actually decided to show up for work, and it's only a blessed coincidence you haven't run into him yet. Well, maybe it's not such a coincidence; it's a big complex, and it sounds like he's been stuck inside the distribution center since he arrived.

You stash the chemicals in the back of your truck, thinking all the while. The safest thing is to ditch Sean's mask and go back in as yourself, pleading an accident, like a flat tire. But it sounds like you're on the verge of getting fired, and if that happens you won't be able to get back in to snag the rest of what you need. Maybe you should just try running the table while you still can.
1111112212.title: The Copycat

111111222.content:
Sean pulls the knot tight and stands up again. He looks around the storage space with his hands on his hips.

"So," he says cheerfully, "we got like fifteen minutes till quitting time. Not enough time to do anything except goof off. Come on." With a wink he leads you over to far corner of the storage space, and to a big cabinet filled with a lot of dusty packages and envelopes.

"This is the dead collection," he says. "Stuff that got misdirected or returned or just came in or came back unclaimed. They clean it out every few months or so, but Jack makes sure that this one always stays." He digs through a box and pulls out a dark bottle. "A little end-of-your-first-day nip?" He waggles his eyebrows, and you grin back.

He takes one big gulp, makes a face, and hands it over to you. It's Scotch—hard and sharp and smoky, and it makes your eyes water, and sets you to coughing. "Been too long on beer, huh?" Sean laughs, but there's no meanness in it. "That's enough," he says, taking the bottle back from you and replacing it. "One good belt before we knock off, enough to make us feel good but not enough to really do anything." He smacks his tongue around in his mouth. "Don't abuse it," he says, and his expression sobers and hardens. "We had some guys who got stinking drunk on the stuff over the summer and got fired. Luckily, they didn't spill about where they got it."

"That sucks."

His expression hardens even more, and his eyes flash. "They were assholes," he says in a low voice. "Couple of guys from Eastman, underage, so the company really had no choice but to come down hard."

The liquor has set your insides on fire, and it does feel good, and with a happy eye you lazily survey the contents of the "dead cabinet." Just a lot of boxes and manila envelopes, pretty dusty.

But one of them on the lowest shelf has been opened. "What's that one?" you point.

"Huh?" Sean frowns. "That's funny. If it was opened, someone must've taken a look and decided it wasn't for him. Jack should have sealed it up and sent it back to the sender." He kneels and examines the flaps, then looks up at you in surprise. "It's addressed to your dad."

You kneel next to him. Sure enough, it's addressed to Salopek care of "Harris Prescott," but the top has been torn completely open. There's nothing inside that you can see except a loose sheet of paper and a lot of packing peanuts. While Sean runs his fingers through the peanuts you take out the paper and unfold it. It's a packing sheet, listing a bunch of items, all very plain and uninteresting, except for one word that leaps out at you: "Masks."

"Hey, who's back there?" a sharp voice calls from the other end of the room. You and Sean both wheel; you crumple up the paper and stuff it into your back pocket.

"Hey Jack," Sean calls back. "Is it quitting time yet?"

"If it's six thirty, it is for you, yeah. Son of a bitch." It's dim in the warehouse, but you can make out the shadowy figure of the distribution center overseer.

"Okay then, we're outta here." Sean picks up the mystery package and lofts it onto his shoulder. He slaps you lightly on the back. "You should head back to the front office, check in, see if there's anything you need to do. I'll run this over by your dad's office, see if there was some kind of mix up."

You briefly toy with offering to take it yourself, but you really don't want to see your dad. You leave Sean and the building supervisor talking at the front counter about the mystery box.

* * * * *

Unlucky you, your dad is in the front office waiting for you. Your heart thumps hard, out of fear he'll smell the alcohol on your breath, but he just gruffly asks about how your first day went, then sends you home. Not until you plop down in your truck do you feel the paper in your pocket and remember to pull it out.

It doesn't seem any more interesting on closer inspection, listing two books; one manila folder; three bags, each containing "metallic strips (3)"; five masks; and a roll of undeveloped film. Naturally, you frown over the word "masks," though it obviously shouldn't have anything to do with your discovery at Arnholm's. But why would anyone be sending masks of any type to your dad at his work?

You look at the top of the packing list, and the mystery deepens. The return address is some town in New York, but it's not addressed to your dad at all, but to someone named Shabbleman in the town of Cuthbert. A twitch passes through your upper back: You have relatives named Shabbleman who live in Cuthbert, a backwater hillbilly town a few hours drive from Saratoga Falls.

"Dad?" you ask him later that evening. "Did Sean Mitchell drop off a package at your office near the end of work, after you saw me?"

"No. What's the story?" You tell him briefly about finding the box in the distribution center. "He must've missed me while I was talking to you. By the way, have you started looking through that work binder yet?"

You were going to show him the packing list, but the sentence dies on your lips. There's probably a company policy against walking off with documents. You tell him you were studying the binder up in your room, and that's what reminded you about the package, then trot back upstairs before he can tell you to return to the books.

* * * * *

Sean confirms your dad's deduction the next day, telling you that he had to return the box to the distribution center and that Jack would be handling it. And, like your dad, he asks if you studied the binder. "There's some pretty dangerous stuff around here, and you have to know how to avoid it, since you're not cleared to handle it." You nod your head dutifully, but he gets a playfully skeptical look. "Come on, let's give you a quiz." He leads you into a back room in a small building and opens up a cabinet that's stacked high and deep with bottles. "What's the stuff you shouldn't touch?"

"All of it?"

He laughs. "Good policy. But c'mon, more specific." He alternately nods and shakes his head as you pick your way through. "Yeah, those two are the worst things to get into," he says, pointing to two big brown bottles with big red stickers on them. This stuff—" He reaches up to take a bottle, but it slips from his hand and shatters on the floor. You step back, but he is even quicker. "Watch out!" he yells, and grabs you around the shoulders. As you topple backward, you feel his warm hand upon your forehead ...

* * * * *

You wake with a groan to find your nostrils filled with a terrible stench. A rather ashen-faced Sean peers down at you. "Well, no real harm done," he says. "Hope you enjoyed your nap."

"What happened?"

"Stupid me, I knocked something off the shelf. You got a snootful. I got it covered up with sawdust and it'll be okay, but you were out for a few minutes."

You feel yourself paling. "Should I head over to the infirmary?'

He shakes his head. "A nap is the worst thing that happens. I'll have to report myself, though." He swears softly to himself.

* * * * *

It's the start of a run of bad luck at work. The next day you're knocked to the ground by a heavy box, and on Wednesday you bang your head hard on some machinery. Sean chides you for your clumsiness, but says he won't report it: "Just learn to be more careful," he tells you.

But the following Monday brings the worst yet. You managed to finish polishing up the new mask over the weekend, and on your way home from work you stop by the elementary school to check the status of your supplies, as you're not sure whether you have enough material to make another mask. To your horror, you find that your lock has been removed from the door and that the basement has been rearranged—apparently the maintenance staff has found your hiding place. Desperately you search for your stuff but find it's all gone, including bags of dirt you filched from the cemetery. You break out sweating as you tear through and cabinets, and with a groan discover that the mask you made of yourself has also been removed. In fact, it looks like someone knew exactly what to look for and what to take, for as near as you can tell only the things you brought down or made have gone missing.

You thank your lucky stars that you kept the book back at your bedroom instead of stashing it here.

Your head is spinning as you head over to your house, but you've no time to get it all sorted out. Umeko's car is out front, and you find her in the living room, talking to your mom and brother. Her eyes twinkle as she turns toward you. "So, what movie do you want to see?" she asks you without preamble.

"Beg pardon?"

Her eyes crinkle in that adorable manner that sets your heart thumping. "Don't you want to see a movie with me?"

"I do!" Robert says, leaping off the sofa.

You shoot him a dirty look. This is an unexpected, though welcome, surprise, and you'd like her all to yourself. On the other hand, you are severely distracted by what you found—or didn't find—back at the elementary school, and are not sure your head would be in the right spot for any kind of play date with your cousin.
111111222.title: The Mystery Box

choices: Put on the mask and go exploring in it.
11112.content:
With the mask hidden behind your back, you saunter into Robert's room and lean inside the open doorway; he is instant messaging, and glances irritably over his shoulder. "What do you want?"

"Just being nosy," you reply. "I wanted to see how a loser wastes his Saturday evenings."

"Then go watch yourself in a mirror," he retorts. "At least I've got something to keep myself busy."

"Tsk tsk," you cluck. "If you call that 'keeping busy.' You can't even get a date."

"And where's your date," he says sarcastically. "Oh yeah, she broke up with you."

"At least I had a girlfriend to break up with me," you snigger. "Poor little Bobby—" he hates the diminutive form of his name "—can't even get a girl." He ignores you and just keeps tapping away at the keyboard.

This isn't going the way you intended; you were hoping to provoke a fight that would lead to your sitting on him and pushing the mask onto his face. But maybe this will work just as well.

You stand behind his chair. He continues to ignore you, though he tenses his shoulders. You expect him to whip around at any moment and yell at you, but when he doesn't you just calmly reach around with both hands and press the mask against his face.

His hands fly up and he twists in his chair, but you just keep pressing the mask against him. It suddenly feels very warm against your palms, and even as he pulls at your fingers his strength ebbs away and his arms fall to his side. You keep holding the mask—

—and then you feel it melting away. You look down in astonishment: your hands are pressing against your brother's bare cheeks.

You rush over and close his bedroom door, and as you turn back he slumps out of his chair. Quickly, you pull him up and drag him onto his bed, where you peer down at him. He is breathing shallowly, with his eyes open. There is no sign of the mask.

Nervously, you watch and bite your lips. Where has the mask gone? What has it done to him? You knew it was a terrible risk trying this magical thing out on someone—that's why you didn't want to try it on yourself—but the realization that you might have irreparably harmed your own brother isn't long in sinking in. You sit on the edge of his bed, with a sick feeling in your stomach, as you watch, hoping that things will turn out alright.

Minutes pass, and nothing seems to happen. You've just about given up, and are trying to figure out what (if anything) you should tell your parents, when Robert's face begins to glow—and then the mask reappears.

You snatch it up and peer anxiously at Robert. His eyes are now closed, and he's breathing deeply; it appears to be nothing worse than a heavy sleep. You watch him carefully for a few moments, and then turn your attention to the mask.

There is the glint of an image in its polished surface, and as you look more carefully you see that it now holds the pale, ghostly image of Robert's face, reproduced like a 3-D image in the mask's surface. As you turn the mask this way and that, you note that it gives you glimpses not only of his face but of the sides and top of his head; you can even see part of his shoulders and chest when you turn it about to the right angle. It looks as though the mask has reproduced not just his face but his entire body.

You're about to creep out of his room when you get a sudden thought, and dip into his closet to snag a shirt and a pair of pants. Then you scurry out before he can wake up.

You've got the mask and his clothes hidden, and are perusing the next spell in the book—which the newly imprinted mask has unlocked—when your bedroom door flies open. Robert stands there, with a bewildered and angry look on his face.

"The hell was—" he starts, and then stops.

"Yes?" you say with studied innocence.

"Weren't you just— Didn't you—?" His brow furrows.

"Didn't I what?"

"I just woke up!" He says it like it's an accusation.

You look around carefully. "And ... isn't it about time to go to bed?"

He glowers at you, but apparently can't find anything to say. "Just stay out of my room!" he finally shouts, and stomps off.

* * * * *

When you turned the newly unlocked page in the book, you discovered some new information about the mask: it will continue to "absorb" new body images each time it is laid upon a face, melding new images with old and thus creating new faces, until it is "sealed." Upon reflection, you decided this means that if you now laid the mask upon your own face—and you've no real qualms about doing that, now that you've seen the mask in action—it will create a new form that looks like someone halfway between you and your brother. This would be a useful feature if you wanted to change your appearance without looking exactly like someone else.

But you were more eager to check that it can actually work as a disguise. This involves "sealing" the mask, which the next spell describes how to do. It was too late Saturday evening to work on it, and you had church the next morning, so Sunday afternoon after lunch was the earliest that you could get around to testing it out. You were nervous, because your parents were still home, and you remembered the mess and the smell when you'd made the mask, but you took a chance anyway. It was well worth it, though. The new spell, which only required some of the materials you already had on hand, was much less noisome and explosive, and resulted in a thin, paint-like liquid that was easy to brush on the inside of the mask.

You are now holding the newly sealed mask and are laying, naked, on your bed. It's a moment of truth: different from, but in its own way just as fraught, as the moment when you hit Robert with it. Even if you survive the experiment, it will be disappointing if it doesn't work as advertised.

Slowly, you lower the mask onto your face. For a brief moment you are very conscious that it fits snugly against you, and that there are no eyeholes or mouth hole for breathing: no wonder Robert seemed on the verge of passing out when you attacked him with it. Then, with a gasp, you feel the mask sinking into your face. All your limbs go rigid. Your heart hammers briefly, then is still. You are very numb all over, and a great weight seems to be oppressing your brain. You feel very drowsy.

* * * * *

And then you feel yourself spring upright. You are stiff all over, and you groan. What has happened? You arch your back to get the kinks out, and stretch an arm. You were trying on the mask and—

You look down. Your legs look funny: not as thick, and slightly darker, with thinner hair on the calves. Your toenails are longer, too, as are your fingers, when you glance at them. You touch your chest and feel only a light, downy patch beneath your fingertips.

You hop up and look in the mirror: Robert's face gazes back. Except it's not the same. In fact, it's totally wrong, all back to front or something. It's like looking at his face distorted in a funhouse mirror. Sure, the hair is the right color—a dark brown—but even combed it lays the wrong way on your scalp. The eyes are the right shade of green, but the eyebrows run off malignantly in strange directions. You grimace, and the lips leer. Even the birthmark beside the nose is on the wrong side—

And then it hits you. You're looking at Robert's face in a mirror, when you're used to looking at it straight on. This is what Robert sees when he looks at himself, and now that you've got his face ...

Now that you've got his face ...

Quickly you pull out the clothes you stole from his room last night and slip them on. That helps with the "mirror image" aspect, and when you look in the mirror again you are satisfied with the disguise: the lanky arms and the big hands; the mop of shaggy hair; the mischievous eyes—more mischievous now that you are the one looking out of them—with the one eyebrow that arches satirically upward; the thick lips. You turn around and around, admiring the effect. You are his exact twin. You'd be his evil twin if you weren't so used to thinking of Robert himself as the wicked little brother. Or maybe you could be his even more evil twin.

The thought has barely registered when you hear a shout from outside. Cautiously, you glance out the window, to see Umeko coming up the drive, shouting a greeting to your mother. Robert has gone off for the afternoon to hang out with his dorky friends. This would be the perfect chance to get back at him for stealing Umeko away for that movie. Of course, your parents know that Robert has left the house ...

You drum your fingers and think.

It would be a simple matter to steal into Robert's bedroom and take a pair of his extra sneakers, then climb out your window and hide in the neighborhood for a bit until Umeko started to leave. Then you could "appear" as Robert and say or do stupid things that would piss her off. It would be a lovely prank—assuming you didn't somehow get caught out as an imposter. Of course, if you did get caught out, it could lead to problems so serious it's hardly worth thinking about.
11112.title: My Brother, Myself

choices: Find a way to sell a mask anonymously to someone else
111122.content:
(by Gimlet )

Oh it's tempting, and getting back at Robert would be well worth... well, most of the possible problems. But... This is a priceless opportunity and you don't want to waste it. You can now BE other people. According to the book you could be completely new people too, merging two images into an unrecognizable face. Is it worth getting discovered just to play a prank on Robert? Hmmm.... You're thinking about it.

With a sigh you sit back on your bed and reconcile yourself that you have much more important things you could do to with such power. Earth shattering things like... see what it was like to be a girl. Or...

"Oh my god." you mutter "The Molester. I could... what? Imitate him? Or maybe frame him. Or... get the body of someone stronger than him and see how HE likes it!"

A grin spreads slowly over your face as you lean back on the bed, but it's short lived. The materials you've gathered will probably make one more mask with a little left over (plus the week and more of effort needed to buff it!) but after that you'll have expended your money supply. How on earth can you get enough to make more masks? You'll certainly want a few of them, just what you've thought of so far would need two or three more masks, and you've barely begun to scrape the surface of the possibilities. You're definitely going to need more cash to make use of this.

You reach up and press your hand to your face in the way the book described, say the nonsense phrase three times and tear the mask from your face. Fainting dead away you come to a few moments later. Oh you have got to get more used to this! Falling asleep every time you put on or take off a Mask is going to be annoying. As far as getting money for more Masks?

Options... You could, of course, take a part time job?... Naaaah! Not your style. But what about the masks themselves? Could you make a mask, put a merged image of two people in (so it couldn't be traced to a specific person) and sell it? Could be dangerous. What if someone knows about the masks, about the book, and is looking for signs of them? Heck maybe the government is after this thing if it knows about it. You're sure the CIA would kill for a tool like this!

Well, maybe you have been watching too much spy thrillers recently, but still it might be risky. But, what if you made a merged mask, used it, then sold another merged mask. They wouldn't be able to trace you as they wouldn't know your face, fingerprints etc. Nothing should lead back to you!

Of course there is a problem with that. It'll need two more masks, one to use and one to sell. You'll need probably another $200 to do that, maybe a bit less depending on how much materials you've got left after making one more mask. You can't use your current mask of Robert. It might serve your horrible brother right, but he IS your brother. Either using his face to sell a mask and thus leading them back to him, or selling his mask and not knowing what the guy who is buying it would effectively be framing Robert for are things you just aren't willing to do. Besides, either could lead people back to you.

You turn the glossy mask over in your hands, peering at the odd 3D image of Robert shining in the surface. It is intoxicating knowing you can BE someone else, feel just like him, his energy his...

Suddenly you sit bolt upright as a thought occurs to you. You had his energy, his body, you were perfectly him. You'd been feeling a little off lately what with spending so much time on polishing, but with that mask on you had your brothers boundless energy. What if it could do more? What if it could GIVE more?

Slowly you get off the bed and go back to the window, this time looking over to your neighbor's house. Andrew would pay through the nose for something like this! He could WALK again!
111122.title: Remove the disguise

choices: You can't tell him, fob him off with something.
Give in, maybe Caleb can help with making Masks
1111221.content:
(Text by Gimlet )

OK, thinking it through does pose some problems. Andrew would have to basically give up his life. A Mask of him wouldn't work, those legs would be paralyzed too (if you can even use a mask of yourself!). But a merged mask, though untraceable, would not be him. If he wore it all the time he'd have to get a new identity to go with it. But, that would be his problem. Knowing him he'd probably find a way, 'adopt' the merged mask persona, then fake his death and give everything to the new him? Hmm, maybe he can come up with something better, but it could work. You are pretty sure you can trust him, thus him knowing it's you that have this shouldn't be a problem, though you don't like the idea of him knowing about the book. Maybe tell him you found the 'recipe' for it online? Then of course the website is gone, no trace anywhere, no history etc. You could show him what happened even! When you try to write the instructions down, or type them into a computer they'd vanish! It'd prove it! That way he'd only know you could make masks and not wonder what else you could do.

Or you could say you bought the mask that you make and are just reselling it to him?

First though you need a new mask to sell, and that'll take time. Another week most likely. Another week of back breaking labor! Okay, not backbreaking but still not fun.

You hear the sounds of laughter downstairs and remember that Umeko just arrived. For the moment you hide the mask (NOT under the bed with your porn! You do not want your brother to find this.) and straighten your hair and clothes before striding nonchalantly downstairs. Yes, Umeko and your mother are talking in the living room, Umeko looking fantastic as ever in a powder blue dress, her hair pulled back in a ponytail.

"Hey Umeko." you say, trying to sound as cool as possible. "How've you been doing?"

"Very well, thanks Will" She says "I was just telling Mrs. Prescott about the movie."

With difficulty you managed to not let your face drop with the reminder that Robert got a 'date' with Umeko. He would pay for that, you'd find a way. Maybe there are a few things you could try with the mask that wouldn't be too risky?

"Will?" Umeko says, waving a hand in front of your face. Oops! You drifted there.

"Oh, I'm sorry Umeko, I just thought of something," you say, and before she can ask what you were thinking of, add "So are you ready for your starring role today?"

She raised an eyebrow, probably amazed you remembered about the flute accompaniment she's doing at church. "I know I am! Why don't you come and listen, Will. I'd like you to hear how well I've practiced."

Going to church is not exactly your idea of fun, but for this?

"Of course, I'd love to Umeko."

"Good, tell Robert, I'm sure he'd love to hear too."
You grin through gritted teeth and just nod. Damn, that's probably going to spoil it for you! Maybe you can avoid sitting right next to him? He's bound to be a pain through the whole thing!



The show is fantastic, and of course you are completely unbiased! Afterwards you can't really remember much apart from Umeko's playing (she was accompanying someone, right?) and how she looked, so focused and really having fun up there. That's another thing you've always admired about Umeko. She has no embarrassment on stage or in front of a crowd. You just tend to clam up. Watching her have fun on the flute, knowing that everyone is listening to her playing obviously is a big thing for her.

When the show is over Robert and you almost get in a fight leaving the church trying to get close to Umeko to escort her home, but a cough from a woman behind you stops you both from making a fool of yourselves. Instead you both look daggers at each other the whole way home and both miss out on chatting with Umeko. Infuriating, and of course it's all Roberts fault!



The next day is back to school and although there is a temptation to take Robert's Mask into school and play some sort of prank on him you do manage to resist. You don't want to be found with a Mask, let alone for someone to find out what they do! This week does seem less intensive on homework, at least from English, and Physics at least you're good at and can deal with it pretty handily (mostly). That leaves you with quite a few nights of full time burnishing your new mask that you fabricated Sunday night. You have to find a better place to do this, blowing the smoke out the window will only work so long, and your Dad complained about the smell again.

Effort on the Mask goes well, and it is mostly done by Wednesday night. On Thursday, though you can't wait to get home to finish the Mask off, things side track you. Well, one particular 'Thing'.

"Hello Prescott, I was just thinking my fist needed a bit of practice and what do I find? A perfect punching bag? I guess I'm just lucky."

Lester The Molester! Oh shit!

You know by now that it doesn't really help to try to talk back to him, it just speeds up the pummeling you'll get... or not. Sometimes he just gets off on the fear in your eyes, the not knowing if Lester will flatten you or not. Unfortunately this isn't one of those times and you stagger to your next class trying to catch your breath after having the wind knocked out of you. At least he didn't give you a black eye. Explaining that to Dad might be a problem.

You spend the rest of the day thinking up ways to deal with Lester once you have the money to make as many Masks as you want. A particular favorite is Using a Lester Mask and a merged mask to frame Lester for murder of guy who doesn't even exist! Tricky to pull off but no way to counter it! Even if it never goes to trial the arrest will be on his record forever!
As you leave Math class at the end of the day you bump into Caleb. "Hey Prescott. What's up?"

You've seen Caleb a couple of times through the week so far, mostly at your locker, but had been a little preoccupied to say much. From his face he might be worried about you. What have you done wrong?

"Oh, nothing much. Got molested, got picked for a verbal presentation in English for next week. That's gonna suck!"

"Hear you man, so... any word from your Dad?"

You clench your eyes tight at the familiar question.

"Look Caleb, he doesn't trust you, OK? I'll keep trying, and maybe he will put your name forwards, but don't count on it."

"Doesn't trust me? Why?" he says looking genuinely confused.

"Perhaps that whole 'shoplifting' thing last year..."

"HEY! You know I was framed for that! I just wish I knew who slipped those magazines in my coat!"

"Yeah, right." you say, chuckling. Magazines was a little too high brow a name for what Caleb had been caught with.

For a moment Caleb looks like he is going to retort back, but then he stops and stares.

"OK, what did you do with Will?"

"Huh?" you manage intelligently.

"You haven't asked once if I talked to Eva about Lisa!"

That hits you. In all your focusing on the Masks you'd completely forgotten about Lisa. Well, not forgotten, just thinking about different things.

"I've been busy." you say lamely.

"With what? What could possibly tear the great Will Prescott away from the plan to re-unite with Lisa?"
1111221.title: Sell the mask to Andrew

choices: Andrew wants to get different faces in the Mask.
11112211.content:
(Text by Gimlet )

"I've just had homework." you manage weakly and Caleb leans in closer.

"Right, pull the other one."

"OK, alright, I've been thinking about Umeko, OK?"

"Your cousin? Oh come on, surely you're over her by now?"

"Oh right, like you haven't drooled over her when you bumped into her?"

"We aren't related."

The rest of the conversation is predictabl, getting nowhere whatsoever, but doing it loudly. After parting outside school you head home thankful that you can get back to finishing the second Mask.

Once you get home the conversation from today comes back to you. What about Lisa? Is there any way a Mask could help get her back? You could make a merged Mask and use that to try and date her as someone else? But that strikes you as a lose-lose situation. If she rejects the new you she still won't be with Will Prescott, and if she doesn't reject him it'll just prove it was the real you that was the problem the whole time!

No, you can't face that, and the only other way you can think you daren't do. Making a Mask of Lisa. Not only wouldn't it feel right you'd probably never get the courage up to wear the damn Mask after you fixed it!

You put the whole idea on the back burner for now until you can find a way that a Mask could help with Lisa. Instead you finish burnishing the Mask while watching evening TV. After an hour and a half it's finally an even glossy blue, deep like crystal just like the first Mask.

Now comes the decision you've been putting off all week. Who to put in the mask for Andrew? You aren't even sure what blending two people in a Mask would actually do. Is it a straight blend between them? Looking as if you were their kid? Hmm, there is the other issue of how to get the images to put in the Mask. Oh, well you and Andrew could just put both your faces on the Mask? That would keep it private at least.

Yeah, that should work, and use the Robert Mask to prove the masks work. Oh this should be interesting. Besides you always liked Andrew. He works at home on his programs (you are still not sure if he is freelance or works at home for a corporation) so he should be in now.

You get some clothes that will fit both you and Robert then head to Andrew's before you can talk yourself out of it.

"Yeah? Who is it?" comes the familiar response to your knock.

"Avon calling. They want their money back!"

With a chuckle he opens the door, pulling his wheelchair out of the way to let you in.

"So, what do I owe the pleasure your company Will?" He says, leading you into the living room.

"This is gonna sound weird Andy, but I ain't shitting you." You get out the Mask. "This thing can make you walk again."

Silence falls and Andrew turns to you with a fierce expression.

"Don't joke about that man! This shit is serious. I ain't some kind of freak for your..."

"OK, I'll prove it!" you interrupt and (remembering to sit down on the couch this time) you put on the Robert Mask.

The familiar sensations wash over you as the Mask sticks, you focus as much as you can as you weave, and for a moment you think you can stay conscious ...



You wake up to see Andrew's shocked face peering down at you.

"JEEEZUS! What the hell was that!" he gasps, touching the side of your face.

"This is worth a grand, Andy. A heck of a lot cheaper than any of the medical asshole's treatments they pushed on you. This one is my brother, I don't want you wandering around as him, but we can..."

"Who whoah a minute!" He says, getting up close to your face. "Backtrack. This one what? What the hell have you got here?"

You grin up at him with Robert's face.

"What I have is something I stumbled across online, Andy. A recipe for making Masks that can record what someone looks like, then project that onto whoever wears the Mask! Is that cool or what?"

"You found this online?" he asks suspiciously.

"It's kind of weird, but it's there, and it's not. Look I'll show you. You got a pen?"

Andrew rummages around and finds one and hands it to you with a notepad.

"OK, the recipe is like this..." and you start writing, or attempting to.

"Wait," Andrew says as he sees nothing being written, "I'll find a working pen."

You grin up at him

"It is working. Look." and you write your name.

"Huh?" Andrew takes the pen and checks it out, finding it works just fine "This is some sort of joke right?"

"No. Got me at first though. The original thing is in Latin. Bitch to translate, especially when you can't type or write any of it down. Even on a computer it just vanishes."

"Wait, if it can't be written down how did they write it for the website?"

You shrug your shoulders.

"Got me, and now I can't even find the website, my browser doesn't even have a history on it, web-address, nothing. It's as if it never existed. The only way to 'store' the instructions is in here." You tap your head. "Maybe it's some sort of safety feature of... whatever this thing is?"

Andrew slumps back in his chair, exhausted despite barely doing anything physical since you arrived.

"And I have to look like your brother?"

You chuckle.

"As I tried to tell you earlier this Mask is off limits. I don't like my brother, but having two of him around would be too much to bear. Seriously, you don't want to look like someone who already exists. However, this" and you hold up the Mask you finished today "is a blank one. Put it on a face and it records the image of that person. Put it on another face after that and it merges the two into a new, composite, body. Presto! We 'fix' the Mask and you have a new body with legs that work. I'm afraid you'd have to try to figure out some way to change your life over to the new you, but I'll help with that if I can, even if I have to wear the Mask I'm selling you or something."

Andrew peers down at you.

"And this is something from a friend that I have to pay a Grand for? Some friend!"

You get up, still a little off balance, not used to Robert's body.

"Hey! You don't know the materials and effort to make one of these. It's not easy, I need the money to make more masks!"

Andrew squints, a faint smile forming.

"You ain't telling me everything, Will."

You ponder, you could just bluff it out, but this is Andrew. He's a pretty smart cookie and if you start using stuff from later in the book and he notices...

"OK, there was more than instructions on making a Mask on that site. Some of it I... I don't know what it was. I just know it takes a lot of cash in materials and a lot of my time. It's emptied my bank account on just two Masks, and this one of Robert I'll probably never get to use! He's a dweeb but he IS my Brother. I'm not gonna get him arrested or anything. This Mask I'm offering is going to make you able to walk which no-one else has been able to give you. Frankly I think that it's pretty good of me to offer it to my friend rather than sell this on the black market!"

Andrew just laughs.

"Yeah, I'm sure you have tons of contacts in the criminal underworld, Will." He drums his fingers on the arm of his wheelchair for a few moments and ponders. "OK, I might consider your deal but I get to test out this Mask now. I can't be sure I really will be able to walk with this thing."

"OK, hang on a sec. To take one of these things off put your fingers like this," you press fingers and thumb to temple and nose, grip your face and pull, "Ungh, pull while saying this." and you recite the phrase you learned three times.

The ripping sensation is very weird, though not actually painful. This time you actually manage to stay conscious, though it's close, and waver, shaking your head as Andrew stares at you.
"Are you OK?" he asks

"It's a bit weird, but after a few times you get used to it. You'll probably pass out the first time. Here, give it a go." and you hand over the Mask to Andrew.

Tentatively he presses it to his face and convulses, collapsing in the chair before the Mask melts into him. Seeing the changes in someone else is incredible, like a scifi show! You can see muscles shifting, bones moving around into new configurations. You wait nervously and a after a minute 'Robert' wakes up.

"What the... My voice!" he gasps, and looks up at you. He's shrunk and his clothes are now rather loose on him. Going the other way could be tricky. Have to strip to sure you wouldn't do yourself an injury with your own clothes!

"Is this enough proof Andrew?" you say, stepping over and taking 'Robert's' hand.

Slowly you pull, easing him up off the wheelchair till he is standing, amazed, under his own power.
"Oh my god! It's true! Sheeit!" he starts to dance, and nearly falls over.

"Hey, wait a bit, gotta get used to your new legs there MJ."

"OK, you have definitely got a deal, Will. God, you're right, this is way worth a thousand bucks!"

"Ya think I should raise the price then?" He freezes and grimaces at you "Joking! God can't take a joke man! So should we do the Mask thing now? I was figuring mix me and you together should make someone no-body would recognize, plus the body should be half way between our ages. Gives you a little fountain of youth thing, hmm?"
11112211.title: You can't tell him, fob him off with someth...

choices: Fix the Mask and try it out.
Maybe you should add a face to the Mask before fixing?
111122111.content:
(Text by Gimlet )

"Yeah, that'd... that... Will, you have absolutely no idea, do you? This thing is not worth a thousand bucks!"

You sigh.

"I know, millions right? But if I go to some research lab they're gonna lock me in a cell so I can't tell anyone about it and the CIA will suddenly have a new toy. Come on, I'm not that dumb! Besides I want to help out my friends."

Andrew smiles and nods, then goes to remove the Mask as you showed him.

"WAIT!" you cry, "Sit down for gods sake first. Your legs won't work after, plus taking it off'll knock you out again anyways. Best to sit or lay down while you take it on or off."

"Gotcha." he says, sits back down, utters the phrase three times, and rips the Mask off. "oooooAaaaahhhhhhssshit!" he groans, and you blink. He stayed awake! The first time he used the Mask and he's getting used to it quicker than you! Damn! Shaking off the jealousy you wave the blank mask in front of him.

"This takes the image by melting into your face... it's OK! It just kind of merges, you saw it with me right? Anyway, it melts in and... I guess takes an image of your body. Takes a while. Ten, fifteen minutes tops. Then the Mask emerges again and a few moments later the guy being 'scanned' wakes up. Bingo recorded body. The Mask won't work then so you can keep recording images. When you 'fix' it you can't record images any more. Then anyone who wears the Mask becomes that image. Take a look in the surface of my brother's Mask."

Andrew shakes some of the fog from his brain and peers into the Mask.

"Damn! Looks like a hologram or something, but that's him alright."

"Yep, that way we can get an idea of what the finished body will look like before we fix it. If the combination of you and me isn't to your liking we can keep adding people to the Mask, slightly changing it's features till it's right. Once fixed though you can't change it at all. Make sure it's what you want before we finish. You'll have to live with it."

Andrew looks askance at you. "You? Giving me Life Lessons? Now this is a role reversal!" You both laugh at that, but soon Andrew is staring down at the blank Mask.

"Ready?" you say. "Well me first I guess."

You lay back and press the blank Mask to your face. You make a real effort to stay awake, despite the discomfort, but knowing what's happening doesn't help. A short time later you wake groggily to see Andrew turning the Mask over in his hands.

"Yep, your image alright. I was waiting for you to wake up before I did me."

Without waiting for you to respond he presses the Mask to his face as well. Just like with your brother you watch as it melts in and you are relieved to find that Andrew faints dead away this time. Maybe 'scanning' always knocks you unconscious? Just using the Mask is different you guess, and you can resist the fainting if you try hard enough. When the Mask emerges you study the face within. It's definitely not you or Andrew but it is a tiny bit like both of you. You're not sure it's half way between you, but it's definitely someone new.

"Oooh, that's gonna be a bitch!" Andrew mutters waking up slowly.

"If it's any consolation, I think it's designed to knock out whoever it scans. Using a finished Mask is a different story," you say it like it's obvious, despite you only having worked it out yourself a moment ago. "If you use the finished Mask regularly I'm sure you can eventually do it without a twinge."

"Let me see." he says, motioning to the Mask.

You toss it to him and he peers into it.

"I definitely like it!" he says. "Looks a bit like Uncle Louis, without the beard... and a lot younger."
111122111.title: Go with a Will/Andrew Mask.

choices: Andy gives you remaining cash he owes.
You bump into Eva yourself at school on Friday. Ask about Lisa maybe?
1111221111.content:
(Text by Gimlet )

"Look I don't have a grand on me, can I get cash out tomorrow for you?"

"Um, I do need materials for another mask and it takes so long to make them I'd rather get started tonight."

Andrew tossed the merged Mask up and down in his hands idly.

"Well, how about if I give you $300 tonight, as long as you 'fix' this mask now. I want to use it!"

"Ya know, by some strange coincidence I brought the materials to fix it with me."

Andrew raised an eyebrow. "OK, you planning ahead? What did you do with Will?"

"HA ha, very funny. So you don't want me to fix it?"

Andrew holds his hands up.

"I give! Uncle!"

Chuckling, you get the mixture you already made and the brush for it out and hold your hand out for the Mask. Andrew hands it to you and you carefully paint the inside of the Mask, making sure not to miss anything. When you're done you hand it back to Andy.

"That's it?"

"Yep. Trust me, making the mixture takes a while, but nothing compared to making the Masks. Those take about a week to do for me with School etc."

Idly he reaches in his wallet and virtually empties it, handing three hundred bucks over to you. You grin as he peers at the Mask intently. Eventually he licks his lips and presses it to his face. The familiar shuddering passes over him and the Mask melts into him while his body shifts and changes. Damn! You meant to tell him about your thought about clothes! You watch and see his legs tear his pants at the thighs, but the rest seems OK, slack if anything.

"Ow!" he manages, still conscious! Damn he's getting good at this! "Next time I'm wearing something more comfortable."

Carefully, and with a silly grin on his face, Andrew stands up. He's a little wobbly but OK.
The new Andy looks slightly shorter, maybe Nineteen or Twenty by looks, short cropped dark hair, brown eyes and fairly ordinary looking features. He probably looks a little better than you to be honest... which you rarely are.

"Odd, this feels stiffer than the other Mask." He says wriggling his legs a little.

"Heck, Robert is hyperactive, what can you expect! I felt weird in his body too."

You both glance at each other after you realize what you just said.

"Fag!" Andy says laughing at you, but is too focused on his working legs to make much fun of you. "Hmm, I think it might be more than that actually, maybe merging me and you was a bad idea? I think it got part of my paralysis into the image, just not fully."

You slap you hand against your head. Why didn't you think of that?

"Damn I'm sorry, but the legs work?"

He flexes his toes and smiles.

"Yep, good enough for government work. Hmm, maybe if I get the cash together we can make a mask up without me as a donor?"

He's offering to buy another Mask? Oh perfect! Got to make sure he stays interested then.

"OK, boy or girl?" you say nonchalantly.

Andrew's eyes go wide.

"What did you say?" he says, and you can't help but let a grin split your face.

"Do you want a Mask of a boy or a girl? What, you telling me you never thought about that this whole time I was explaining it? Anyone this scans is stored, then you wear the Mask and you ARE that person. Doesn't have to be the same sex!"

"Oooh shit! That's kind of freaky." He looks as if he's not as into the idea as you are. Hmm, maybe not a good way to keep him interested.

"Look, you can decide that later, for now this should do fine. I ought to head out and start buying supplies. Some of the stores I need close at ten on Sunday."

As you stand Andrew grabs you and hugs tight.

"I am NOT going to forget this Will. Thanks for thinking of me first."

You smile and hug back. "No problem Andy."

Waving, you leave him with his new Mask, taking the Robert Mask with you. It's getting late so you dash out to try and get the supplies you need. It's a pinch but you manage to get enough to make two more masks and head home. Crashing down on your bed you look at the table where you made the last two Masks. Not good enough. You need somewhere private to do this.

Then the obvious strikes you. The clubhouse! OK, you haven't been there in months but the locks should still be good. You stumbled across the Clubhouse a few years ago now, a basement in an abandoned Elementary school, but even though some of the upper building has been renovated and turned into a community center no-one thought to do anything with the basement. You put a lock on to be sure no-one could spoil your fun... or at least you'd know when they bolt cut the padlock, and have used it to hang out at with a few friends for years. It'd make the perfect place to make foul stenches and burn stuff and no-one would find out!

Unwilling to wait till tomorrow night you keep an eye out for your parents and brother and once they've all gone to bed you head out to the Clubhouse with bags full of supplies. You've got the instructions down pretty good now and manage to do the operation without referring to the book and the horrible job of translating. When you return to your house at 1AM you have two new gray Masks.

You get an idea and use a couple of old belts to strap the Masks, one to each knee. Then you use the proscribed cloth and buff them, one with each hand. You'll have to shift the belts to burnish those parts of it, but this'll cut your time in half... though after a few minutes of this you find it's more tiring than before as well. For tonight you give in, put the masks away and head to bed, but soon you'll have another two blank Masks to play with. Well, next week you will anyway. Maybe you can get some polishing done over the weekend?
1111221111.title: Fix the Mask and try it out.

choices: Try to keep to your lie with Andy.
Maybe you should tell him about the book?
11112211111.content:
(Text by Gimlet )

The next day you even wonder if you can get away with being sick and stay home to polish masks, but decide against it. Your mom is rather over protective and would be coming in and out with chicken soup and pills all day. The possibility that she'll interrupt you while you're polishing would be high, and you want to keep the whole thing as secret as possible.

At school you manage to avoid the Molester, a small miracle in itself, and remember to ask Caleb about Lisa. Again he hasn't talked to Eva but you seem less angry at him now. Are you letting her go or just getting way to involved with the Masks to think about much else? Or are you burying your emotions on the subject? You don't think so, but how would you know? You're not used to thinking about your emotions like this.

That evening as you reach your house you see Andrew's door open and he waves you in. Smiling you head over. He's still in his old body, in the wheelchair.

"So given up on the new body already? Come on, you can't have worn it out that quick?"

"Har har!" he says, and pulls the mask from under the wheelchair as he pushes the front door shut. "Right now I'm keeping Freddy to myself. I still haven't got all the details of how to 'inherit' Andrew Gary's fortune down pat and don't want to do something to mess things up."

"Fortune?" you snort. "Since when are you loaded! You make a hell of a lot more than me, but still, you ain't loaded."

You and Andrew head into the living room as he peers into his Mask.

"Maybe not now, but if I can figure out a way to get the life insurance money... Who boy!"

You raise an eyebrow at him.

"Dang, you think big. How can you pull that off without a body?"

"Like I said, a few details aren't there yet." You shake your head laughing "Hey I'll get it, don't you worry! Hey want a beer?" You nod and he wheels into the kitchen, but comes back running in his new body. "Catch!"

"You're doing that change damn fast!" you comment, a little acidly but take a sip from your beer and try to relax. "I'm just glad that it's working for you."

"Oh it's better than just 'working'. It's incredible. Still feels a little stiff but I've managed to work out enough to run and jump a bit. Feels a bit like arthritis or something, but minimal. I'll definitely need another mask later."

As you take another sip of beer something lands in your lap with a slap.

"Seven hundred, as promised, in twenties. I figured if your buying chemicals and stuff from stores you don't want it to be in too large a bills."

You pick up the thick wedge of cash and grin wolfishly.

"Thanks Andrew, this will really help. Damn!" you say, as you realize you didn't check the materials for the new item. Will what you bought work for that? You glanced at the instructions for the new metal strips earlier in the week, but with all the polishing you didn't want to distract from what you were doing. Well, that and the damn text didn't describe what the thing was supposed to do! You'd rather make Masks that you're sure of than leaping into the unknown, well for the moment.

"What is it?" Andrew asks.

"I was just realizing I'd forgotten about something I wanted to try," you say lamely, trying to sound casually interested only.

"Ooooh, what? The next item after the Mask? What is it?" he asks eagerly. Damn, you should have kept your mouth shut!
11112211111.title: Andy gives you remaining cash he owes.

choices: You have to try it out. No matter how weird it is.
Not now. Too freaky! Finish this mask and start on another two.
111122111111.content:
(Text by Gimlet )

"I don't know really!" you say, trying not to give any details. Frankly it's not far from the truth. Who knows what the strip does? "Look, you're really getting into your new body, I need to sort some things out, so do you mind if I head out?"

Andrew looks a little disappointed but waves goodbye good naturedly from the living-room, unwilling to change back to let you out. You lock the door and close it and head home. Well at least Andrew is getting some immediate use out of these things! You have a useless mask (well, nearly useless), two blank ones that still need a lot of polishing... and a wad of cash? OK, so not a total loss!

Grinning you bound upstairs, giving only a cursory "I'm home!" to your mom before dashing upstairs.

That evening you get next to no polishing done. If it isn't Robert annoying you it's your mom wanting to get you to be involved with the church more, or your dad demanding you do your chores. Luckily no-one sees what you're doing, but it's still frustrating. In the end you go to bed early and set your alarm for 1AM. Dashing out in the dead of night you unlock the Clubhouse and start polishing in private.

You almost stay too long, but manage to get home before everyone gets up in the morning. Tired and irritated you spend Saturday morning doing more chores (did this household really make this much trash in a day?) but by mid-day you manage to head out and again go to the Clubhouse to polish. Watching TV while polishing the two Masks on your knees is very tiring. You can't alternate between arms and they ache like mad. Plus, nice as it is in here it is a little claustrophobic. Though it's tiring you get both masks mostly done by the afternoon, but are way too tired to continue. You rest a little before heading home, making sure to lock up.

On Sunday (after church) you head back and pick up where you left off, but it's way too stuffy for you in here right now. The masks look mostly done. Only two days of work, but very intensive two days. Maybe you can take them in public? It'd be nice to get some fresh air, but would it be safe? Well, who knows about them anyway? It's not as if they'll work until their polished fully.

With a smile you head to the park, leaving the belts behind and deciding to focus on one at a time for the last little bit. It's a sunny day at least, a little too hot for the clothes your wearing actually, but you don't want to go back and change now. Sitting at a bench you set one Mask on the table and start burnishing the other Before mid-day you have one finished and swap over, watching wispy clouds drift across the sky as you polish.

"ARROOOOooo-up!" comes the plaintiff bark, cut short and you turn in time to see the mask you just finished melt into the forehead of a large Doberman!

"Nooo!" you leap over to the dog as it lays unconscious on the ground. "That's not possible, is it?"

It must have leaped up at the shiny mask and knocked it off the table and onto its face.
Glancing around you don't see anyone searching for their dog so wait in silence for the time to be up. What if it's longer for a dog? What if the thing can't scan a dog and stays like this forever! What if...

Slowly you see the Mask return, is that slower than before? You think so. There was absolutely NO mention of animals in the book. If this isn't what the mask was designed for, who knows what the results will be?

After a minute of slowly emerging it is free and you grab the mask and run, not wanting to be around the dog when it wakes.

Your heart is pounding when you get home, collapsing on your bed. You put the nearly polished mask away and stare at the dog mask. Yep, in the crystal finish you can see the image of that Doberman. It's recorded the body of a dog! Wait, could that actually work? Could you BECOME a dog? Oh this is getting weirder and weirder.
111122111111.title: Try to keep to your lie with Andy.

choices: You head to the Reptile house and end up looking at an Anaconda.
You head to the Aquarium and peer in at a big Octopus.
1111221111111.content:
(Text by Gimlet )

OK, it's dangerous, but you have to try it out. It's just too tempting!

You strip this time, not wanting to risk damage to your clothes or you in the process. Laying on on your side on the bed you bring the mask up to your face and slowly take a deep breath and press it home before you can second guess yourself.

*PAIN!*

You writhe around on the bed in panic, searing bolts of white hot lead pouring through your face and into your body. Luckily the mask covers your mouth so muffles your screams of terror, otherwise your mom or dad might have burst in while you were changing! You aren't thinking about that though, the mind numbing agony is high on your list of things to be concentrating on, but it doesn't last. Your body seems to take much longer, as much as a minute or more before the mask fully melts into you and your body succumbs to unconsciousness but eventually you do. While you sleep your body distorts and shifts till a Doberman is laying on your bed.

Consciousness returns in a painful haze, but thankfully it's receding. Will you have to go through that again when you take the mask off? Suddenly panic fills you. TAKE THE MASK OFF! How can you say the words that remove the mask? You're a DOG!

With a thump you roll off the bed and land on the floor. Oh this is weird. You feel like you're in a monster suit, twisted like a pretzel. Rear legs are... tricky. Like standing on your toes the whole time, but also the front legs; balanced on your fingers... er paws. Twice you fall over to your side but eventually to stay upright, if a bit wobbly.

Now that you can stand pretty well... you collapse to the floor! Struggling you fumble your paws up to your face and press, trying to grip your face.

"Rrrroo Ruff!" you bark, trying to say the words, desperately. You repeat it twice more and...

*Pain!*

This time it's not so bad. Perhaps, like Andrew, you're getting used to this. It's just worse when it's not a human body! You still writhe around on the floor in pain, but surprisingly don't faint.
"Will?" comes your mother's voice as you shakily pull the mask from your, now human, face. "Are you OK?"

"Y.. Yes mom," you manage, and struggle under the covers to hide your nakedness, but she doesn't come in. Relaxing you try to let the memory of that swell of agony subside. Would you do that again? It was easier taking it off, hopefully next time to put it on it wouldn't hurt so much.

A while later you wake, realizing you fell asleep without noticing! The clock says 4PM, you've slept three hours. Still a little of the day left. You hide the dog mask next to Robert's and take the nearly polished mask out. You head out with the intention of going to the Clubhouse, but instead head into town. You aren't sure where you're going at first, then realize what it is. The Zoo is nearby.

Smiling you idly polish the mask while you head in. Do you really want to waste another mask on an animal? There are all sorts of things you could be doing. At very least get a girl body to fondle at night. Still you find yourself wandering around the Zoo trying to see if any animal sparks your imagination.
1111221111111.title: You have to try it out. No matter how weird it is.

choices: Fix the Snake Mask and try it out now!
Maybe you should merge it with a human? A hybrid animal Mask?
11112211111111.content:
(Text by Gimlet )

Dark slitted eyes stare back at you, forked tongue slipping out. The head of this huge snake is not as big as you'd have thought given it's bulky body. Would the mask work if it can't fit on the creature's face? Hmm, well this one is the biggest snake here and it's face is maybe the size of a toddler's.

You were only passing by the Reptile house but suddenly had a thought. Snakes are incredibly strong. Thinking back to Lester you wondered if you could deal with him. Walking in you thought better of it, after all after you do attack him, having him talk about being squeezed by a snake might get people into checking for weird things at the school, if anyone believed him that is. You don't want that much attention. As you looked around at all the various snakes in here you imagined squeezing the hell out of him, then realized it would do you little good. After all he wouldn't know it was you doing it, and if he DID know... you'd be in even worse trouble.

If he lived.

The thought brings you to an abrupt halt. Could you really kill Lester? OK he has given so much pain to you and seems to revel in it, you know he is going to go on to being evil outside of school... but kill him?

You look in at a large puff adder, this species venom could kill. Could you really do that? But how would you dispose of the body?

That's when you saw the Anaconda.

Maybe you could get a mask on it. If it works it would be child's play to... deal with Lester, and then... eat him? Would that work? It would sure do away with the evidence.

The more you peer in at the snake the more you like the idea. You've never liked snakes much, but not really disliked them either, and now with your new perspective you can imagine being inside a snake's body and the thought of sinuously moving around like that is definitely interesting. It's face is dark, greens and yellow-green mottled patterns, and honestly you kind of like it. It looks... serene somehow. Unfortunately it's in a large tank with a sealed hatch. You can see a lock from here. Caleb is better at this than you, but... You get out your tool kit, originally for electrical repairs but you've added some finer tools and picks, and peer around. The room is dark and you are fairly sure no-one is looking. Wait, what about cameras? Again you peer around and can't see any. The Zoo is seriously under funded but would they really have no cameras?

One final check and you step up onto the ledge, reaching up to the high hatch. Why is it so high up? Hmm, maybe so the snake doesn't get out as easily when it's opened? The lock is simple and snicks open seconds later. Easier than the tumblers to the girl's locker rooms! You get out the mask that you finished polishing as you were wandering around the Zoo and hold it over the snake's head. If you drop it and miss, or the snake dodges away you won't get it back! Quickly you pull out a power cord you were going to use at the Clubhouse and loop it loosely over. Easily you lower it down, planning on swinging it over the...

*Snap!* the snake's head shoots up, snaps at the lip of the Mask and pulls it free of the cord!

"Shit!" you whisper, as the snake nibbles it, then drops it. Wasted! How are you going to get it now! You're not climbing in there with...

You stare unbelieving as the snake's head pokes around the mask, then wriggles under it. It must have covered something it wanted. With a jerk the Mask sticks, it works! The snake starts thrashing around, then slows, finally stopping at the mask melts in.

You let the door pull-to, but not lock, and step down from the ledge. You've got ten minutes or so, maybe longer. You think the dog took a bit more than normal.

It's incredible, and you really can't believe that it worked, well you haven't got the mask to try out yet, but so far it's working.

A couple wander through, peering in at the snakes and you nervously look at your watch, then at the Anaconda. The time's up and the Mask hasn't reappeared! They leave and you dash to the tank. Nope, still no Mask. Fretfully you cast about, hoping something hasn't gone wrong. Another ten minutes go by and you are about to bail out of here when a slight blue glow comes from the snake's head. Quickly you get on the ledge and open the hatch and lean in. You reach down and grab the Mask just as it's finished emerging, the snake still asleep. Pulling back you hear the hatch click as the lock engages and you look at your prize. Yep, the image of a snake head is there, body trailing below out of sight. God damn it worked!

So far, you keep reminding yourself. Can't get your hopes up yet!

It's with great trepidation that you head out, almost heading for the clubhouse, but you are tired after all the tension back there and there aren't any beds in that basement. It'd be private but really uncomfortable. When you get home your Dad is out late at 'The Company' but your mom greets you pleasantly. She's still watching her soaps on the living room TV and doesn't really seem interested in chatting. Thankfully. You just want to sleep, but are intoxicated with the idea of the snake Mask.
11112211111111.title: You head to the Reptile house and end up lookin...

choices: Take the Mask off and hope you finish changing before Dad gets to the Kitchen.
Make a break for the kitchen window.
111122111111111.content:
(Text by Gimlet )

Collapsing on your bed you stare at the mask. This is so freaky! A snake. What's next, a Shark? An Eagle? Now there's a thought! Wait, are there any bird's heads that would fit the mask? Even closely? Hmmm probably not. Bummer, it'd cool to fly like a bird, or rather BE a bird.

Idly you pick up the fixing solution and nervously paint the inside.

It's done. Now to test it. You strip and hop on the bed, holding the Mask.

Um, yeah. Test it right now.

A few minutes later you're still staring at the thing, wondering if you'll ever have the courage to put it on. Have you wasted yet another Mask? Laying the Mask carefully on your bed you go back to the book and leaf through what you can open. No matter how well you search, how carefully you translate, there is no mention of animals at all. Just 'people', or 'corpus' which does mean person or body, or several other things but not human. It could have said 'hominis' or something close which WOULD mean human or body or person, but it uses 'corpus' Is that on purpose? Being generalized to make the magic work? Who knows how this stuff works.

With a sigh you close the book and turn back to the Mask. You can't put this off... OK, you can, but you aren't going to. This is just too fun an idea. OK, you don't want to, but you want to. It's gonna hurt, but it will be fun, and at least you know you can get back to human again. For the next few minutes your mind whirls, thinking contrary thoughts on the whole thing. Finally you shake your head and try to concentrate.

Again you pause, staring at the Mask's surface, the image stored within. Can you really...? Yes you can do this!

With a gritting of teeth you lay on the floor (the bed isn't nearly big enough for the Anaconda!) and bring the Mask to your face... and you pause. Last time it was so painful you thrashed around. If you were still thrashing as an Anaconda the piles of stuff around you room would go flying.

You know it's an excuse, but use it to delay things as you tidy up (first time in months!), pushing things under the bed, up on the top of cabinets etc. Eventually you have a nine foot space around you, probably enough.

Once more you lay on the ground and nervously bring the Mask up. This is it! With your heart racing and your hands shaking you bring it up to your face and press it on.

For seconds nothing happens and you begin to wonder if it worked after all.

"P***A***I***N!!!"

This is worse! MUCH worse! Agony sears your veins, your head threatening to explode, and thankfully you pass out quickly this time.

Eyes plop open blearily. Damn what were you dreaming again? Something funky but you can't quite place it. It was a snake you think but... You try to shift and feel hardness beneath you, but when you try with more effort to move, something feels... wrong. Your arms are numb, and your legs! Twisting in shock you look down and... YOU'RE A SNAKE!

It comes back to you, the dog, the Zoo and your final test, along with the blinding agony. Blinking you stare at yourself. It worked! Shit!

For minutes you just stare at yourself in amazement, not sure whether to be happy or not. It does feel cool, but not what you expected. Hmm, maybe try to move? Snakes have that whole rippling movement thing, their belly's shifting in ripples, dragging them along. Can you do that?

You try to slither, undulating your belly, but it's hard just to move. After a while you can slowly and carefully move your body, but that slithering thing seems beyond you. Instead you move in a kind of press, lift maneuver. Is that how sidewinders move? You don't think so. Maybe you don't have snake instincts? This is more the way an engineer might think of for a snake should move.

It feels crude, but you manage and shift and crawl your way about your room. Your vision is in black and white and your sense of smell seems mostly based on your tongue. Very weird! OK, maybe it's not your tongue but something in your mouth that the tongue brushes against. After checking your body is much longer than your room is wide, maybe twice as much. That makes you a little over seventeen foot long, maybe twenty tops. Big certainly, but big enough to eat Lester? Well shows you've seen on TV picture Anaconda's eating animals bigger than humans, but you'd have to test this. How?

Wait, Mom has a 20lb turkey in the kitchen on the counter. It's bigger than your snake head, not as big as person but it would be a start.

You nudge the door open with your muzzle and try to hear if your mom is still in the living room. It's tricky, you can't really hear very well. Do snakes have ears? It seems easier to hear, at least deeper notes, when your head is on the ground. Maybe it's the vibrations through the paneling?

When you're sure she's still watching TV you wriggle out, awkwardly without slithering, and try to get down the stairs. This is a challenge! You could change back, walk down, then change again, but the pain when you change would be hard to hide in the kitchen, even though there is more space there. No, just head down and deal with this now.

Several times you feel coils slipping and almost tumble down the stairs. This is hard! Why couldn't the Mask record the snake's instincts? You should be able to do this effortlessly! You've seen snakes navigate far more awkward conditions than this.

Peering up the hall at the bottom of the stairs you see the light of the TV going, she's still there, and you turn to the Kitchen. Up on the counter is the turkey. Your head is smaller so it looks totally huge from your perspective. It's out of the wrapping thankfully, sitting in a pan. You position coils beneath it around a table leg to catch the pan and use your tail to nudge it off the table, positioning your head, wide open, beneath it.

There is a little clunk as the pan hits the table leg but it seems quiet. The Turkey slams into your jaws and you desperately try to swallow. Halfway in you feel a deep cold seep into you and realize it wasn't long ago she took it out of the freezer! It's still partially frozen! Damn it! You're too far gone now though and swallow heavily, feeling lots of little teeth fold out to grip it. Some times they don't fold out and it's awkward. You haven't quite got the hang of this yet. The turkey doesn't seem a stretch for your new body, and soon is working it's way easily down your throat. That feels kind of cool, though Lester? You imagine someone struggling while you do this and wince. You'd have to deal with him first. Are you really a killer though?

As the melting meat oozes nicely down into your bulkier body you ponder that... but are interrupted by a slam. DAD'S HOME! OH SHIT!

You glance around in panic and try to figure a way out of this. The front door is too close to the stairs, he'd notice if your dashed that way. You could try the Kitchen window, but that might make a lot of noise. You don't want him coming in and seeing a giant snake wriggling out the window!

Or you could take the Mask off! You don't have much to lose now!
111122111111111.title: Fix the Snake Mask and try it out now!

choices: You bump into him on the landing.
There are odd noises coming from Roberts bedroom!
1111221111111111.content:
(Text by Gimlet )

You hear a deep rumble. Is that your dad calling to your mom? It's now or never, he'll probably be in here soon!

You wrap your tail around your face and pull, hissing the words, but nothing happens. You try again, levering against your lower jaws and nose. It doesn't work! Twisting and wriggling you try for something closer to the 'brow and nose' grip that the book proscribes and heave, yet again hissing the words. Finally you feel it give and you tense waiting for the pain explosion.

You aren't disappointed.

Again you faint dead away, and when you wake up Dad is leaning in over you.

"Son Son! Will are you OK?"

Groaning you sit up. Yes, you're human, but where is the Mask?

"I... I think so Dad. What happened?"

"You tell me, I found you naked in the Kitchen. I don't think your mother would appreciate it so I hauled you into my office. What were you doing in there naked?"

You use the echoes of the pain to try and fake expressions of anguish to cover your nervousness. You don't want him to know about the Masks.

"I don't know. I went to bed and... Oooh, I don't feel so good." This is true. You have a heavy cold lump in your stomach. The turkey! Glancing down you expect a huge bulge in your belly, but it's flat. What the heck?

"You've never sleep walked before son. Is this on the up and up?"

"You think I'd *gnnn* make this up? Oooh god!"

Dad carries your groaning body upstairs quietly, and as he goes through the downstairs hall you glance towards the kitchen. There is the Mask! Under kitchen table! Oh god, you can't tell your dad about it, but to leave it there... You'll have to risk it.

He lays you in bed and tucks you in.

"Lets not mention the sleep walking to your mom hmm? I'll tell her you don't feel good. I think we've got some Nyquil somewhere."

Laying in bed you ponder if this could have gone much worse! You've got a lump of ice in your stomach, your dad thinks you are sleep walking, you've lost the snake Mask downstairs and are coming down with a cold or something from the turkey (you guess) and don't have the energy to go grab it. What if someone puts it on! Oh god!
There is nothing you can do about it though, and you just shiver and cough through the next few days, fading in and out of consciousness, your mom being as overprotective as ever. You get pretty sick of chicken soup until by Thursday morning you start to feel a little better. The lump of the turkey is still there but it's long since melted. Will you need to eat again soon? Who knows? That's one hell of a meal!
