1111344141111221312222112.content:
The next day—Friday—is electric with anxiety. Not for academic reasons. There are no quizzes or tests or projects to worry you. But the air seems charged, and your brain prickles with static. Every hour or so a spasm runs through you, as though a small, hot spark has discharged at the base of your skull.

Your friends notice. "What are you being a spazz for?" Tilley asks you in second period. "Oh, right." He lifts his nose to smirk down at you. "You gotta date."

"I don't have a date!" you protest. "I'm just seeing a movie is all."

"With someone. I hear she's got a name."

"Katy Conlee," you mutter.

"Yeah." Keith bobs his head. "She's cute." He puts his fist out for a bump. You brush his knuckles with yours, then look away. "You'll do fine," Keith says.

"I'm just seeing a movie with her!"

"Then why are you spazzing out?" A lazy grin spreads over his face. "Is she spazzing out about it too?"

Your throat and tongue seem to have seized up, so you just jerk your shoulders.

* * * * *

If Katy is spazzing out, she doesn't show it when you cross paths with her after fourth. You have another one of those spasms, though, when Stephanie, who is with her, jerks her chin at you with a faint smile.

"You wanna eat lunch with us again?" you ask Katy in a rush, and ignore the double-take that Caleb gives you. This time he doesn't go off to leave you alone with Katy, and Keith joins you too. You fancy you keep up your end of the conversation, though the time mostly passes with Keith and Caleb getting to know Katy better. Before you part, though, you reiterate that you'll pick her up that evening for the seven-thirty showing of Cravenmoor.

But the most "electric" moments of the day come during eighth period. You give Stephanie a sidelong look as you shuffle into the classroom and continue to dart her looks before class begins. She's too absorbed in her cell phone to notice, though you'd think the little thunderclaps that seem to be going off inside your skull would get her attention. Dimly, you wonder if you're having a series of micro-strokes.

Your gullet and guts grow colder and colder as class unfolds, until they feel completely frozen by the time the bell rings. Your knees don't want to unbend, and they creak when you stand. Slowly you look around to see if Stephanie has left yet. It would be a relief if she has. But she's still at her desk, tapping at her phone with a look of concentration.

She glances up—her countenance is friendly—when you shuffle over to her. "Hey, you going to see a movie with Katy tonight, huh?" she says.

"Yeah." Your voice is a croak. "Um. If you're not busy this afternoon, there's something I'd like to talk to you about."

"Yeah?" Her brow furrows. "Not about Katy, is it?"

"No. Well, not exactly. Actually, um, it's something I want to show you."

A look of faint alarm comes into her eyes. "Uh huh?"

You glance around, to see that the room is rapidly emptying, then fall into the seat directly in front of her.

"Look," you say in a low voice. "Katy told me about that voodoo thing you guys are doing. With that girl Hannah." Stephanie's eyes freeze, and your heart climbs up into your throat. "It's something kind of related to that. Not to Hannah, not to her," you hurriedly add. "It's— Well, you had that voodoo book, and it got me thinking— So I found this book at Arnholm's the other day. It's like an authentic magical grimoire, really old, got magic spells in it. I thought, if you're interested in using voodoo against that girl, you might want to take a look at it? For ideas?"

All the expression has drained from Stephanie's face, so that she's staring at you with a look of blank intensity. Then she blinks once, draws a short breath, and smiles. "Sure," she says. "Bring it in next week, I'll have a look at it—"

"Could you come look at it this afternoon?" you blurt out. "I mean, I guess next week would be fine, too. But I've got some stuff that I made with it, you could look at those things and it at the same time. You know that mask I showed you at the library the other night?" you add as Stephanie cocks her head. "That's something I made with it."

"Huh. Well, sure, I got time. What time are you picking Katy up?"

"Around seven. If you want to meet me where I keep the stuff, there's an old elementary school in Acheson."

"The community center? I know where that is." She agrees to rendezvous with you there in thirty minutes.

* * * * *

You're not sure why you've decided to let Stephanie in on this secret. She's no friend of yours, and you haven't even told Caleb and Keith, who are your friends. The only thing you can figure, as you mentally pull and twist at the question on the drive back into Acheson, is that you want to impress her. There's a good chance you'll be part of her social circle soon, if this relationship with Katy works out. You wonder if you're making her a kind of offering: See, you seem to be telling her, I'm worth knowing, worth hanging out with. I've got stuff to offer.

At least now you know why you were freaking out all day. It wasn't on account of the upcoming date with Katy, though that does give you a fluttery feeling in your stomach. It's because subconsciously you knew what you were going to say to Stephanie.

You beat her to the elementary school by about ten minutes, and she looks past you at it after dismounting from her SUV. Her expression is unreadable—she's wearing sunglasses—but you're struck suddenly by healthy she looks. She's a polished, golden bronze all over, from her bobbed blonde hair to her late summertime tan. Her legs and arms are smooth and strong, and bigger and more muscular than yours. And though you feel yourself hunching slightly in her presence, she has her shoulders back and her chin up.

"So I don't get it," she says, and she frowns behind her sunglasses. "You're keeping that stuff here? Where?"

"The basement." You gesture her to follow you down the steps, and as you undo the lock and lead her in you give her a summary of your history with it. "So, I think they've totally forgotten about it."

"Jesus," Stephanie says as she looks around the dark and dusty room. "You got guts, making this place your hideawy." She pulls off her sunglasses and wrinkles her nose at the room.

You notice that the fire has gone out again, but you ignore it for the moment. "Here's that book." You pull it from its lonely spot on a bookshelf and hand it to her. "It's all in Latin," you continue as she opens it. "I've made a couple of things from it, like that mask I showed you. Oh, and I took your advice on using a polisher." You hold up the mask you made last night, and she gives it a brief glance. "Got it done real fast."

"So, what kind of things can you do with this. Besides make those mask things?"

"I've only got a few spells into the book, because it does this funny thing with the pages. Here, I'll show you." She hangs onto the book as you flip the pages one by one. "I did this spell, and this one, and this one. Now I'm working on this one." You point to the pile of dirt. "That's the, uh, experiment over there. But I'm not done yet. So see?" You pull at the corner of the page. "It won't turn."

"Why not?" Stephanie says as she pulls at the corner. "Is it glued down?"

"No. Well, yes, but magically. All the pages were like that before I did the spell. See, it's like the page is locked down. Then you do the spell. Then the page turns loose."

Stephanie gives you a faint smile from under her lowered brows. At least she's amused, rather than contemptuous, of your story. But her skepticism provokes you into making the final throw.

"This is something I made," you tell her as you pull out the one finished mask you have. "I, uh— Well, never mind how it worked out this way. But I made this. It's of Coach Schell." You hand her the mask, inner face up, so that the coach's name shows.

Stephanie's face drains of all emotion as she takes it, and her eye has turned flinty when she looks back up at it you. But she is clearly curious, for she rubs her fingertip over the surface, where the letters of the coach's name seem to float. "So what is it supposed to do?" she says in a cold voice.

"It's a disguise. A mask of the coach. You put it on your face and it—" Sweat breaks out all over you. "You should just try it out and see. That's the easiest way."

Stephanie gives you a hard look. Then she shrugs and puts the mask to her face. She wobbles briefly, and you catch her as she topples forward.

It's Coach Schell who you lower onto the floor.

* * * * *

You leave her there, and go outside to wait. You wish you smoked. You're nervous, and a cigarette would pass the time.

After fifteen minutes pass with no sign of Stephanie, you creep back down the stairs to check on her. You open the door—

A figure at the other end of the basement whirls. It's Coach Schell, but she's in Stephanie's clothes. She's standing in front of the old mirror.

She says nothing. Finally, you croak out, "So, what do you think?"

A tense moment passes. Then Stephanie says, "Okay, first of all, we don't tell anyone about this."

"No one? Not even Katy?"

"No one. Have you told any of your friends?"

It might be fun, having a secret that's just yours and Stephanie's. But she's awfully bossy. Maybe you should tell some others.

11113441411112213122221121.content:
"Second of all," Stephanie says after you numbly nod your head, "you tell me all about this."

This, of course, is the mask she's wearing, that has transformed her into a duplicate of Coach Cathy Schell.

"Well, it's like I told you," you say. "I found this book at Arnholm's—"

"Hang on." She holds up her hand. "You're asking me to believe that a freaking used book store sold you a book that taught you how to do this?" She points to her face.

You can only shrug. "It was in the special collections case! They had it marked for, like, two hundred dollars. But I got it for cheap because, like I showed you, it was like all the pages were glued shut."

Stephanie barrels past you, and you get a frisson as her skin brushes yours.

She snatches up the book and flips rapidly through the first few pages, frowns at the one that's stuck shut, and grimaces as her thumbnail can't pry any of the subsequent ones open.

"Yeah," you tell her over her shoulder. "At first not even the first page would open. But then I, uh, gave it some blood—"

She wheels on you, and you snap your own mouth shut. But then she just says, "Go on."

"So I, uh, cut my thumb and squeezed out some blood and put it on this sigil thing on the front page. Here." You flip the book back to the first page, and show her the brownish stain. "After that it turned loose, and I did the first spell. It, uh, made that mask you're wearing."

"So the first recipe makes a mask that makes you look like Coach Schell?" Stephanie demands.

"No! It's more complicated than that. First, you—"

"Show me," Stephanie says, and there's iron in her voice.

* * * * *

So you spend the next hour going through each spell, step by step. You don't complete all of them, naturally—you're short on both time and materials. But you describe how to make a mask and a brain band. You show her the tubs of sealant and glue, and describe their uses. You tell her about fetching the dirt from the graveyard for the spell you have going now, and you relight it and show her how the purple flames that flare off it have no heat.

And—much more embarrassing—you describe how you got a copy of Coach Schell into the mask.

"I wanted to finish each spell, see what comes next," you explain, and you hate the desperate embarrassment that even you can hear in your voice. "And, you know, I didn't set out to copy Coach Schell. She was just convenient."

But you don't tell Stephanie about sneaking into Coach Schell's house and taking some of her clothes, or getting money off her friends, or how you copied Yumi's mind into a brain band and then used the Coach Schell disguise to eavesdrop at the Dairy Queen. Fortunately, Stephanie doesn't press for any details that would force you to confess any of that.

She does draw one really mortifying confession from you. "So these bands," she says while fingering . "They copy memories? And you got a copy of Coach Schell's memories? Here in this mask?" You nod in answer to each of these questions. "So, shouldn't I have her memories now? Shouldn't I be able to remember things that she could remember?"

"Sure." Your heart skips a beat. "Don't you?"

She shakes her head. "Am I supposed to concentrate or something?"

"No. It should come naturally."

"How do you know?" Her tone is sharp. "You tried them out?"

"Of course!" As soon as you say it, you feel yourself turning black with embarrassment.

Stephanie gives you a look, but she doesn't look angry or scandalized. "So like what sorts of things should I be remembering?"

"Oh, everything. Where she lives, where she goes to the gym. Her classes. Her, uh, boyfriend." You stare closely at Stephanie, whose gaze has gone distant. "Getting anything?"

"No. What's her boyfriend's name?"

"I don't remember. The memories don't stay with you long after you take the mask off. He's a Hispanic guy, I know that. He's one of the tutors."

"Oh, him," Stephanie says, then she blinks. "Really? Does everyone know it?"

"I guess the staff does. I don't remember it being a secret thing."

"Huh. 'Cos I'm not getting anything. I mean, I know who you're talking about, but I don't remember anything ..." She trails off, and again her gaze goes unfocused. "No," she says with a sigh. "Nothing. Are you sure?"

"Yeah, pretty sure. But the, uh, the mask itself works fine." You look her up and down. She does look good, especially in Stephanie's clothes, which expose her legs from high on the thigh all the way down to her ankles. "But maybe I should take it off you."

"Maybe you better," Stephanie agrees, and at your direction she lays back on one of the tables. Her eyes flutter as you lay your hand across her brow. You grip her forehead, mutter some nonsensical syllables, and pull. The mask comes away in your hand, leaving the unconscious Stephanie behind.

You give her another good lookover, and wonder what exactly you've gotten yourself into by sharing all this with her, then trudge up the stairs and outside.

* * * * *

It's closing on dinnertime, and you've a date after that, so you and Stephanie part thereafter. She impresses upon you again the need for secrecy, and says that she'll want to talk to tomorrow. "Early," she says, which makes your heart sink a little.

You've not much appetite at the dinner table, but no one expects you to have one on account of your going to the show. Afterward, you change into fresh jeans and a shirt and shoot Katy a text telling her you're on your way. It's a pleasant drive up to the Silverplex Cinema, though you feel yourself distracted. You're more pleasantly distracted during the movie by the way Katy keeps grabbing you at tense moments, so that you're nicely aroused by the time the movie is over, and you come real close to leaning over and nuzzling her while end credits crawl, but restrain yourself. Afterward you drive down to The Flying Saucer for a post-cinema snack and to talk about the movie, and other scary movies that you've seen. You part by telling her you'll text her after church on Sunday, to see about getting together to do something else.

You make a point of telling all this to Stephanie when she texts you later that night to inform you that you'll be meeting at The Shed, a cafe in the tiny Acheson business district, but she only texts back an ok.

She's waiting out front the next morning when you arrive, and she gives you a look as you get out of your truck. "You drove?" she says.

"Sure. How did you get here?"

"I jogged," she says. (But she looks pretty fresh.) "You don't live that far, Will," she reminds you, for you'd given her your address last night. You grimace at her back as she leads you inside. It's an old-fashioned cafe, the kind with a bar at the front with stools, but you settle into a booth in the farthest corner you can muster. Stephanie leans over the tabletop to address you in a low voice.

"So I told you last night not to tell anyone about this," she says, "and I'm serious. Totally serious. I mean, my God, can you imagine what people could do with that book? Who'd be interested in it?"

"Like the CIA?"

"Never mind the CIA. Think of terrorists. Criminal gangs. The kind of illegal shit you could get up to with it is—" She gives you a sharp look. "What were you planning to do with it?"

You feel yourself pale. "Nothing! I mean, I hadn't even thought about it. I'm just, you know, curious about what all you can—"

"Jesus, Will," she says softly. "Well, anyway, don't tell anyone. Let's just keep this between us."

You nod, then blurt out, "What do you want to do with it?"

She rears back like she's been slapped. "I don't know! I mean, I'm just thinking how we can't let anyone know about it. That's the most—"

She breaks off and licks her lips. "So one thing is," she says when she resumes, "is you don't do any more, like— You don't go ambushing people like Coach Schell anymore. Okay? I mean, Christ, what if you'd got caught?"

"What if the next spell needs us to? Are you saying we can't?" You feel your heart sinking, for it sounds like Stephanie is going to try to take the book away from you.

"Well, we can finish up the one you've got going. Any idea how long it's supposed to take?"

You shake your head. "But as far as doing stuff with the book— Look, I thought you wanted to use voodoo against Hannah. So I thought you'd want to—"

"Jesus," she breathes, and turns pale. She looks away, and her jaw works. You hold your breath. "Well, like what?" she says at last. "Are you saying you've got ideas?"

"Well, Katy told me you had an idea about getting Hannah drunk, and getting her to make out with someone not her boyfriend. Maybe instead you could, uh, copy Hannah in a mask, then disguise yourself as her and go out in public and—"

Stephanie rears back. But it's like your tongue has a mind of its own, and another suggestion bubbles out.

"Or you could gaslight her," you say. "Pretend to be some of her friends, get in fights with her, then they think she's crazy when she calls them on it afterward. Or, you want her to quit the soccer team? Pretend to be the soccer coach, yell at her, get her mad so she quits—"

"Jesus," she says again. She's very pale—haggard, even—and breathing hard. You clap your mouth shut. The moment hangs.

"Look," she says at last. "You're the one seems pretty bullish on doing any of these tricks. You wanna do one, fine. I won't stop you."

You can't tell from her tone whether she's disgusted and wants you to recant your suggestions, or whether she wants you to do them and is afraid to say so.
11113441411112213122221121.title: The Voodoo That You Do So Well

choices: Send a copy of yourself to send to school, etc.
Duplicate a friend of Hannah's for gaslighting.
Never mind; Stephanie is clearly too horrified
111134414111122131222211213.content:
You hesitate. All this stuff is new to Stephanie. Hell, it's new to you too. So with a shrug of your shoulders you try to indicate that you won't push anything.

But deep down, as the waitress sets your food in front of you, you're thinking, Let her get used to all this. Then we'll talk about gaslighting this Hannah girl. We'll get some masks of her girlfriends, she can help me with that, and then I'll—

"What we need to do," Stephanie says, interrupting your thoughts, "is to move that stuff someplace safe."

"What? Move what stuff?

"The crap you've got in the basement. You don't want to get caught down there."

"I won't get caught!"

She gives you one of her patented looks, the kind that says Don't be a moron. "You've been lucky so far. You get busted, and you're looking at—"

"Well, I can't move the stuff to my house!"

"I know where we can put it. There's a vacant space next to my dad's furniture store."

"That'd be trespassing too! And the elementary school is easy to get to, it's just down the road from where I live!"

"Keep your voice down. Look, lemme just show it to you. If you can come up with a better idea, we'll do it. But we have to move out of where you are now."

You're even less happy when she tells you her proposed hideout is next to Argosy Furniture, which is practically in the middle of the downtown district, and that it would be hard getting in and out of it outside of business hours. But you agree to look it over, and you also agree to move the stuff out of the elementary school and into your truck at least until you can settle on a new spot. On the drive out to the school after breakfast, you tease her on your foresight bringing your truck to The Shed to meet her.

* * * * *

The fire is out again, but you ignore the moldering pile of dirt for the moment to concentrate on gathering everything else up. It makes for a jumbled heap: bags and canisters and boxes of chemicals and soils along with the grimoire, the masks, and the containers of sealant and glue. But after transferring all that to the bed your truck, Stephanie crooks a finger at the dirt pile. "What about that? Think we can move it?"

"How? Move the table it's on? The dirt by itself is four hundred pounds, and I don't want to risk messing it up."

"Maybe we could start over again?" Stephanie rubs her nose. "How long has it been cooking for?"

"A week. I don't want to get more dirt."

Stephanie grimaces. "Thing is, it already looks ruined."

You give it a hard look of your own. It has changed, and not in a way that suggests it's been improved. The berm has tightened up into a solid, log-like cylinder and acquired a grayish hue; in fact, it now looks more like a concrete support that's been laid on its side. But it is split up the middle at one end, and two other rents have opened farther up.

You're not willing to give up on it yet, though. "Let's just burn it until it won't burn anymore," you say. "Then we can start over if it's fucked up."

Stephanie shrugs. You fetch the lighter from the truck, where you'd already packed it, and set a flame to its center.

Nothing happens. You set the flame lower, and when it doesn't catch, you wave it about, trying to find a spot where the fuel is still damp. Still nothing happens. You glance back at Stephanie.

"Lemme see," she says, and takes the lighter from you. She can't get it to fire up either. "Do you think it's done?" she asks.

"I think I know how we can find out." You fetch the book from the truck and hold your breath as you pull at the corner of the last open page. But it doesn't come away.

"Here." Again, Stephanie has to make a go of it herself, also without success. She makes a face—showing her teeth—at the book and at the dirt.

"Hang on, lemme try something." You take the book back from her and rest it briefly open-face down atop the solidified dirt pile. When you flip it back over, the troublesome page easily flips over. "You just gotta show it who's boss," you tell Stephanie with a grin.

"That's great," she says, "but what now?"

You run a finger down the newly revealed text. "This should tell us what it does."

"Can you read Latin?"

"No, but that's what an online translator is for. Get out your phone and I'll dictate."

* * * * *

But Stephanie turns out to be all thumbs at typing messages in, so you wind up doing it all yourself while she looks over your shoulder. Word by word, phrase by phrase, it emerges. You have to read it through a couple of times in order to fix the translation so that it makes sense. But when you're done, Stephanie stands back on her heels with wide, staring eyes. "That can't be right," she insists.

"But that's what it says. And there's only one way to find out." You heart is beating hard with anticipation. "We'll use Coach Schell's mask. Go get it."

But Stephanie looks too ill to move, so you make a third trip up to your truck. When you're back, Stephanie scuttles away to give you room to hazard the experiment. You sidle up to one end of the thing—the end with the onion-like blob, that looks sort of like a head, you now realize, same as the tear up the middle has created what look like legs, and the rents up the sides have separated out two rude arms—and place the mask on it.

You know what will happen; the spell tells you what will happen, despite Stephanie's doubts that you've translated correctly. But it's still a shock when the mask and the thing you made vanish, and Coach Schell appears there in its place.

It's a perfect replica of her: The upturned face is a little hard to make out on account of the angle you're looking at her from. But the flowing blonde hair; the curves of the shoulder and the bosom; the inward swoop of her stomach and the swelling of her hips; the strong thighs and calves; and the pert feet—it's all as you remember her being.

It's an even greater shock when she frowns and opens her eyes. She looks over at you, does a little double take, and gasps.

"Will!"

At first you think it's like a ventriloquist's trick: the coach's lips didn't move when she said your name. Then you realize it was Stephanie. A hand falls on your shoulder and wrenches you around. Stephanie's green eyes are shining hard and her lip is curled back in a slight snarl. "Maybe you better go wait upstairs," she says.

Upstairs? You gape. Stephanie is trying to throw you out because the fake Coach Schell is naked?

"Hey, she's my lackey!" you exclaim.

"She's no one's—! At least turn around!"

"I've already seen what she looks like, Stephanie! Remember, I told you yesterday that I put the mask on!"

"That was—! That was—!" She stammers and falls silent. Her eyes blaze.

From behind you, a plaintive voice wails, "What the hell is going on? Stephanie?"

Stephanie pales. You whirl.

The fake coach is sitting up and covering herself as best she can with her arms and hands and legs. "What's going on?" she asks again.

"What's your name?" you demand. It's a stupid thing to ask, but you're stuck for a test question.

"Cathy Schell," she says. "Stephanie, who is—? Where are—?"

"Where do you teach?"

Her frown deepens. "Westside High. What's with all the—?"

Her voice is drowned out by Stephanie's and then your own as you all start talking at once. You cut the coach off with a sharp, "Be quiet," then round on Stephanie.

"Look, we have to test it out," you tell her. "To be sure it's doing what it's supposed to do, and how far we can, uh—"

"How far?" Stephanie echoes. Her voice rises. "What the fuck are you planning to do with it?"

"Nothing! I don't know! It's supposed to be a lackey! That's what the book says!" You point at the grimoire. "Put a mask on it, and it turns into the image of the one in the mask and a lackey of the one who made it. Well, it sure looks like Coach Schell, but we should make sure that it's got the lackey part too!"

"This is sick," Stephanie snarls. "Look at her! It's practically her! It's not a— a robot or whatever you thought it was going to be!"

"Let's just test it out, okay? Then we'll take the mask off it if it's creeping you out so bad. I promise!"

Stephanie's mouth spreads into a sharp, wide rictus, but she says nothing. You turn back to the coach.

But suddenly you're at a loss for ideas. "What should I tell her to do?" you ask Stephanie.

"Stand up," Stephanie orders the coach. But she only stares back with a terrified expression.

But when you say, "Stand up," the coach lurches to her feet, her hands flapping to cover her private parts. "Jesus," Stephanie gasps. "We need to get her some clothes!"

"We'll call that enough," you assure her. "Sit back down," you tell the thing. "Lay back down." The thing complies, and its terror seems to increase. But the emotion vanishes—along with the face itself—when you lay your hand on its forehead and rip the mask off.

Stephanie collapses against a table. "This is really creepy," she says in a quavering voice.

"It's cool," you say. "Don't you see what we can do with it?"

"I can think of lots of sick things you could do with it."

"There's sick things you could do with it too," you blurt out. Stephanie turns a bright red.

"Look," you continue. "I showed you this stuff 'cos I want us to be friends. I'll let you do something with it, if you let me do something with it."

"What's that?"

1111344141111221312222112131.content:
"We can make copies of ourselves," you tell Stephanie, "and use them to do all the stuff we don't."

Stephanie stares at you as though you're a madman.

"Don't you see?" you continue. "Like going to school or church or shit like that. We make masks of ourselves— I mean, we'd have to take turns sharing the thing, 'cos there's only one of them." The ideas are coming so fast you trip over them. "But we could send a lackey in to school or wherever to cover for us so we don't have to—"

"Hang on," Stephanie says. "You want to skip school?"

"Don't you?"

She grimaces. "Look, I don't mind skipping classes. But all my friends are there. I don't wanna skip out and miss them."

Her objection stops you short. That's not something you'd thought of.

"Besides," she says, "if you miss out on school, you'll be confused when you go back."

"The lackey will tell you what you missed!"

"It's not the same thing, Will. What if something important happens and it forgets to tell you?" She puts a hand on her hip and gives you a very direct stare. "And school's not that bad."

"Maybe not for you," you blurt back. "Do you get hassled in the hallways by assholes?"

She opens her mouth to reply, then closes it with a snap.

"Yeah, I bet you don't," you continue, and your neck gets hot. "Maybe you have guys hitting on you, I bet you've got that, but you don't have guys pushing you around or hauling you outside or—"

"Who?" says Stephanie. "Who does that to you?"

"The Molester. Lester Pozniak. David Kirkham. Seth Javits, though I guess he—"

"Wait." Stephanie raises her hand. "Someone's molesting you?"

"Well, not sexually. That's just what we call him."

"Who?"

"I told you, Lester Pozniak. Lester the Molester. Mo-Lester," you repeat.

Stephanie bursts out laughing. "That's good," she says, "but—" She catches herself, and looks you up and down. Her expression tightens. "Look, I'm sorry you get bullied, but even if you skipped, what would you do?"

"Hang out someplace?"

"That's not an answer, Will."

"Just let me try it out! We made the damn thing, we should get at least some use out of it!"

"Fine. You made it, it's your thing. But for now we need to get the stuff moved."

"The lackey's too heavy to move."

Stephanie stares down at it, then looks back up at you with a smile you don't like. "Go home and get some clothes," she tells you. "Shorts, t-shirt and flip-flops will be enough."

* * * * *

"I told you the thing-a-fuckie would come in handy," Will Prescott brags.

"No you didn't," you retort. "I—"

"He was talking to me, Will," Stephanie says. "Weren't you, Will?"

"Damn straight," your doppelganger replies. "And wasn't I right?"

"You sure showed me," Stephanie agrees.

"Shut up, both of you," you growl. "Concentrate on the road," you order the thing that's driving your truck.

You thought it was pretty cool at first, when the thing came to life again, only with your face instead of Coach Schell's. It took a couple of hours to get it set up, though, as you'd explained to Stephanie when she told you her plan for moving the lackey. You had a blank mask you could use on yourself, but you had to carve a set of runes into another brain band.

While you did that at your house, she used your truck to drive the other stuff out to her dad's store. A little after lunch you met her at the school again with the makings of a complete "Will Prescott" disguise—mask, brain band, and clothes—and put them on the lackey. There was a little confusion at first, as the thing upon waking was convinced it was you and that you were it, but it only took a little argument, and the demonstration that he had to follow your orders while you didn't have to follow its, to straighten things out. It pleased you immensely at first as Lackey-Will unhappily did jumping jacks while you gloated Make me when it tried to order you to do the same.

But then Stephanie started taking its side.

It started with the clothes. You ordered it to get into the cheap shorts and shirt you'd brought for it, but Stephanie stopped you. "You put them on," she said. "Give him the clothes you got on."

"How come?"

"Because you want it to be you, right? So give it—him—your clothes."

Your doppelganger grinned as you buckled under and started stripping.

Then when you demanded the keys from him—they were in the pockets of the jeans he was now wearing—Stephanie insisted that he should drive your truck if he was going to be you. And when Lackey-Will pointed out that it would look weird to see two Will Prescotts in the cab of his truck, Stephanie tried to force you to ride in the back under the tarp before grudgingly allowing you to crouch down in the passenger-side foot well.

Even after you reach your destination, Stephanie tells you to stay in the car while she takes "Will" inside, leaving you to fume. It's fifteen minutes before she returns.

Argosy Furniture is a giant second-hand furniture store occupying most of a city block in downtown Saratoga Falls. It's a three-story building of weathered brick that's a hundred and fifty years old, probably, with immense bay windows that glint over the sidewalk at the traffic that grumbles past on Borman. Inside, it smells of old wood and musty fabrics.

"I got the other guy through without running into anyone," Stephanie mutters at you as she winds her way past dining room sets and living room sets. "So if we run into anyone, just be yourself."

"Thanks," you grumble back. "But how'm I to get my lackey out of here for school on Monday? What time does this place open?"

"Ten, but your twin and I already set it up." You do a double take at her words. "We'll take him out of storage on Sunday afternoon before closing time. He'll go home and be you, then go to school the next morning."

"And where will I be? Sleeping here?"

"No, you'll spend the night with Caleb, and drive in with him Monday morning. Your other guy will leave the keys to your truck under the floor mat so you can take off as soon as you get to school."

"What if Caleb doesn't want me spending the night?"

"We already set it up. Will texted him and Caleb's okay with it."

"Oh, now he's 'Will', is he?" you snap at her.

"Yeah." Stephanie flashes you a grin. "I really like him. He's twice as smart and not half the wanker you are."

You clench your fists.

Stephanie leads you through an office complex in the back and down a maintenance hallway that seems to run the length of the block. She stops before a metal door and glances around before sliding a key into the lock and opening it. She hustles you through and shuts the door. It's pitch black until she switches on the light.

It's a small room, dusty and bare, with three yawning doorways leading out. She pushes you through one and flicks on another light. The room beyond is also bare but for a long table, on which rests the sacks containing your work material. You do a double-take at a stone pylon in the corner: the lackey, disencumbered of a mask.

"So, this is where we'll keep things," Stephanie says. "I'll make you another key so you can get in. If anyone ever tries to stop you from getting back here, tell them you're looking for me."

"How did you get a key?"

"Lifted it off my dad, copied it. You're not the only one who likes getting into stuff, you know. Here's your clothes." She picks up a bundle from the table and thrusts it at you. "I'll be waiting outside while you change." She's gone before you ask her why it's okay for her to look at your naked doppelganger but not your naked self.

* * * * *

She wants you to take her home after that, but you're in a rebellious mood. And besides, you point out, if this is going to be a workspace, you should try it out. She grimaces but accedes, and tells you to keep out of sight while she gets a ride from someone else.

You spoke more out of spite than a genuine desire to do some work, though, and after twenty minutes of polishing a new mask, you're bored.

So you pop your mask onto the lackey. His knees briefly buckle before he catches himself. "Whoa," he says. "Is it Sunday already?"

"No, it's still Saturday. Thirty minutes after you left us."

"So what's up?" His face falls as you thrust the polisher and the mask at him. "Jesus! Stephanie's right, you are an asshole."

"Did she call me that?" you exclaim.

"No," he admits. "So what are you going to do? Polish yourself while I polish the mask?"

"No, I'm going to study up on the next spell." You throw the tatty shorts and t-shirt at him, then curl up on the floor with the grimoire and your cell phone.

* * * * *

Twenty minutes later, your twin shuts off the car buffer. "What's wrong?" he says. "Translator won't work?"

You wish it were. Instead, you've found the next spell all too easy to translate.

It's practically a duplicate of previous spell, which made the lackey. There's only one difference: Instead of four hundred pounds of graveyard dirt, it calls for forty.

And it also calls for a human being. To be set on fire along with everything else.

You doubt Stephanie would go along with that. Maybe this would be a good time to distract her with that "gaslighting" idea you had earlier.

11113441411112213122221121312.content:
In the time it takes you to carve the runes into a single brain band, your double finishes polishing all the masks. Instead of continuing to work, though, you shut things down and go home. No one stops you on the way out as you exit through the furniture store.

You get your weekend homework done while fielding texts from Caleb, Katy, and Stephanie. Caleb wants to know what you're doing Sunday afternoon. Katy wants to know the same thing, while Stephanie wants to get the key to the new hideout back from you so she can make a duplicate. You mention to her that Katy is looking for something to do, and she quickly texts back that Catherine Muskov, one of the popular girls at school, will probably be hosting an impromptu party, and that you and Katy should try to show up there.

who else be there? you ask, thinking of possible people to copy for a gaslighting attack on Hannah. Stephanie shoots back a list of names, many of which you recognize only as names, not as faces. But one jumps out—mehgan—before Stephanie winds things up with, lotsf pepople w be three jst shpw up.

You propose Catherine's place to Katy, and she thinks that's a great idea; and you also propose it to Caleb. He's slower to reply, and when he does he asks, what's the attraction?

girls u idiot, you reply. COME ON!

Another long pause, and you can practically hear the tired sigh in his reply: ok text me tomorrow abt it.

You fall asleep thinking about girls, and you dream about girls too. Girls in tight, hip-hugging shorts and breasts that strain against athletic tops; girls showing flushed thighs and arms and throats. You don't remember any faces in the dream, and the bodies aren't so distinct that you recognize them. But you have the very strong impression that you know them.

* * * * *

You're antsy all through church—but you always are—and once it's over you race out to the car with your phone to start a round of furious texting. It continues, except for a break for lunch, until around one-thirty, when plans get nailed down. You will rendezvous at three o'clock at Catherine Muskov's with Caleb and Katy; but first you will meet Stephanie to get that key copied.

"So I stayed late yesterday and made another mask," you tell her while the locksmith is in back running the key through his machine. "My, uh, twin helped me out."

"That's great, I guess you're getting some use out of him," she says.

"So, now I've got this new mask, and ... " You trail off, and watch Stephanie closely for her reaction. She stares off into the back of the shop for a moment, then turns to give you a blank, expectant look. "And I figure we could get some use of it, too," you lamely conclude.

"Like how?"

"Well, the thing you're doing with Hannah. Remember we talked about that? I was thinking we could, like, copy one of her girlfriends, stir up some trouble between them?"

"Like how?" she repeats.

"I don't know," you admit. "We'd have to get inside her, uh, her brain, see what kind of trouble we could make. Like starting fights about something. Maybe we could pretend that the girl is jealous of Hannah's boyfriend? Start a fight over him? Maybe one of them is." You shrug. Stephanie's expression remains very taut.

"Thing is," you continue after taking a deep breath, "I don't know this Hannah girl, so I don't know who her friends are, who we could, you know—"

"You keep saying 'we', Will. This thing we got going with Hannah, it's not really any of your business."

"Well, I want to help. Can't I help? I mean, I know I'm not ... friends"—you gulp out the word—"with you and your friends. I mean, I guess I'm not. Am I?"

Stephanie doesn't reply. The locksmith returns with the key and its copy, and she pays him. Out in the parking lot, she dons her sunglasses, gives you the copy of the key, and looks away.

"Look, it's not a club," she says. "You don't have to fill out an application. I'm not saying you're not a friend. I'm not saying anything. But we've got guy friends who aren't part of this, even the ones who know about it. Oh, and by the way, I really wish you wouldn't say anything about it."

"I won't. I mean, I haven't."

She grunts, scrapes the back of her hand across her nose. You tense as you wait for her to speak.

But when she speaks again, she just says, "I'll see you at Catherine's."

* * * * *

The Muskovs don't live in the toniest part of town, but they live in a very nice neighborhood in a large house with plenty of parking. That's good, because there are lots of cars on the street when you pull up.

The door is opened by two giggling girls who are leaning against each other to keep from falling over. They look familiar, but you can't quite place them, and they don't seem to recognize you. "Oh hey," the blonde one says. "Come on in."

"Is Katy here yet?" you ask. "Katy Conlee?"

"Yeah, she's upstairs. Oooh!" The blonde one seems to see you for the first time, and her eyes go very wide. She grins, and pinches her friend in the side. "She's upstairs," she tells you again over the other girl's squeals.

"Thanks." You glance around, and move toward the staircase while trying not to blush. It's hard, especially when the other girl bursts out in shrill laughter a few seconds after your back is turned.

There's a broad hallway at the top of the stairs, but it's not so broad that three people, standing in a knot, can't clog it. One is Fred Hildown, a tall, good-natured kid who like Catherine is on the track team. You don't know the other guy, but he's in shorts that show off thighs knotted with muscles, and he's got his deep chest thrown out, so even though he doesn't throw you to the floor and give you a wedgie, you're pretty sure he's a jock. Like Meghan Velasquez, who they're talking to, they're holding and drinking from plastic tumblers. Fred nods at you with a "Hey Will," and Meghan smiles brightly as you squeeze past them.

Girls' laughter floats out of a bedroom, and inside it you find Katy and half a dozen other girls, including Catherine Muskov herself. She's a tall girl with a mane of brunette hair that falls softly to her shoulders, and a calm, merry expression. She's in shorts and a tank top, showing off long, strong limbs—much like the limbs you dreamed about last night, you realize with a start. Just the kind of limbs you'd like to find embracing you.

111134414111122131222211213124314.content:
You lean in on Stephanie. "Who do you really have the hots for?"

It's an obvious question, so it's an innocent question, and so it's a question that Stephanie shouldn't freak out over. But it's one that could stir her up, get her excited; get her a little rowdy, maybe, and if you worked at it ... a little raunchy?

She rolls her eyes. "What are we, back in middle school all of a sudden?"

You giggle. "You play it so close, Stephanie. I have no idea who you like, or even what kind of guy you like. Isn't there anyone?"

She sighs. "Dare."

You groan. "Dares are no fun," you pout, "and I'm no good at coming up with any. At least, none we can do here when it's just us." Actually you can think of a dare that would involve just the two of you, but you judge it's too early for that kind of thing. "So I'll change my question. Is there anyone who gets you all, you know, twitchy?" You tickle her, and she jumps.

"Dare," she repeats.

"Oh God, there is, isn't there?" you exclaim. Stephanie, who is already pink, turns a deeper crimson. "Why don't you want anyone to know? But you can tell me. I can keep it a secret, remember?" You grin at her.

Stephanie falls onto her back and stares at the ceiling. She pinches the bridge of her nose. She takes a couple of deep breaths.

Then she says, "No. I can't say it out loud."

"Why not?" You suck in a sharp breath. "Is it a girl?"

Wow! If a look could scorch, the glare Stephanie shoots at you would have burnt your face off, mask and all! "No," she says.

"Oh, don't take it like that," you laugh. "I'm never more than about four wine coolers away from making out with a girl at a party."

Stephanie's eyes widen. "Seriously?"

You nod, and roll onto your stomach to give her a close stare. "Go on," you say. "Ask me." You grin. "That's my Dare to you. Ask me who I've made out with."

Stephanie's nostrils flare. "Who?" she asks in a croak.

"No one!" You loose a gale of laughter into the room. "Never had a chance! But I would," you add more earnestly. It's not a lie, not exactly, you're putting into Catherine's mouth. "There wouldn't be as much pressure, you know?" You curl onto your side and hug your knees to your chest. Your bare legs are warm and smooth, and you thrill inside and out as you hug them. "I figure it would be hot, but alos kind of relaxing, more like a cuddle. Don't you ever want to do that? Just to cuddle with someone? To hold them and stroke them?"

Stephanie's gaze goes distant. "Nnh. I guess when I think about it I go straight to the fun part."

You suppress a little gasp of excitement. "Well," you drawl, "I guess it could go on for a little more than just a cuddle. Depending on how fun it was." You titter. "Your turn."

But Stephanie says nothing, and continues to gaze past your shoulder. After a few minutes of silence, she stirs when someone downstairs calls her name. "Be right back," she tells you as she hops off the bed. But it's actually closer to a quarter hour, and her mood has cooled by the time she returns.

* * * * *

So that's the end of the game, and when she comes back she tells you to amuse yourself on her laptop while she checks her phone. She does join you, though, when she notices that you've logged in to Catherine's social media accounts, and she puts her arm around you as she leans in to run the cursor around the screen as she reads.

"Lookit," she says, "Catherine's setting up a thing with the track and baseball teams for after school tomorrow. She'll be busy with them, so you can get together with Hannah then, maybe."

"How will I do that?"

She looks at you. "How would Catherine set it up?"

It's a good question, and you mull it for a minute. Then you open up Snapchat.

Stephanie stops you. "Hang on, don't do it through Catherine's account. Do it through—" She wraps her arms around you and taps at the keyboard. "Here. This is a, uh, second account I keep. For special stuff."

As she types, you reach up to lightly clasp and stroke her arm, letting go only when she straightens up again.

"What should I tell her?" you ask.

"Just that you want to meet her. Tell her it's important, though, and, uh, kind of sensitive. Just you and her."

"Where can we meet?"

"Cherry Brook Bakery. It' just up the street from my pop's store."

"And what am I supposed to do when we're together."

"I'll tell you tomorrow. Just send her the invite now."

You shrug, and lean in toward the laptop camera. "Hey Hannah," you say, speaking quickly so as to squeeze the full message into the tiny video snippet. "I'm gonna be at Cherry Brook Bakery tomorrow after school, could you meet me there around four, four-thirty? Just us, 'cos it's kind of sensitive. And don't tell anyone. Really." You flash a brief frown. "We need to talk."

Stephanie grunts over it, and forces you to record it a few more times until she's satisfied that your message will draw out Hannah without alarming her and causing her to say anything to the real Catherine at school. Then you send it. Your co-conspirator is looking a little pale in the face when you stand up.

"It'll be okay," you tell her, and draw her into a light embrace. "I know I was kind of a bitch earlier about it all, but now I figure that if you're going to all this trouble to get back at her, you must a good reason." You stroke her back.

If you thought your words would reassure her, you were wrong, for Stephanie looks even more stricken when you release her.

* * * * *

When it's time for bed, Stephanie changes into pajamas. She's not shy about disrobing in front of you, and you have to pretend very hard not to be interested as her shirt and shorts and underthings come off. She has strong, smooth limbs, and her flat, taut stomach faintly shows the lines of her abdominal muscles. After she's changed, she hands you a set of flannel pajamas. You pull off the skimpy clothes you've been wearing, enjoying the feel of the cool air on your breasts and hips, but are slow to put the other things on.

"You know," you tell her as you unfold them, "I don't normally wear PJs when I sleep."

"What, you sleep in the nude?" Stephanie replies as she pulls back the sheets of her bed. "I sometimes do too."

"It's nice, isn't it? Just feeling the sheets against you. Do you mind if I, uh—?"

"Do whatever you want," she grunts as she slips between the sheets. "Come on, I have to get up early tomorrow."

So you slip into bed with her, with only her pajamas between you. She puts out the light, and for a long while you lay there listening to the sound of her breathing. Your heart works its way higher and higher into your throat.

"You know," you finally croak out, "when I was talking earlier about ... cuddling?"

A pause. "Uh huh?"

"Well, I'd kind of like it if— I mean, wouldn't it be fun if—"

You break off at the long sigh that follows. "The hell is wrong with you?" Stephanie mutters.

You wince, but persist. "Nothing. But I'm not real. You know I'm not. And—" You pluck at the side of Stephanie's pajamas. "It's like when we were doing Truth or Dare. We could tell each other things we'd never tell people, because it can't go any farther than us. Well, we could also—" You gulp. "We could also do things that—" You trail off as your words are swallowed into the oppressive silence.

"I don't want to do anything," Stephanie says. Her tone is rough and impatient. "I'm not into that. It doesn't have any appeal for me." Under her breath she adds something that sounds like, "Especially not with a sex doll."

"So you're exclusively interested in guys?"

"Yeah, pretty much."

Still you press: "And even though it's dark in here, you can't close your eyes and pretend that I'm a guy?"

"I'm only interested in one guy." Her voice is strained. "And it's pretty hard to pretend you're him."

It's a shot in a million, but you take it anyway: "It's not your friend Will, is it?"

She snorts. "Oh, Jesus. Just shut up and go to sleep. Remember, you have to do what I say."

* * * * *

Stephanie is up early the next morning for a jog. You'd go with her—a first for Will Prescott though not for Catherine Muskov—but you've no running shoes, so instead you take a very long and soapy shower with lots of time to rub and finger yourself. After she's back and showered, Stephanie gives you a fresh set of gym clothes and also an old iPod Touch that used to belong to her older brother (now off at college) so you can keep amused during the day. She drops you off at Argosy Furniture on her way to school, and you make your way back into the workroom.

It's not long before you're bored out of your skull. With nothing better to do, you pull out mask supplies and resume working on them. Six mind-crushingly dull hours later, you've completed and attached two more brain-bands to two more polished masks. Your only respite comes at around two, when Stephanie texts you with an alert: Her mother needs her to run errands after school, so "Will Prescott" will instead be meeting you at Argosy after your meeting with Hannah.

With nothing else to do after finishing those masks, you return to the grimoire and study the new spell—the one that calls for a person to be set on fire. You're so bored that you can't help thinking about it, and how you might execute it.

And who you might use when executing it.

So the next spell uses a person as an ingredient. But it's not really asking for a human sacrifice. You're sure of that. Why would it? Probably it just wants to, you know, borrow some of the person's "life force" or something. Nothing bad would happen if you used, say, Hannah Westrick in the spell. Would it?

Of course, if that were true you could use yourself in the spell instead of someone else. But just because you're sure the spell is totally safe doesn't mean that you're stupid.

You kill the rest of the afternoon by prepping the ingredients. Ten minutes after school lets out, you shoot Hannah another little video, asking her to meet you at Argosy Furniture instead.

* * * * *

"Hey!" You give Hannah a wide smile and put your arms out for an embrace as she gets out of her car. Remarkably, she found a metered parking space on the street.

Hannah puts out her arms, and you pull her into a close hug. She's a big girl—though not in a bad way—and fills your arms. She is very warm, too.

Hannah Westrick is one of the stars of Westside girls' varsity soccer team. If you—that is to say, Catherine—were forced to confess, you'd say that she's the best player, and by a fair margin too. She's tall—almost six-foot—with strong thighs and calves and a build that manages to seem husky even while preserving an hourglass shape between her large bosom and her wide hips. You wouldn't want to see a girl that size charging across the field at you, whether the ball was between her feet or between yours. She wears her hair, which coils up in tight, frizzy curls, in a long, thick ponytail that trails almost to the small of her back. Her face is wide and flat and handsome. Maybe it's her size, and the mane-like shape of her hair, but there's something cat-like, even leonine, about her visage.

"So you got changed in a hurry," Hannah says now. She pulls back but continues to stroke your back while smiling into your face.

You shrug. "Well, you know, couldn't wait to get comfortable. So how was your day?" You tuck your arm into hers and hold her hand as you lead her into the store.

"God. Fuck. Excuse my language." She covers her mouth with her fingers as you almost run into a woman her small child just inside the front door. Into your ear she murmurs, "Would you talk to Dominique Hughes for me, please? I'd talk to her myself, but I can't even."

"Why, what's she doing now?"

Hannah snorts. "Look, that shit she pulled at the party was one thing. You know I'm not blaming you for that, right? Where are we going?" she interrupts herself, and looks around.

"A place in the back we can talk."

"What was wrong with the bakery?" She looks around, as though she's just noticed what kind of store she's in.

"There's more privacy here. You won't mind. It's kind of cozy."

But Hannah stiffens as you pull her along toward the back offices. "What did you want to talk about anyway?" she asks.

"That can wait 'til whenever." You squeeze her hand. "What was Dominique doing, like, today?"

"Oh, well, you know that headscarf she wore to your party?"

"The red one? Oh my God!" The words come blurting out before you can stop them. "If I thought I could pull off a look like that!"

"I know, right?" Hannah squeezes your hand back. "That's only one of the reasons I friggin' hate her, because she can do that whole exotic gypsy thing—"

"Did you notice she wasn't even wearing earrings the other night?" Still Catherine's thoughts come tumbling out of you. It's easier to give in to her excitement than to stifle and second-guess them.

"What about her earrings?"

"She wasn't wearing any. At the party. But didn't it seem like to you she was?" You cluck your tongue enviously. "Big, gold, hoop earrings, to go with the headscarf. You know, like a gypsy."

"I didn't notice, but why are you making a deal about—? Was she wearing earrings or wasn't she?"

You roll your eyes. "She wasn't, but it totally seemed like she was, right? It didn't seem like that to you? It did to me. I mean, that's how perfect that headscarf was for her, all by itself it gave her that totally exotic look like you were saying."

"I that's why I hate her. She doesn't have to try to look great. I guess it's that Mexican-Indian look she's got," she adds with a cluck of her tongue.

"She is half Hopi," you remind her.

"Well, here's half hoping she dies in a fire."

"Hannah!"

"I'm sorry. No, I take it back, I'm not. What is this?" Hannah asks as you unlock and open the door to the abandoned store front.

"It's the place. But what were you telling me about Dominique? What did she do today?"

"Oh, nothing. Just irritated the hell out of me." Hannah wrinkles her nose and clucks distastefully as you usher her into the dim, dusty room. "She wore that headscarf to school today, just to spite me, I think. I don't remember ever seeing her in it before, but today it was like every time I turned around I saw her out of the corner of my—" She trails off. "The hell, Catherine? Why'd you wanna come here instead of—?"

"Because I wanted to show you this." You pick up one of the masks. "I didn't want to take a chance on losing it in public." You hand it to her.

"What is it?"

"It's a mask, silly. A thing for Halloween. It needs some eyeholes punched into it, but otherwise it's, you know."

Hannah turns it over a couple of times. "Okay, it's pretty cool, I guess. But come on, let's get out of—"

"Try it on," you urge her. "I got it thinking it would suit your looks," you continue as she looks dubious. "With your hair—"

You press up close and put your arms around her to pull at her ponytail, loosening it and pulling the strands free. You're close enough that you can smell her breath—cinnamon. Your lips twitch into a smile. You weren't lying last night when, as Catherine, you confessed to Stephanie that you were only ever a few drinks away from making out with a girl. You'd love to make out with Hannah. To open your mouth and take hers in yours ...

You let go of her but you don't step back. "Try it on," you say. "Just put it up to your face." You grasp her wrists, and she only lightly resists as you push her hands to her face. "We'll take a picture and you'll see." You titter. "Maybe you'll look spooky enough we can send it around to freak out Dominique."

That turns the trick. Hannah lifts the mask to her face. It only touches it before it vanishes, and she sinks to the ground, taking you with her.

* * * * *

You had two good reasons for forcing a blank mask onto Hannah. One was that you wanted to knock her out so you could perform that spell on her. Probably you couldn't have talked her into it! And Stephanie would probably dig having a copy of her nemesis—a bonus on the kind of trouble she wanted you to do anyway.

But now you're really glad to have a copy of Hannah on hand. It turns out that spell was a lot hinkier than you were counting on.

So while she was knocked out, you lofted her onto one of the tables, pulled her clothes off her—and found she's got a bush down below that almost's as much of a jungle as the one atop her head—and dumped the rest of the ingredients on her. You almost backed out at the last moment when you went to set a flame to her, for you remembered how long it took to "cook" the lackey, and it would be bad—for lots of reasons!—if Hannah Westrick was spread out, on fire, for the next week in the empty storefront next to Argosy Furniture. But then you reminded yourself that surely this new spell wasn't going to be a duplicate of the previous spell.

Well, the good news is that Hannah wasn't on fire for more than half a minute, if even that. The bad news is that ... the new spell is pretty much otherwise a duplicate of the spell that made the lackey.

The difference is that it has turned Hannah into a lackey.

At least, that's what it looks like to you. You are cold with horror all over as you study her.

She is the same color as the lackey, for a start—an off-white, like a water-stained marble statue. She is also stiff all over, though maybe her flesh yields just the tiniest little bit when you push a fingertip into her. But from the tips of her toenails to the tips of her hair, she really does look like she's been transformed into a statue.

So it really is good that you've got a copy of her in the mask that you lifted off her face just before you put the match to her. All you have to do is put on the mask, put on the clothes, and Hannah Westrick can go home without anyone knowing anything happened to her. Or you can get your own lackey out here, put Hannah's mask on it and resume your own life. That would be quickest and easiest. And as for what to do with this thing you've made ...

You jump as the iPod touch chimes. It's a text from Stephanie: on my way twshop wehn u redy meet me thre.

Shit!

You can worry about Catherine later. Right now you need to keep this mess under wraps from Stephanie. You throw yourself onto the floor next to what's left of Catherine and jam the mask onto your face.

* * * * *

Your head is aching when you awake, and you're sick to your stomach with the cold. You glance around the dark room, wondering how you got on the floor and where Will Prescott scampered off to, but the confusion lasts only a moment. You rub your face and haul yourself to your feet. You squint at the blurry world and frown.

Then you think: My contacts.

You make a face, and gingerly touch and pluck at the surface of your eyeball. Catherine's used to it, thank God; you yourself have never touched an eyeball directly, neither your own nor someone else's. But it takes you only a few seconds to grimly conclude that Catherine's contacts did not transfer into your own eyes when you put the mask on. So where are they?

Your gaze falls upon the petrified Catherine Muskov. You bend over her face and peer into her eyes.

Something glints there, something you would have missed if you hadn't looked very closely.

Carefully, holding your breath, you pluck her lenses out of her petrified eyes. They are still pliable, but too stiff to put into your eyes. She didn't bring her book bag in with her, so you don't have any contact solution.

So you go looking for a restroom and a sink, which you find must off the Argosy back offices. You're rubbing your eyes, lubricating the water-wetted lenses with your own tears, when a voice behind you calls your name: "Catherine?"

You shriek, jump, and whirl. It's Stephanie, standing in the doorways. "Jesus," she says. "Calm down. Where's Will?"

You are breathing very heavily as you grip the sink behind you, and your heart is beating hard. In a whirl you wonder, Does Stephanie think I'm the real Catherine? Does she know that I called her out here? Does she actually know it's me, and what I did to her friend?

Stephanie frowns and snaps her fingers in your face. "Hey," she says. "You okay? You meet with Hannah yet?"

Hannah? Oh God! You let out a deep breath. She thinks you're the lackey!

"Oh, um, no, we weren't able to hook up," you say in a trembling voice. "We missed each other or something."

"Fuck." Stephanie puts her hands on her hips. "We can't try it again tomorrow," she mutters.

"We can't?" you gasp. "Maybe we could?"

"I don't know where to put you tonight. Shit." Stephanie sighs and falls silent.

You can't find anything to say, so you jog from foot to foot until she looks up again. "Where's Will?" she asks.

"Um, I think he's out looking for a parking space," you improvise. "He dropped me off, sent me in here to wait for you."

"Well, let's go put you away. We can't have you running around in case someone sees you." She gestures for you to follow.

To your horror, you realize she's leading you back to the abandoned storefront, where the real Catherine is splayed out on a table.

Five steps, ten steps, fifteen steps ... Your mind is a whirl-a-gig of terror as Stephanie advances on the door of doom. Words try to form in your throat, but you can't force them past a tongue that has gone thick and parched. Stephanie grasps the metal knob; a hoarse shout dies in your throat ...

The knob rattles but refuses to turn. Stephanie jerks at it again, then grunts. "Got the key?" she asks.

You almost faint, but retain enough presence of mind to pat at your pockets. "No," you lie. "Will forgot to give it to me."

"Never mind, I've got my own copy." Stephanie feels at her own pockets, then frowns and mutters. "In my bag," she says, and brushes past you back toward the furniture shop.

You grab her by the arm. "Wait, I'll go find Will. We need to get together anyway, right? Be right back." Before she can argue, you sprint off back the way you came.

At first you think that your doppelganger must have run off, when you don't see him behind the wheel of the truck. But it turns out that he's just ducked down in the cab, playing a mobile game on your phone, and he jumps as you throw yourself into the cab of the truck. "Hey babe," he smirks. "Got your thing done? 'Cos if you don't need me now, Caleb is talking about—"

"I need your clothes," you snap, "and your face, too. My face, I mean. Take your clothes off!" you order as he gapes at you. He jerks into motion as you crouch in the passenger-side foot well and pull off your top and bottoms. You look up when your double makes a weird groan, and find him ogling you hard. His cock is rising like the spar of sailing ship as he twists himself out of his pants. He squeaks as you loft yourself onto him, pressing your boobs against his chest, and he goes stiff all over as you grasp his face, mutter some arcane words, and pull.

When you settle back, there's a blob-like slab of rock bent between the driver's bench and the steering wheel. Your eye instinctively falls to the "crotch" of the thing, and are relieved to see that there's no bone-like spur sticking out of the thing's lap.

You settle back into the foot well, and pull at your own face.

* * * * *

You're woken by an insistent ringtone, and raise a muzzy head to look around. The world is a blur, and your eyes hurt as though they've been scratched and gouged. You rub at them with the heel of your hand, but that only makes it worse. You fumble at the lumpy clothes on the truck bench until you find your phone, wrapped in a shirt. You have to hold it out very far from your face before you can begin to make out the text on the screen: meet me n stor w kee, it seems to say.

Fuck. You'd much rather rack out in the truck for a few more minutes of sleep—maybe your eyes are hurting because the phone woke you up—but you hustle into your own clothes and hop out of the truck. You squint against the sunlight, and an unexpected car honks at you as you dash across the street.

"Will!" a voice shouts, and you spin. A blurry figure trots up to you, and she has to get quite close before you recognize Stephanie. "Didn't you see me?"

"Huh? Oh. Guess I had, uh—" You look around. Everything is a smeary blur, and you hope the blobs that are moving are people and not furniture. It feels like you've got something stuck in your eyes—

Oh yeah.

"Hey," Stephanie says, and she shakes you. "Pay attention."

"What?" you snap. You desperately want to get back into that bathroom so you can take Catherine's contacts out.

"I said, Where's Catherine?"

"Oh. I, uh, pulled the mask off the thing, left her— Uh, it, out in the truck."

"Well, put it back on her. It. We need to put it back in the storeroom. The place."

"I'll take care of it. Listen, just hang on a minute, I need to use the restroom." Without waiting for her to argue, you run off, caroming off the corners of sofas and tables as you stumble blindly into the back offices.

And after you're back out again, you find that Stephanie has vanished on you. With your heart in your throat you check the door to the abandoned store, but it's locked. Your relief is short-lived, though, when you return to the front of the furniture store and find Stephanie leading ... Catherine? ... back in through the front door.

"You got the key?" Stephanie asks you.

"The what?" you reply, trying not to swallow your own tongue.

"The key, Will, to the place." She rubs her nose and frowns. "Catherine went back to get it from you."

"Oh." You pat your pockets, which are empty. "No, they must have fallen out in the truck," you truthfully reply.

Stephanie rolls her eyes hard. "Fine. Just wait here, I'll go get my set from my bag." She turns on her heel.

You give the lackey a sidelong glance. It looks just like Catherine, and it's dressed in those same cast-off clothes that Stephanie gave to you, and if that's not enough to settle its identity, there's a greenish tinge behind the ghastly smile she turns on you. "What's going on?" she says. "I feel like I should be down at Stewart's Hole with all my friends, but I also feel like I should be—"

"Listen, you have a set of keys on you?" you ask. She pats her pockets, and pulls out the key to the abandoned storefront. "Trade you." You give her her contacts and take the key. "Go put your lenses in," you say as you push her toward the back. "Close the door and lock it and don't come out until I tell you." Your heart is racing, but you think you finally see a way out of this farce.

You're loitering out front when Stephanie strides back in with a very determined expression on her face. "Oh," you tell her with studied casualness. "I found my key after you left and I put the lackey back. We're all good."

Stephanie grunts. "Except she didn't get to talk to Hannah."

"Well, that was a cock up," you agree. "You want to try again tomorrow?"

"I think we need to just give up on it. No offense, Will, but this magic shit you found is more trouble than it's worth."

You're actually inclined to agree, but you keep quiet.
