1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.content:
Carmona and Miller are willing to along with your idea for infiltrating the high school using masks, but they've accepted it with something like a brusque determination. Miller, particularly, has the unhappy expression of someone who's being swept up in something she doesn't quite approve of.

But it's Carmona—a leather-skinned rugby player and a 4.0-point honors student back at Putnam—who takes charge of the planning.

"So if I get this right," he says, "we're going to need, what, six masks? One for each of us to wear, and one to put on the poor assholes we're gonna be impersonating?"

You nod. "Plus the stuff we need to make the, uh, enchantment to put on those other masks."

"How much is it gonna set us back?"

"No idea," you confess. "I'd have to make up a list and go to the store. But I don't think the masks are going to cost us more than sixty or seventy dollars." You don't mention that your estimate is based on experience. "The other stuff, I don't know."

Carmona grunts and checks the time. "We already owe on tonight's room rental. But if we get started tonight, maybe we can check out tomorrow. I don't want to sleep on the street if we need the rest of our cash stash to pay for the stuff."

You pull out a piece of paper and start jotting down a shopping list.

* * * * *

It would save time but cost too much in cab fare to split up and hit multiple shops at once. You split the difference instead, taking into one cab around town, dropping each of you off at a different store or district while the others race ahead to the next stop. After leaving Carmona downtown and Miller at the mall, and you hit a shopping center on the west side, then head down to the Masonic cemetery to scoop a few pounds of dirt from off a grave. (This necessary stop you haven't mentioned to the others; you're not sure Miller can hold herself together if you told her that necromancy might be involved.) Then you circle back around town to pick up the others, who are patiently waiting at the agreed upon meeting places, the return to the motel. When all is said and done, the cab ride is the most expensive item in the ledger.

Casting the masks will stink up the place, so you take the stuff outside to an empty lot behind the motel, where crumbling patches of a cement foundation peep out between the stiff weeds, stickers, and trash. You huddle around the burner to hide your work, so you all get a face-full of the noxious smoke. Once is enough for Miller, who retreats to stand a few yards off with her shirt pulled up over her nose and mouth, but Carmona gets in and gets his hands dirty alongside you as you cast the other five masks. Back inside, Carmona polishes up the masks with a car buffer while you and Miller carve runes into the metal bands that will copy the memories and personalities of the people you'll be impersonating.

And who will those be? It doesn't take long for you and Carmona (Miller keeps quiet) to settle on using teachers at Westside as your infiltration point.

It makes the most sense. As teachers you'll have uninhibited access to the school, before and after classes, and will be able to move through it unmolested. You'll have access to lots of different classes with lots of different students to investigate. You'll be able to pull students aside and isolate them. And as adults, you'll have money and independence.

Getting to the teachers, though, is going to be a problem. Not until the next morning, when Carmona with a vexed sigh, says he's going to go for a run, does it come to you how you can corner and isolate one.

* * * * *

"Do we need to check in with the main office?" Carmona asks as the three of you stride across the student parking lot toward Westside High. It gives you a weird kind of deja vu to be back here. On the one hand, nothing could be more familiar than the sight of the blue-and-white walls of the gym and drama wing that loom up in front of you. On the other, you're conscious that's it's been almost two months since you've been here, and that you're returning under an alias. "Will?" Carmona repeats when you (too wrapped up in your thoughts) don't immediately reply.

"Huh? No. Not unless you want the administration to know they got a couple of strangers on campus."

"Don't you got security that's going to stop us?"

"Pff. No. There's one old guard that putters around the front doors, but it's an open campus, and anyone can get in and out."

Carmona snorts at that.

The shout of voices and the squeak of shoes erupts as you pull open the double doors to the gym. Carmona pauses in the vestibule to study the display case of trophies and team photographs—going all the way back to the seventies—before following you to the left into one of the gym courts. A pack of students—freshmen, it looks like— in t-shirts and shorts is jogging around the perimeter under the watchful eye of Coach Puente. You catch her glancing in your direction as you lead your friends over to the mezzanine, but she doesn't call or stop you.

Atop the mezzanine, which separates the two basketball courts, is the weights area, but within it are the offices of the P.E. staff. That's the idea that came to you back at the motel. Most of the P.E. teachers will out with their classes, but those with a free period will be isolated, in their office, in a building that is itself cut off from the rest of the school.

Silently your trio pad down the central corridor, glancing at the names on the doors as you pass: Coach Brooks, Coach Gossett, Coach Carter, Coach Gellman. You stop in front of the latter door to try the handle. Locked. That's too bad. He's the soccer coach, and under his identity you could get to Andrew Webb.

Only two doors are open. The first belongs to Coach Tesla, and you quickly pull Carmona and Miller past it. Beggars can't be choosers, but none of you, you're sure, would want to impersonate that baggy-faced toad-lady. Instead, you push on to the very end of the corridor, where a crack of light spills out from behind the half-open door of Coach Puente's office. You push it open and peer inside.

The coach is sitting at her desk, bent toward her open laptop and tapping the keyboard with such furious concentration that she doesn't even notice you. She's a Hispanic woman of about thirty, you'd guess, with mocha-colored skin and black hair that falls in a straight line to just below her shoulders. She's wearing a blue spandex top that binds itself tightly to her boobs.

You motion behind for one of your compatriots to hand you a mask. The gesture must have caught the coach's attention, for she looks up with a start.

You grin at her. "Ay! Coach Puente!" you exclaim, doing your best to imitate Dane Matthias's goofball personality. "You remember me!" You feel the sweat pop out on your forehead as she only stares at you. "Dane! Matthias! The Danester! You had me, uh, freshman year in P.E.!" (You've no idea if she did.) "I came back to say hi!"

"Hi Dane," she says, and still she doesn't blink. "Can I help you?" Her brow furrows as she peers past you. "Did you graduate?"

"Nah, I changed schools. Din'cha hear? I got packed off to a military school!" You snap your fingers behind your back, and someone finally pushes a mask into your hand. "This is my Thanksgiving break, so I came back to check in and say hi to people!" You saunter up to her desk.

She pulls back fractionally, and her expression tightens. "That's great, Dane," she says. "But—"

You wheel onto Carmona and Miller. "Shut the door, okay, so we can have some privacy?" you tell them. Miller is very pale, and she stumbles a little as she turns to push the door shut. When you turn back around again, the coach is also looking alarmed.

"Look, I need your help," you tell her as you lean across her desk. She pulls away as you put a knee up on it and stretch yourself toward her. "There's some bad dudes on the loose in Westside and we need—"

She ducks her face as you thrust the mask at her, and you fall forward, losing your balance. But your blow lands true, and your fingers grasp her forehead as the mask dissolves into her face.

"We need one of us to be you," you conclude with a murmur as you recover yourself. The coach, her disordered hair draping over her face, slumps and slides onto the floor. Miller backs into a far corner of the room, and in a frightened, bird-like chirp, mutters "Oh my God oh my God oh my God!" over and over until Carmona silences her with a sharp word.

You step around the desk and bend down to straighten out Coach Puente's prone body. Below the waist, you find, she's dressed in blue athletic shorts, ankle socks, and sneakers. Her flesh is warm and soft to the touch.

"What happens now?" Carmona asks as he bends over you and the coach.

"We wait for the mask to copy her, then we seal it up and switch places with her." You've already made masks and brain-bands for Carmona and Miller, and Dane's mask has a band copying your own brain and personality inside. Those masks are also coated with the special sealant that puts them under the control of you and your friends, so that you can turn the coach and the two other impersonations into obedient copies of yourselves that you can send back to Putnam.

"So who puts it on?" Carmona asks, and he glances over his shoulder at Miller. She has her hands over her nose and mouth, and looks like she's trying hard not to hyperventilate.
1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.title: To Teach His Own

1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.content:
Coach Puente should be knocked out for about ten minutes. But Miller looks like she's going to throw up right now.

In three steps you're by her side with your arm around her. "Are you okay?" you ask.

She gulps and nods. But then she shakes her head, and sags against you.

"The coach is okay," you assure her. "She's just knocked out. I mean, asleep."

"Kind of a rough thing, though," Carmona says. He stalks over to the office door and pushes it shut. "You look like you got practice at this, man."

Miller shrinks up inside your embrace, and in that moment you could almost kill your roommate.

"I told you I did some stupid shit," you snipe at him over your shoulder. "But this is all about putting it right, you know?" You turn back to Miller. "You said you were going to help," you murmur. An ache starts to spread through your chest when she doesn't reply. This is too much for her, you think. And maybe her horror is infectious, because you feel yourself getting nauseated as well.

"Look," you say when the silence has gotten oppressive, "if this is too much for you, you don't have to help. We— Tim and I'll handle it. You can hang out at— at whatever place we wind up crashing."

"That's right," Carmona says. "You can fly back out to Putnam. Will and I'll stay here and take care of things."

You feel Miller tensing. "It'll be okay," you tell her again.

"We need to do any more prep work?" Carmona asks. He's now squatting beside the prostrate coach.

"No. Just need to— Well, we'll need to strip her. And I guess we can rock-paper-scissor to see who puts on the mask." You put out your fist. "On three. One, two— Whatsamatter?" you ask as Carmona stares at you from under a sharply cocked eyebrow.

"Oh, Jeez Lou-eeze!" Miller suddenly snorts and pushes you away, to stalk over to where Carmona is crouching. "Keep your hands off her. I'll undress her myself."

"Hey!" Carmona backs up. "I know my way around a female's—"

"Shut up!" Miller slaps him in the back of the head. "Coupla perverts is what you guys are." She kneels next to Coach Puente. "I'll take her clothes off. And I'll put the mask on. You pervs turn around. Or go find a bathroom or someplace to hide out in till I'm done." With something like ferocity she starts tugging the shoes off the coach's feet.

You and Carmona exchange a wondering glance. "I told you," you start to say, "you don't have to—"

"I said I'd stay and help, okay? What, suddenly you don't want me around? I can handle it if you two per— assholes can!" She mutters under her breath.

Carmona sucks in his cheeks, shoves his hands into his pockets, and gives you a look as Miller starts tugging at the coach's shorts. But he doesn't say anything, and neither do you.

And Miller—being one-hundred-thousand-percent invested in showing that she's as much of a badass as you and Carmona—concentrates on stripping Coach Puente down to her underthings, and neither speaks nor lifts her face until she's done.

* * * * *

Perverts or not, you and Carmona stay with her the whole time. You, to supervise the final touches to the coach's mask when it comes out of her, and Carmona to— Well, probably to ogle the naked coach and to annoy Miller with his presence. She finally throws him out, though, when you announce that Miller herself will need to strip down so that her duplicate can take her clothes.

"You can stay, Will," she says as you start to follow Carmona out the door. "You know, to make sure I do this right."

"You'll do fine."

"I want you to stay." There's steel in her voice, and as Carmona edges out the door he gives you the kind of look one guy gives to another when he thinks he might be seeing his friend alive for the last time. The door clicks shut behind him with the snicker-snack of a falling guillotine blade.

Miller's face is blotchy with patches of rose and chalk, and her hair, though still done up in its tiny bun, looks windswept. She's got her hands on her hips, and her lips are compressed so tightly they've disappeared.

"Will," she says. You nod when she doesn't continue. She blinks. Then she looks away. "Oh, nothing," she grumbles.

"No, you can tell me."

"It's nothing." She glares into a corner of the room, and takes a deep breath. "I just can't believe we're doing this."

"I told you, you don't have to."

"That's not the point!" She swings sharply onto you. "It's this!" She flings her hand at the unconscious coach, and at the finished mask now sitting on the corner of the desk. "It's what we're doing! It's what you're doing!" A shadow flashes across her throat as she swallows. "It's what you did."

"You mean, what I'm doing right now." You point to your face, which is starting to burn.

She nods, and her expression lengthens.

"I thought you were really sweet," she says. "Oh, hell, I know that you're really sweet. And with your ... your thing. You know." She gestures vaguely at her own face. "It made you sweeter, somehow. I thought you were like the frog prince or whoever in the fairy tale. The Beast in Beauty and the Beast." Her expression turns pinched. "You know. Like it wasn't your fault."

You feel an ache in your own throat.

"But you did it to yourself," she continues.

"You knew that."

"I know! Only this made it real. What you did to the coach. The way you—" She bites her lip.

"Like I had a lot of practice," you finish for her.

She nods. It hurts to see her being so honest. But you're glad, too. It gets things out in the open. "It's okay," she starts to say, but you interrupt her.

"But it isn't. Me and Caleb were being really stupid, just goofing off. And then we panicked. I panicked. But now it's worse than anything, probably, and I have to fix it." Your face feels very heavy, like it's going to slide off the front of your skull, as you confess your stupidities and perversities.

"I know," she says, sounding as grave as you feel. "That's why I'm going along with it. Why I'm going to help."

"Thanks."

"Oh, Will," she sighs, but she smiles a wry smile too. "You are sweet. Sweet and stupid." She grabs you in a hug. "That's how come you're in this trouble."

"And you're gonna help me out. 'Cos you're smart and tough."

"That's right." She punches you lightly in the kidney. "Someone's got to keep an eye on you and Carmona so you don't get into trouble. Okay?" She sighs after giving you one last squeeze. "So what comes next?"

* * * * *

Miller crouches down behind the desk where you can't see her, and drops her clothes one article at a time onto the desk top. When she's done, you hand her the mask of herself that you made back at the motel, then scramble back against the far wall. Your heart in your throat, you wait to see the results.

It starts with a rustle and a murmuring from behind the desk. Then there's a strained cry of "Oh jeez!" and "Oh my God!" and a squeak. You can't tell for sure, but it might be two voices rather than one.

Then Miller says, "Will?" You edge up to the desk, going up on tiptoes to peer over the top as two heads peep out at you. "I think it worked," one of the girls says in a strangled voice.

"Miller?"

"Yes," two voices say in unison. They exchange uneasy glances.

"Okay, Miller, the real Miller? You have to be the boss. I mean, you are the boss. But you have to act like it."

"Do I have to?"

But the other Miller slaps at the one who spoke. "He's talking to me, you ... Fake!" The first one drops her eyes. "How do I do that?"

"I think you just did. Tell it to get dressed."

"Get dressed," Miller says (though she sounds uncertain). "My clothes. I put them up on—"

"I remember where I put them!" A hand jumps out to pull Miller's clothes off the desk. "And they're my clothes too, you now."

"Only for now. Oh, God!" There's a sound of scrambling from behind the desk. "Tell me when you're done! I don't want to look!"

"What's wrong?" you ask.

"It's gross looking at her!"

"Ditto," says the other.

"You're the ditto!"

"Just get dressed," you snap. "Miller, get the coach's mask. It's on top of the—" A hand shoots up and fumbles across the top of the desk. "Yeah, there. It's all ready, just put it on. By the time you wake up, your ditto will be dressed."

"I wish you wouldn't call me that," the other Miller says. It has its shirt on now, and it stands up. The hair is tumbling about its shoulders, which adds to the distress evident on its face. "You know, Will, things were really nice there, between us, until—"

"Just finish getting dressed," you order it. It makes a face back at you, but complies. "You're a fake, don't forget."

"I don't feel like a fake," it says.

You can't help swallowing. It doesn't look like a fake, either, and it sounds just like your girlfriend. When it steps out from behind the desk, it takes all your willpower to remember that it's not.

"Go sit out on the bleachers," you tell it roughly, when what you really want to do is pull it to yourself.
1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.title: The Miller's Tale

choices: Use the mask on this intruder
1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.content:
Should I stay or leave until after Miller's changed? you ask yourself. You forgot to ask before she put on Coach Puente's mask. You huddle on the far side of the corner, with the coach's desk hiding sight of Miller, as you agonize with indecision.

Before you can decide, there's a tap at the door, and Carmona looks in. "Is it safe?" he asks in a low voice.

"Yeah, come on in," you tell him. "Miller just put the mask on. She's going to be out for a while."

"How long?"

"Five, ten minutes. I think."

He gives you a sober look. "Can we wake her up?"

"She hasn't got any clothes on."

"Jesus." Carmona wipes his palms on his jeans, and glances over his shoulder into the hall. "I told the, uh—" He licks his lips with a white tongue. "The other Miller to go wait out in the parking lot. It's freaky, man." He shakes his head. "Uncanny valley."

"I thought she seemed normal."

He gives you a quick look. "Too normal. It was weird thinking it wasn't her."

You nod. That's the reason you sent it out of the office.

"What about us?" Carmona asks. "You got some people picked out for you and me?"

"No, I'm just winging it. I'm kind of hoping that, uh, Miller'll be able to pick us out something good."

"Is she married?"

"Who? Miller?"

"No, dumbass. The person she's—"

"Oh. I don't know." The question suddenly alarms you. "Jesus, if she is—"

"If she is," Carmona starts to say, then lapses into a miserable silence. "Oh, forget it. But if she is, better her than me."

It doesn't sound like what he was originally going to say, but you skip it. "You didn't want to be the one to put on the mask," you accuse him. "Did you?"

"Not my thing. Gonna be weird, putting on someone else's skin."

"You put on Dane's mask."

"Yeah, but that was just goofing around back at Putnam. Besides—"

Oh, God, you mutter to yourself. I'm gonna get the same speech from Carmona as I got from Miller. "I know," you Interrupt him with a sigh. "This is all real sketchy, I'm a dumbass for getting everything fucked up this way. But we're doing this to fix things."

"Oh, I know," Carmona says. "I just want you to promise me you'll fix me up so I still have a schlong. Okay?"

Oh, you now think. Is that all his problem is?

You lapse into a silence, one that lasts until there's a low groan from behind the desk. You wait for the sound of someone moving before you call out. "Miller?" Carmona goes up on tiptoes and tries to peer over the top of the desk.

"Yes?" comes a voice.

"You okay?"

"I guess. I feel like— Oh, God!"

"What's wrong? Miller?" you call again when she doesn't answer.

"I'm fine. Only these aren't my fingers! And this isn't my—"

A head pops up from behind the desk. It's got long, straight dark hair, and eyes that are wide with astonishment. There's a pallor beneath the brown tan of Coach Puente's face.

"Does everything work?" Carmona asks.

"What?" Puente's brow furrows. "What do you mean by—? Does my voice sound funny?" She covers her mouth with the tips of her fingers.

Does it? It doesn't sound like Miller, not exactly. The timbre is throatier and raspier. But do you detect a trace of Miller's nasal Wisconsin twang? "How's your head?" you ask.

"Got a touch of a headache. I feel like I woke up too fast from a really deep sleep." She touches her temple and shakes her head. "Rrng. I wonder if she's got any Tylenol in her desk." Distractedly, she starts pulling open drawers.

"Well, think about it," you suggest. "You should be able to get her memories if you try."

Puente pauses and frowns. Then she shakes her head. "Brain still feels fried. I wanna take a nap."

"You got classes and you need to get Puente's brain engaged."

"You could start by getting dressed," Carmona suggests.

Puente makes a face. "You guys get a good enough look while I was conked out?"

"We didn't even peek, Miller," you retort. "Come one, give us a little credit."

"Alright," she grumbles. "Just give me a minute." Her face disappears, but the crown of her head bobs into a view a few time as she fumbles about behind the desk. Arms fly up into the air as she pulls her shirt on, and she hefts herself into her office chair to put on her shoes and socks.

"Okay," she puffs when she's done. "How do I look?" She stands up.

You didn't realize Coach Puente was so short. Well, she's not short, but in your mind's eye all teachers, especially the P.E. coaches, are taller than you.

But she looks very fit as she comes around the desk. Her shorts are very short and so are her socks, so that there's lots of strong, milk-chocolate leg to ogle. Her top is very form-fitting, and— Well, dammit, her breasts are a lot bigger than Miller's, and the spandex lifts, sculpts and pumps up those assets.

Neither you nor Carmona can speak, something neither of you notice until Miller, with a frown, says, "I'm asking if I can pass as this coach lady, guys. And my eyes are up here."

"Yeah, you look fine," you croak.

"You have her for P.E.?"

"Nope." You did see Coach Puente around the gym during your freshman and sophomore years, when you were forced to take a P.E. class, but your hatred of the gym was such that nothing connected to it, not even Coach Puente, looked inviting.

"How long till I have to teach a class?" the new coach asks.

"I dunno her schedule," you confess. You glance at a clock on her desk. "Probably fifteen minutes, though."

Her face falls. "Jeez. I better get started on remembering things!" She perches on the edge of the desk, and lowers her face to stare at her shoes.

* * * * *

But her face is pale when the bell rings, and there's fear in her eyes. She's got nothing, she tells you. Not a clue about this woman she's pretending to be.

The three of you have a hurried conference while trying to ignore the rumble of feet in the hallway outside. Miller can't go out and pretend to be Coach Puente without the memories—if she's spotted by any asshole sophomores pretending to be other people—the appearance of an amnesiac teacher will instantly tip your hand to them. But there isn't any time to check the mask for defects.

It's something like panic that sends you caroming off in a desperate direction. You escort Miller to the front office, where she crisply announces to the secretary at the front desk that she's taken ill and is going to have to take the rest of the day off. The flustered secretary tries to stop her, but she strides out without getting caught.

Carmona meets you in the teacher's parking lot with the coach's purse and computer bag, and using her keys you're able to hunt down her car—a minivan—which you all pile in to. It's a disorganized retreat you make from Westside, so disorganized that you have to go back to the school and swing into the student parking lot to pick up the fake Miller, who you had forgotten in your flight. On the other side of the river you pull into the parking lot of a strip mall and consult the coach's driver's license for her home address while ignoring the insistent buzzing on her cell phone.

She lives, you find, in a modest apartment complex on the west side of town. A cat greets you on opening the door, but it scuttles out of sight as you and the others follow the transformed coach inside. The place is clean, but there's a musty odor in the air, as of unwashed laundry.

A quick search turns up two bedrooms—one converted into a study—two bathrooms, a small kitchen and smaller dining area, and a cozy living room. The furniture is faded and dumpy, and the dining table looks second-hand, but there's a large, flat-screen TV, and the office contains not only a desktop computer but another laptop.

There's a queen-size bed in the bedroom.

Anxiously, you all scan the photographs on the walls for evidence about Coach Puente's life choices. There are a couple of framed photos that you assume show her parents, and one that shows a much younger coach—high school age?—in a cluster of girls and boys. But there are no photos that show her as one of a couple.

"Let's check that mask," you tell Miller in the bedroom. "I can't believe I messed anything up."

"You think it's my fault?" she retorts, sounding peevish and tired.

"No. I don't know what's going on. But we need to—" You break off as her phone buzzes again. You need to just turn it off.

But you freeze as you reach for the coach's face. From the other end of the apartment comes a dreadful sound: that of the front door opening. "Beatriz?" a male voice calls out.

The three of you exchange looks of horror. Coach Puente's husband?

There's a walk-in closet that you and Carmona could hide in while Miller gets rid of him. But suppose she can't?

You've also got two blank masks. You intend to use them on teachers, and this is probably not a teacher. But—

"Beatriz!" whoever it is calls again, sounding impatient.

—this is a desperate moment.
1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.title: The Punt

choices: Lure Coach Schell out to be replaced
1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.content:
"Beatriz!" The intruder calls out a third time.

"Answer him!" you hiss at the girl who looks like Coach Puente.

She pales. "But I don't know who—"

"Doesn't matter! Just get him back here!"

"I'm back in the bedroom!" Puente calls out in a quavering voice as you dive for the sack that carries your gear. You pull out one of the blank masks.

"Didn't you hear me calling?" the stranger calls back. He sounds surly.

Puente's jaw work soundlessly until Carmona nudges her and points at the bathroom door. "I— I was in the bathroom!" she calls out. "Uh, come on back!" she adds after you poke her. Carmona springs over to hide behind the bedroom door. You run over to hand him the blank mask before diving into the bathroom, dragging the fake Tess Miller in with you. You push the door shut until it's open by just a crack.

There's a mutter and murmur of voices outside, and the heavy tramp of footsteps. "Why aren't you checking your texts?" the guy asks. It sounds like he's just on the other side of the door.

"I guess I had my phone turned off," Puente stammers.

"Well, I got hauled into the office by— Rrfff!"

There's a soft thump and a thud, and a hard gasp from Puente. Your heart jackhammers in your chest. You grip the knob of the bathroom door, but don't pull on it until you hear Carmona call your name in a ragged voice. "It's okay, you can come out."

You pull the door open.

A figure lays in a crumpled hump of clothing and limbs on the bedroom floor. It hardly looks human, just a tangle of dirty Levis and a camouflage jacket. The hair is thick and dark as coffee, and the skin on the back of his neck is even darker than Coach Puente's.

"Any idea who he is?" you ask.

"No!" Puente collapses onto the bed and grabs her temples. "I don't know anything, Will! And what are we going to do now?"

"Same thing we did with the coach." You nudge the prone figure with your toe. "There's your schlong, bro," you tell Carmona.

"But he's not a teacher! Is he?" Puente protests.

You push the dude over with your foot. He has a dark beard, thick but close-shorn. Under the unbuttoned camo jacket is a white t-shirt with food stains all down its front.

"I don't recognize him," you admit.

"Fuck," Carmona says. "Check for ID." He squats to search the man's pockets. "Matias Puente," he reads off the driver's license that he extracts from a wallet. "Different home address," he adds after studying it further. "Maybe her brother?" He squints up at Miller.

"We'll know for sure after one of us puts on the mask," you say.

"How do you know the masks are working?" Puente protests. "You said I was supposed to know what this teacher knows, but I—"

"We know they're working," you retort, and point at the fake Miller, who has been silently following you all around all this time. "Look at this girl here. Hey, what's your roommate's name, back at Putnam?" you ask her.

"Courtenay Philips," the fake Miller replies with a pinched look. She edges back a step. "Can I go sit in the car or something? This is all way too weird."

"See?" you tell Puente. You point to her face. "Whatever's wrong— Well, soon as we take care of this guy we'll try figuring out what's wrong with your set up."

"Let's do that now," Puente says. She hops backward on the bed and grabs her face, smushing it up. "Can you get it off me?"

"Sure thing." You climb onto the bed and prop yourself over her so you can get a grip on her face.

But you pause before making a move. It gives you a funny feeling—a pleasurable feeling—to hover over her like this. You've never been in or on a bed with her, but as you look down at her and she looks up at you, you can't help feeling like this could or should be the prelude to an intimate moment.

So when you touch her face, it's a caress rather than a grip.

"I'm sorry about all this, Miller," you murmur at her. "I didn't want any of this to happen."

"It's okay, Will," she says, and smiles tightly at you. "I'm sorry I'm not doing it right."

You smile back at her, then place your fingers around her temple and pull.

* * * * *

"Oh, fuck," you mutter as you sit up. "Mother of God." You squeeze your head between your hands. All this taking off and putting on of faces is getting really old.

First you pulled Beatriz Puente's mask off of Miller and put it on yourself, while Carmona put on the mask of her brother. (Yes, it's her younger brother who busted in on you.) You woke up not only with all of Beatriz's memories, but for almost half a minute you were convinced you were Beatriz Puente and couldn't figure out why these strangers were in your bedroom with you. Carmona, though, had no clue as to who Matias was other than what you (as Beatriz) were able to tell him. The same thing was true of Miller when you transferred Matias's mask onto her, and Carmona couldn't get any of Beatriz's memories when he put on her mask. (Meanwhile, a fake version of Carmona is now sitting in Beatriz's living room with the fake version of Miller.)

Finally it was your turn to put on Matias's mask. You are presently suffering a brief migraine as you try to squeeze two sets of memories—yours and his—into one compact and manageable ball. "Oh, fuck," you groan again.

"Any luck?" Carmona.

"Sure, all bad. God damn it."

Carmona and Miller exchange a brief glance. "It doesn't work for you?" she asks.

"No, it does. Son of a bitch." You drag yourself up onto your feet and shake your head clear. A hard shiver runs through you as the last of Matias Puente's memories click into place, giving you full control over everything he can think or do. "Wish I knew what the fucking deal was."

The fucking deal, apparently, is that the masks work just fine for you, but don't work for your two partners.

"And the bitch of it is," you grumble, "I don't got time now to figure it out." Instinctively you feel at your pockets for your cell phone, only to discover that you're still wearing your own clothes, not Matias's. "I gotta get back up to the school."

"The school?" Miller asks, sounding alarmed. "What for?"

"My job. Lobo here works in the cafeteria." The new memories and the knowledge are so vivid and clear that it almost gives you vertigo as you hurtle through them. "He got called in to the office when the coach ran out. She wasn't answering her phone, so Sagansky sent him over to see what's wrong." You cock your head and pick up Beatriz's mask. "I s'pose I could tell 'em she's throwing her guts up all over the bathroom. That still doesn't settle what to do about her tomorrow, though."

Worried glances are exchanged around your small, three-person circle.

"Okay, look, I gotta go back up to the school, cover for Matias," you say. "I can do him, an' we don't want both of 'em disappearing. But you guys stay here— Beatriz don't got a boyfriend or nothing, ain't no one gonna come bustin' in on you 'cept me. You should put her mask on again, though," you tell Miller. "Try concentratin' on gettin' some of her memories and shit. Look around the place. Maybe something'll knock something loose. I'll be back over sometime tonight."

"Tonight?" Miller echoes. "Not after school?"

"Got another job I need to cover. God damn it. Six hour shift at the IHOP. What?" you ask as you notice them both giving you strange looks.

"You're not talking like yourself, Will," Carmona says. "You've got an accent, and you're not— You just don't sound like you usually do."

You only snort. "So I guess I'm talkin' like Matias here. But I gotta split." You pat a pocket, looking for a cigarette. "Gotta change first, though," you mutter to yourself.

* * * * *

You chain smoke three cigarettes on the drive back over to Westside in Matias Puente's beat up van. (The faded logo of the pool cleaning service he bought the old junker off is still faintly visible under the coating of gray paint he got a friend to spray over it.) Everything's turning out a lot harder, a lot more complicated, than you'd planned. Sure, you managed to swap places with one of the teachers, but no one except you can seem to get into her memories to play her part. And now, at the moment, you're trapped in the body of a cafeteria cook who has no access to any of the students at Westside.

Was it this hard for Andrew Webb and his friends?

You park in the staff lot and make a quick stop in the office to report on Beatriz Puente's condition—"She's real sick, looks like food poisoning"—before trudging back into the cafeteria to resume your Matias's place at the hot stove, prepping gloppy food for the lunchtime crowd. Matias's absence has slowed things down, and the other cooks have had to work even harder to not fall back even further, and you get lots of surly looks and curses.

But either your luck is changing, or you are being tempted to double down on disaster, when as you take a smoke break in back of the school once the lunch rush is over you look up at the sound of your new name, and see Cathy Schell approaching.

You toss the cigarette away. A gorgeous blonde P.E. coach like Coach Schell won't like seeing a guy smoke. "I heard Beatriz got food poisoning," she tells you.

"Yeah, we think so. She'll be okay, though."

"Does she need me to bring anything over?"

Your heart leaps. Here's a chance to make another replacement.

Then it sinks. Here's a chance to make another fuck up.

* Lure Coach Schell out to be replaced.
* Hold back for now.
1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.title: One Hot Mess

Use masks on both Ava Price and Reagan Hackett
Use a mask only on the sophomore
Use a mask only on the senior
1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.content:
Cathy Schell. P. E. coach. You've seen her around. You've seen her talking and hanging out with your sister. And God. Damn. Is she hot!

Okay, that's Matias Puente talking. But he speaks for you, too. Just at a louder volume.

Cathy Schell is trim, compact, and stacked. Legs that work a Stairmaster every day; tits like torpedoes. She's dressed now in blue shorts and a white t-shirt; the red lanyard draped across her chest is like a neon arrow pulling your eyes down to her chest. Her blonde hair falls in two great waves to the top of her shoulders.

"Yeah, Beatriz got a touch of ptomaine or somethin'," you tell her as you wrench your gaze up to meet hers. "She was pukin' her guts up all over the bathroom when I went in to see her."

"Oh my God!" Coach Schell's chest heaves with concern, and your eyes go to her boobs again. "Does she need to go to the doctor?"

"Nah, she said it came on sudden like. She just needs to get the shit outta her system. You should stop by and see her, though," you add with a thumping heart. "She'd like that."

"I wouldn't want to bother her."

"No, she'd wanna see you," you assure her. "You could do us both a favor, actually. She asked me to pick up a few things at the store for her, but I got another job I gotta get to right after I leave here. Could you—?"

Coach Schell nods and says she'll be happy to help.

* * * * *

"Another one?" Beatriz protests when you get back to her place and tell her what you've got in mind. "We can't even get these masks to work!"

"They work for me," you remind her. You're perched on the sofa by the front window, watching through a crack between the curtains for Coach Schell. "I can't do any good as Matias here, I'm stuck back in the kitchen all day and then I got other jobs. Coach Schell's inside the school, she's as good as Coach Puente." Better, you add to yourself. Sexier.

"So why don't you put on Coach Puente's mask, take over here?" Beatriz insists. "I'm not doing any good with it."

"You still not getting any of the memories? You trying?" You glance back when you're answered by only a doubtful silence. "Well?"

"Well, maybe I am getting something," she admits. "I'm getting deja vu kind of hard." She glances around.

"There you go. Maybe it'll come."

"So how come—?" That's Carmona sauntering in from the kitchen with half a sandwich and a glass of milk. "So how come you can get into character, Will, instantly, and for us it takes—?"

"Beats me, pendejo. Sorry," you add when Carmona frowns. "I guess I get in character fast and deep." You try not to notice the veiled glances that Carmona and Beatriz exchange. "But look," you tell Miller, "if in the morning you still got trouble with Beatriz's memories and stuff, I'll take over for her."

"Then what happens to this other coach if we—? Who would—?"

"She can miss a day. Tomorrow's last day of school before break, she can take an absence. Then we got the holiday to figure out how to handle it."

But you've already outlined a potential scheme to yourself. That spell that enchants the masks, putting them under a magician's control? You've set it up so each of you gets one mask to control—each of you controls the mask of yourself. But are you really limited to controlling just one mask? Nothing in the spell says that you are. If you can control more than one mask, then you could turn Beatriz Puente and Cathy Schell both into puppets, and move between them. And if that works, you wouldn't need Carmona or Miller inside the school with you, doing impersonations. You could handle all the impersonations yourself. But you haven't suggested this idea to them yet, as you've worried they might freak out at the idea of turning lots of people into puppets.

"Okay, here she is," you announce a few minutes later, when you glimpse Cathy Schell, a grocery sack in her arm, getting out of a car. You hop away from the window. "You bring her inside," you instruct Beatriz, "take her into the kitchen, keep her back to the doorway. Carmona and me'll come in and get her from behind."

Your girlfriend nods unhappily.

* * * * *

It's disorienting at first when you wake again, but you quickly get yours situated, even though you're naked, in bed, in Beatriz Puente's bedroom. But even though it's a lovely feeling to sit up with Cathy Schell's boobs hanging off your chest, you don't waste time playing with yourself, for Miller is sitting on the edge of the bed, watching you with a hooded expression.

"Does it work?" she asks. "The mask?"

"Yes." You squeeze your temples between your hands. "I just wish I didn't get a migraine every time I took one of these things off and put one on. Was it like that for you, with Beatriz's mask?"

She shakes her head. "No, I just felt funny when I woke up, like my body was all weird." She pauses. "Is it because you get all the memories at once, that you get a headache?"

"I think so." You have a truly bewildering array of thoughts flicking through your head, like a TV zipping through a hundred channels at once. Only after you stagger to your feet do things start to settle down. "At least it doesn't last long. Hand me my things, could you?"

Beatriz Puente hands over underwear and bra, then the gym clothes. You try not to feel self-conscious as you dress in front of her.

"What about Thomas Luna?" she asks in a tone of studied casualness.

"Who?" It takes you a moment to place the name. But when it comes rushing in, you sit back down hard on the bed. "Oh!"

"Uh huh." Beatriz's tone is very dry.

"Who told you about him and, uh, Cathy?" Him and me is what you almost said.

"No one. I told you think I'm starting to get the memories in the mask." She doesn't look happy as she says it. "I was just sitting here, looking at you, and all of a sudden I thought how Cathy and Thomas are—"

"Look, don't remind me, okay?" You stand back up again. "It's vivid for me. And I got more to remember." You can't help flinching as you think of the guidance counselor's hairy cock worming its way up your cunny—and at the intensely pleasurable thrill it gives Cathy Schell to have him pumping away inside her. "Don't be jealous," you snap at her.

"I'm not jealous. I was just thinking we could make a mask of him," Beatriz says. "Give it to Carmona to wear."

"Oh, God, no!"

"I mean, then he'd be under control. You wouldn't have to worry about, uh—"

"We'll talk about it later," you snap. "Speaking of Carmona," you add, "has he gone yet to pick up the stuff?"

"Yes." She pauses. "I guess that's the answer, then."

"What is?"

She looks up at you. "What you explained when you asked him to get stuff to make more masks.

* * * * *

What you explained was your idea about making student puppets, to spy out the school from the inside. They jibbed a lot less at this than you thought they would; Carmona even said, "I thought we were going to do that anyway." But now, even before he's returned with the supplies, you're thinking of switching it up further. Instead of using student puppets as spies while impersonating teachers, maybe you should impersonate the students while keeping teachers in reserve as puppets.

Carmona agrees when he's returned with the additional supplies, and you've explained this evolution in your thinking. And he goes further, suggesting that you scatter lots of puppets throughout the school, to smoke out any fakes that are hiding inside it.

"We're not really going to do this to the whole school, are we, Will?" Beatriz asks when she walks you out to the car at three o'clock in the morning, by which time your trio has made six new masks.

"No, not the whole school," you assure her. "Maybe not even all that many."

"Really?"

You hesitate, then explain, "We might get lucky and trip up over some of Red Team's fakes." You don't add the kicker: If you do quickly trip over one of their fakes, it will probably be because they've made so many of them. They might already own the whole school.

"I just want to get this over with," Beatriz murmur.

"I know. I do too." It feels funny for you—Cathy Schell—to pull Beatriz Puente into an embrace. "It's why we can't waste time," you whisper as you squeeze her to you. She squeezes you back.

You then part for the night, to get a few hours sleep before going in to the school for the last day of classes before Thanksgiving break. You and Miller will each have three masks with you, and six classes to pick recruits from.

But you're already picking them out as you stride in to school at seven-thirty the next morning, your head buzzing with a mix of exhaustion and anticipation. You are already looking forward to your first-period class—volleyball practice—and two prime candidates to turn into puppets and spies.

The first is Ava Price, the only sophomore on the team. You don't know how popular or connected she is, but at least she would be a recruit down in the sophomore class, where Red Team would likely have some of its own agents. The other is Reagan Hackett, a senior, who impresses Cathy Schell as a snoop, a gossip, and a plugged-in social butterfly.

As you stride toward the gym you spot another possible recruit: Carl Gellman. He coaches the soccer teams, and maybe you should snag him for Carmona. At least one of the masks you carry is supposed to be for a disguise for him.

Or maybe you should wait to talk to Miller first, and coordinate with her.

choices: Make one a girl for Miller
1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.content:
The Tuesday before Thanksgiving dawns very cold, and the temperature has just broken above freezing as you stride in toward the gym. Overhead, pillowy clouds float in a pale blue sky.

The bracing chill seems to stiffen your spine. No point in fucking around, you decide as you cross the small quad in front of the gym. Reagan Hackett and Ava Price will probably be as good recruits as any, and if you start second-guessing yourself you'll never stop.

Harsh voices sound over the squeak of rubber soles on polished wood sound as you enter the gym vestibule, just as they did yesterday morning when you and your friends came in search of some coaches. This morning, though, as you enter the eastern practice court, Coach Schell's instincts pull your eyes onto the floor, where the school basketball team is practicing.

They've broken into two five-man squads and are playing a hard practice game. Lean, muscled forms in baggy shorts and tops sprint up and down the court and hurl themselves through the air at the nets; the ball bangs like a gunshot against floor. A scent of testosterone and sweat hangs in the air, and you draw in a deep lungful of it. Normally it would make you retch; but your impersonation loves it the smell of teenage boy.

You start a little when you spot an out-of-place figure in the middle of the scrum: the lanky form of Will Prescott. You almost don't recognize him, what with his shortened hair and his crimson-and-gold uniform. He looks scrawny and underfed when mixing it up with giants like Steve Patterson and Brendan Tummler. But he zips across the floor when he's got the ball, weaving in and out like a shuttlecock on a loom; and once, as you watch, he nails two points with a shot that's all net. His expression is set in stone as he sprints back down to the far end of the court.

There are other changes to the squad, which you take in like a flash. Gordon Black is gone—and what a lot of drama there was in the coaches' offices when Black suddenly fell apart on them; Coach Brooks was almost suicidal—and his absence is like plucking the biggest skyscraper from a metropolitan skyline. Gone too is Jeremy Richards. A new standout on the court is Adam Dortch, less for his skill or height than for the immense bush of hair—like a brown dandelion—that puffs up on his head. Put it in a tie or tease it into a 'fro, Brooks has told him, but as yet he's done neither.

But the two standout changes to the Westside team have to be—

"'Ay, Coach Schell!" a clear voice rings out, and your eye flicks over to Joe Durras. Golden of limb and golden of hair, he dances in place for you with his hands over his head, grinning. God, he's gorgeous, Cathy Schell murmurs in your ear. If I was ten years younger and on the girls' basketball squad—

"Dumbass!" Patterson barks. "Get your ass back in gear!"

Joe kicks up his heels, does a cartwheel, then trots down to the far end of the court, where play has moved. He casts a glinting grin back over his shoulder at you. His brother, Frank—tall and dark and brooding ("Byronic," Ms. Goretsky sighed as she and Cathy and some of the other teachers were drooling over him and his brother one afternoon)—mutters at him, but Joe only shrugs.

They came over to Westside from cross-town rival Eastman just a few weeks ago. And despite Gordon's dropping out, talk is that the Westside Dragons have significantly bettered their chances of going to state by adding them to the roster.

With a deep, pleasurable sigh, you turn toward the mezzanine and the coaches' offices.

* * * * *

"Nice spike, Ava!" you shout as the volleyball bounces away on the other side of the net. Whitney Rosenthal, looking grim and exhausted as her team falls further behind the other, scoops it out of the air and hurls it back over the net to Regina Yost. Ava Price herself only returns you a hooded glance. You carefully refrain from frowning.

She was vexed when she woke up in your office as a fake version of herself. First thing after class started, you lined up the girls and asked who was staying in town for the break. To your relief, both Ava and Reagan had raised their hands. Not that you couldn't have picked two other girls, but it saved you from having to invent new plans on the fly.

After sending the other girls jogging around the gym, you asked Ava to come back into your office, where you got her from behind with a mask. While she was unconscious you checked her for a mask and found nothing, and after the mask came out of her you applied some of the special enchanting goop to its inner surface before returning the mask to her face. She had instantly woken, confused and a little resentful, but had dutifully promised to tell the other girls that she had only had a short "conference" with you about her grades. Except for a shadow of anger that still hangs over her, you have seen no other change in her.

You spent the balance of class running drills and practice, the way Coach Schell would. Maybe she was more enthusiastic about watching the boys' basketball team than you were, but you enjoy this class more than she would. The girls aren't the prettiest in the school, and in truth they're not the most athletic either. But they show lots of leg and arm in their skimpy shorts and t-shirts, and there's a flush of health in them that gives you a flush of pleasure too.

You call an early halt to practice, telling the girls they can shower, change, and have the balance of the time to hang out, but you call Reagan to follow you into your office. "My grades are fine, Ms. Schell," she tells you in a very dry tone as you lead her down the hallway.

"Oh, did Ava tell you that's what I talked to her about?" You force a laugh. "That was just a cover. There's something else I want to see you about." Reagan looks piqued as she follows you into the office. "Take a seat," you invite her, and close the door as she sits with her back to you. From the shallow shelf on the back wall, where the coach has balanced some plaques and small trophies, you pluck down a second blank mask. Smoothly you step up behind Reagan and reach around to press it into her face. All the starch goes out of her, and she slumps in her seat.

You check her face for other masks and find none, then perch on the edge of your desk to study her. Like Ava, Reagan has long, dark-blonde hair that falls in straight lengths to the top of her boobs. But Reagan has a bold mouth and a bolder, almost prow-like nose, and she also has a figure that the instructor in Cathy Schell's college-level art appreciation class might call "Rubenesque": solid and barrel-like, but without being fat. Indeed, her thighs, though very big, are toned and tanned, even now at the end of November. Probably she hits a tanning bed once a week, you tell yourself. All in all, she has an appearance that well matches the bossy personality she sometimes shows on the volleyball court—the personality that you chose her for.

You catch the mask as it falls out of her, and coat its inner surface with the goop before setting it back onto her face, where it instantly sinks out of sight. Her eyes open, and she looks puzzled. But she accepts your instructions—to tell the other girls that you wanted to talk to her about her classes—with a calm assurance. As with Ava, you instruct her to come find you in your office when school lets out.

* * * * *

During the break between first and second period you tap at Beatriz Puente's door. But there's no answer, and it's nearly five minutes before, looking very blown, she comes striding down the hallway. "Oh, God, I wanted to kill the girls this morning," she pants as she jams a key into the lock. This morning, unlike yesterday, she has a slight Hispanic accent. "What's up?" she asks as she leads you into her office.

"Just checking to see how you're doing," you tell her.

"I'm okay." She blows out a deep breath and turns a distracted gaze onto you. "Don't worry about me, Will," she mutters, but she seems not to be looking at you.

"You sure everything's okay?" you ask.

"Trying not to lose my concentration," she says. "Is like running," she adds. "I lose my momentum, I got to pick it up all over again."

"Huh," you reply. With you, it's easiest to just fall into Coach Schell's personality, but you don't want to upset Miller by telling her that. "I just wanted to check in with you," you repeat. "I placed two of my masks last period. How are you coming along?"

"Are you kidding?" Beatriz snaps. "I been running a soccer practice for the last two hours. When was I—?"

"Just chill, Miller. It's okay. You've got the rest of the day."

"I'm out on the field all day," she retorts. "Well, I got the two tutorials this afternoon, but they got those glass walls in the offices, anyone can see in."

"Call your own students in for a one-on-one conference in here," you suggest. "That's what I did with my girls."

Beatriz bites her lip. "You got two done already? Really? Can I give you one of mine, that way I only have to do two instead of three?"

That's no problem for you, and Miller is relieved and grateful when you take one of her masks from her.

You've met your own quota—two masks for you to control—this morning. Now, with two more to handle, you have to find two recruits for Carmona.

Or maybe it should be one for him and one for Miller. You'd like to pick a good one for her—one that you could appreciate too.
1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.title: Fast Play

1112111311222221222222122121124312112111.content:
You place the new mask that Miller gave you on the back shelf of your office next to the other mask that you still have to find a place for. You already have a container of enchanted goop that will turn the wearer of a mask into an obedient servant of Tim Carmona.

Except, you only realize now that it's too late, Carmona won't be here to give it any orders. How much of a problem is that going to be? Will it obey me if I give it orders? Or will it run out and tell everyone that Coach Schell is doing weird things with students back in her office?

Best not to chance it, you decide. You're going to have to restrain yourself and pick only one alias for Carmona, not two, for you will have to switch into the mask of whoever you pick so that you can control it directly while leaving Coach Schell on auto-pilot. Then, using that disguise or some other, you will have to get Carmona his second alias later today or tomorrow.

The bell rings, and you jump. Time for second period: Personal Fitness.

* * * * *

The Personal Fitness classes are electives, unlike the Basic P.E. classes that every graduate of Westside is required to take two semesters of. That means they are mostly filled with sophomores and juniors, and occasionally seniors, who need or want more physical activity. Mostly that means members of the junior varsity teams. Better than that, even, it means that the classes, being voluntary, are a lot more pleasant for the students, which makes them more pleasant for the teachers as well, who don't have to worry about bullying by the more athletic types, or sulking indifference from the less athletic kids.

This particular Personal Fitness class concentrates on stamina and aerobic activities, and the kids on the floor are already stretching and warming up as you come striding out. Most of them are in sweat pants and long-sleeve tops, for you'll be taking them outside. You spend a few minutes looking them over as they continue to filter out from the changing rooms, and watch as some of them take off on a short, light jog around the court. Except for one or two of the chunkier kids, who signed up for the class to get in better shape, most of them look pretty good.

When it looks like everyone is out and ready, you blow your whistle and summon everyone over for roll call. "Adler! Ayala! Beecher!" Down the list you go, too quick to make any notes for yourself. "Okay, ten times around the perimeter, then out to the track," you order them. "Go!"

With heads down they take off, the fleetest of them flying out in front, and lapping the slow-pokes within the first two circuits. You stand in the middle of the gym, clipboard to your chest, beaming at them. Now you can take notes.
.

The juniors in the class you ignore: your gut tells you that if Andrew Webb and his friends have spread their tentacles through the school, they will mostly be in their own class or in the senior class. But there aren't that many seniors to worry about, and you are able to narrow the list of possible senior recruits for Carmona down to two: Darren Green and Shawn Sax.

Sax is the more plausible of the two. For a start, he's on the varsity basketball team, and given the squad's glamor and prestige you'd bet that that is one place that Webb and his friends would want to infiltrate. Sax is one of the few African-American students in the school, and though he's on the small side for a player, he makes up for it with raw skill and strength. You've always been scared of him—with his bandana, moustache and goatee, and thuggishly soft-spoken manner he exudes menace—but that makes him attractive in the current, dangerous circumstances. Even now, there's an animal vigor to his stride as he pounds around the perimeter of the gym in his snowy-white jogging suit.

His friend Green was also on the squad until the purge a few weeks ago, when along with Black and Richards and Dylan Lloyd he was sent down and replaced with the two Durras brothers, Adam Dortch and (still bizarre to think about) Will Prescott. At first you're inclined to discount him for that reason. But it occurs to you that Green would still be close to members of the team, but that being off the squad he might not be a target for Red Team, which would make him a good recruit for your side. He would probably look more plausible as a companion to Reagan Hackett, the senior volleyball player you put a mask on.

There are a lot more sophomore boys to consider, but you soon reduce them to three. James Randolph, like Sax and Green, is a basketball player, though as yet he's only on the junior varsity team. You're not sure, but you suspect that he's popular down in his class. Or is it only because, with his blonde hair and strong legs, he reminds Cathy Schell of Joe Durras? Even so, you'd trust her instincts, and you consider him a candidate.

The other two are Liam Schoonover and Bradley White. Both are on the skinny side, and Schoonover in particular looks like a scarecrow with his thin arms and legs. But Cathy has noticed the way the girls in the class sidle up to him and White, to talk and smile and tuck their hair back while laughing. Schoonover plays in a popular garage band, so that explains his appeal. Of White's appeal you're much less sure, as he doesn't look all that special, though he has a very fresh face and a glinting grin under his mop of platinum-blonde hair. He must have a personality that gets the girls excited.

You follow the kids outside to the track, and after Randolph and Jamie Laird (one of the junior girls) have circled it twice, you start shuttling them back inside as each one completes a circuit. You jog in with the last of them and let them walk it off and catch their breath before sending Sax into the equipment room to fetch out a bag of rubber balls. I wouldn't tap that, you think. But maybe that's a reason to pick her, so that Miller won't think you were plotting with your cock rather than with your brain. You've still not picked anyone for Miller when the kids start exiting the gym, and you follow them out at a thoughtful pace. But she is good friends with the other two.

If I was on Red Team, you think, Kaylee and probably Wendy would be girls I'd want masks of. If you want to uncover one of their puppets, it would be best to strike at one of them. Alternately, if you just want to get close to Red Team agents, to spy them out, you'd probably be better off picking Avery.

Most of the kids' faces light up at the prospect of playing dodge ball for the rest of the period, but Cristina looks like she wants to crawl under the bleachers.

"Who's staying in town for Thanksgiving?" you shout out before the game can start. "Come on, put your hands up!" The kids look puzzled but comply.

Good. First, though, you knock on Coach Puente's door and put your head into her office, for this is her free period. "Come talk to me in my office when you have a minute," you tell her as she looks up from her laptop. You hope she'll approve your choice of—

Does she? You give her a doubtful look.

She gasps and laughs and tucks back a strand of her hair. "We got ten minutes," she says. "Why don't I give you that blow job that I—" She catches herself and for a moment looks confused. "That we were talking about a little while ago."

But you're distracted by another thought—the thought of using this new spell on Gary Chen—so Caleb's comment yanks you back to the present. "Huh?"

"God, is that what I sound like? 'Huh?'" he says.

"Yeah, probably," you say with a very Caleb-like wave of your hand. "Look, it's no trouble, I can cover for you at home, and maybe I should in case Eva—"

"No, I'll go home myself," he says, very loudly and firmly. "You go back to cover for Dane."

"You're worried too much about that."

"Of course I'm worried! It's fucking Chen, and he's out twenty-two thousand dollars, and he's got permission to do anything short of killing me!"

"Killing Dane, you mean," Caleb says.

"And who's living inside Dane's skin these days?"

"You could always let Dane out," Caleb says. "Let him go back to being himself. He'd just think it was a bizarre hallucination he'd been having. You can go back to being Gordon."

He turns, and his manner is a little frosty. "I'll make you a deal," he says. "Since you want to share your idea, and since you're having a lot of fun inside my head, how about—" He grabs one of the many metal strips you've made over the last few days, and dangles it between his fingertips. "Gimme a copy of your head."

You grimace as you take it from him. "I shoulda known that's what you'd say."

At least he has the grace to not put it on in front of you. In fact, he's already left by the time you recover from the swoon after putting it on; indeed, while you were out he seemingly took care of all the business that needed taking care of. And when you look around, you find that he's taken his own mask and brain band with him.

You're a little miffed at that, for it seems like a sign that he doesn't trust you with them. Doesn't trust you? Like you'd really like to move in on his life, to live in that shitty little house alone with his mother; to worry and gnaw at the wound of his father's abandonment when he was a kid; to chase hard after good grades and career contacts so he can win himself a solid, rewarding job so he can get a wife and family that he won't abandon; to stagger through the school halls with an erect cock and a frozen tongue at the sight of all the girls who he's sure won't even talk to him—

You rub thoughtfully at your forehead. Did Caleb really pull that metal strip off of you? You have a raw feeling inside you, as though something has been torn away, and you've lost that sense that you've got another person riding around under your skin. But the memories and impressions seem very vivid, and thoughts you recognize as not your own keep popping up unbidden. You wince hard at some of the jokes that Keith Tilley was making behind your back about you and Lisa, and silently vow to get back at him somehow. And the thoughts keep coming even after you've bent over the grimoire in the dim light of Caleb's laptop, checking the translation of the ingredients against the supplies he'd started to set out.

It's not a hard spell, and it uses many of the same liquids and powders you'd gathered for the first two spells, and after about twenty minutes you're able to set a bowl of the slurry-like liquid onto the sigil in the book. As directed by the instructions, you run your finger three times around the circle and set a flame to it. It flashes into a brief fire, then goes out. The page beneath turns when you lift the bowl.

There is only a short paragraph on he other side, and the on-line Latin translator gives a straight-forward interpretation: It's a glue that lets you attach one of those metal strips to the inner surface of a mask. Cool! That means you'd be able to put the strip and the mask on at the same time instead of in two separate steps. And on mulling it over, you think you see another benefit: You could get a mask and mind-strip onto a victim in one blow if you glued a blank strip into a blank mask. Like if you got that kind of combination onto Gary Chen.

Of course, you reflect grimly an hour later as you slip into the sleeping bag, you'll have to convince Caleb to go along with the plan. And he's being such a turd that he might not want to.

He's got a point, you admit to yourself as sleep begins to take you. It probably would be easier to just take Dane out of Gordon's mask, and let him take the consequences for what you've done. You swallow down a great gulp of bitter coffee, and it scalds your throat. But it shocks you into semi-coherence. "You were shopping?"

Caleb shrugs tightly. "Well, it makes sense. You don't want him coming after you, right?" He's avoiding your eye, and falls silent. Then he speaks again in a rush as you continue to stare at him. "Look, that was something else I saw last night when I had the, uh, the thing in my head. I didn't realize just how fucking scary Dane's cousin is. So, you know, it makes sense, this idea you've got." He pauses. "I don't wanna see Dane all fucked up either," he adds quietly.

Caleb is listening intently, and his eyebrows shoot up. "Patrick Star?" he mouths incredulously.

"Yeah? So bring it to me," Chen says.

"I can't," you say. "It's up at the school and I can't reach it. Yeah, I can't reach it," you repeat. "It's up in— I don't know what it is, but it's back up in this space thing where I can't get to it, but maybe you can? You know, 'cos, you're, like, stronger than me?"

"You're not making any sense," Chen says, but consents to meet you at the portables at three-thirty. You hang up with a sigh of relief.

"So which of us gets to be Chen?" Caleb asks.

—and around his head to press the mask into his face. Chen jerks back, then sags against you. The sudden onslaught of his full weight almost knocks you off the desk, but you catch him and yourself just in time, and sag with him onto the desk. You disentangle your limbs from his, and leap for the door. "Caleb!" you call, and your friend dashes in from the portable opposite.

Chen isn't a big guy—he's about your height—but he's strong without being bulky or sculpted. Getting him undressed is a bit of a production, for he's wearing a dark-green, heavy canvas jacket over his red t-shirt; dark denim trousers; and combat-style boots. You whisk away the gray ski cap he's got pulled low over his forehead and are about to tackle the jacket when Caleb waves you off. "Just get out of Dane's things," he hisses.

"Don't you need my help?"

"Yeah, but first things first. I won't let you sleep."

So you quickly strip yourself of Dane's loose gear, lay in the filthy floor, and grab your face.

* * * * *

You come out of your swoon slapping hard at Caleb: to rouse you, he's covered your mouth and pinched your nose shut. Effective, but it leaves your brain feeling like it's been stuffed with dry leaves and set on fire. You ache all over as you rush over to help get Chen undressed.

It turns out you didn't have to rush too hard. The mask is still copying Chen by the time you've got him completely disrobed and into Dane's clothes. He never wakes or stirs, even when you accidentally drop his head hard onto the desk.

Once you've got Chen changed, you get yourself into his clothes. There's a rough, grimy feel to them. They don't seem to be dirty—not overly much—and there's no smell off them. But they're not the kind of clothes you'd wear, and they're associated with someone you are very much not like. You feel like you're playing a very unconvincing game of "dress up" as you tighten the laces on the boots and wrap yourself in the jacket; you feel lost in them. You pull the ski cap down around your ears, tuck your hair into it, and turn to Caleb. "How do I look?"

"Like a sad little douchebag wannabe. Go wait in his car, I'll be along with his mask when it's done."

"Don't you want me here to help?"

"I don't wanna be seen with you while you're looking like that. I'm not sure I wanna be seen with you after you've got Chen's mask on, either," he adds in a grumble.

Chen drives a battered red Jeep with a fabric top and doors. The interior of the cab isn't much different from the interior of your old truck, with the floorboards on the passenger side being buried in papers and old fast-food sacks. You may be dressed like Chen, but you don't look like him yet, and it would never do if someone spotted you sitting behind his wheel. It wouldn't do for them to spot you dressed like this out in the open, either. You try compromising by sitting in the passenger side, but even that leaves you feeling exposed, and you slouch down as far as you can, then lay on your side so that you'll be entirely invisible to casual passers-by.

The time passes uncomfortably, but it's only a few minutes before there's a scratching at the fabric of the door, and you sit up as Caleb opens it. His look of surprise changes to a sneer of exasperation. "And you're going to take over for Chen," he snorts. "I'll believe it when I see it." He hands you a mask.

"Look, you don't want to piss me off, not if I'm going to be wearing this mask," you retort. You turn it over to look at its inner surface. Your jaw drops a little.

"Yeah, check it out, Chinese characters and shit," Caleb says. "Gimme the keys, I'll drive."

"Can't I drive? It's gonna be—"

"I wanna be far away when Chen wakes up," Caleb says. "Gimme. We'll finish up back to the clubhouse."

As he puts the car in motion, you open up the plastic tub filled with the sealing goop, and with a brush that shakes from the movement of the car you paint its interior. You move fast, and the Jeep is still on the street when you're able to wriggle down firmly into the seat and raise the mask with both hands to your face. The blue flames of the Chinese characters dance and burn and blur as they rise to meet you.
111211131122222122222212212121.title: Change for a Chen

1112111311222221222222122121211.content:
You rise from sleep like a shark breaching the ocean surface. Someone is shaking you, and the side of your fist--did you swing your arm?--connects with something hard but a little yielding. You sit up and look around.

You're parked next to the old elementary school; Caleb is rubbing the side of his jaw and giving you a wounded, reproachful look. "So, does this mean you're Gary Chen now?"

"Ungh." You put your face in your hands, but it doesn't help. Your clothes crawl all over your body, like they're made of insects. You brush and pat and pull at them, trying to get comfortable.

And then you're hit by that wave of nausea and dizziness, like you had yesterday when waking under Caleb's mind-strip.

It wells up and spills over you, over the crown of your head, down your limbs, and into your lungs and guts. You bend double, first with sickness and then with fear, for his approach is awful. He's dark and shrouded and baleful as he creeps up behind and wraps himself around you like a full-body veil. Your mind unravels, and you reel as new threads entwine with old; you turn and fall and twist; but when the sense of motion ceases you find yourself standing again on firm and familiar ground, though with a new horizon about you. You open your eyes, and are enveloped by an overpowering sense of something like déjà vu—a sense that you're looking at and remembering things twice over. Briefly you are of two minds about where you are and what you've been doing, but with only a tiny spasm of willpower you bring them into alignment. You suck in a deep breath, and exhale. "Yeah I'm here. Let's have a look at our shit," you say, and get out of the car.

You're sharply aware of Caleb's movements as he follows you to the basement door, though you only watch him from the corner of your eye. Fucking stupid to let them make that play back in the portable, you can't help feeling; but you also can't help feeling glee at having bested Chen. You kick the ground impatiently as Caleb fumbles the key into the lock. "Snap it up there, Johansson," you say.

"Don't be an asshole, Will," he replies. His tone is quieter than the one he usually takes with you, you notice.

"Hard for me not to be under the circumstances, you know?"

"Don't overdo it. You're just playacting, and you're with me."

The dizziness hasn't completely faded; maybe that's why you feel not quite in control of yourself. "If this is playacting, I'm doing a pretty good job convincing myself," you retort, and push past your friend once he's got the door open.

You pause halfway down the interior steps, and blink away a distressing portrait of home life you'll be returning to. Mnh, that's not gonna be fun. But Chen's dealt with it before, and you're sure you can too.

Because as you test the wooden stairs under your boots, everything firms and tightens up. This feels natural, you think to yourself. This feels right. "Is the shit still in that desk?" you ask. "Get it out while I make sure I got my gear on right." Caleb makes a face, but you ignore it to shove your way to the back where the full-length mirror is.

And there he is; or, there you are: Chen Guangli, or "Gary Chen," as the Americanization has it. Grandfather didn't come to the United States from China, he came via Indonesia, but there's still the pressure to conform to the old ways, even in these days of the old father's physical and mental decrepitude. Not that the form staring back at you has anything like an "old ways" stamp to it. You shift about inside the jacket, resettling it; you adjust the belt and pants; and who the fuck put your boots on that way? You undo them and start over again, getting your cuffs just inside the tops before lacing them up again. And the cap: You pull it off, sending straight dark hair falling over your brows and into your face, over your ears and down the back of your neck. You slide the cap back on, pushing your bangs inside it as you pull it down to your eyebrows; but you tug the hair on the sides of your head and the back out further, so that it frames a face that narrows from wide-set eyes and high cheek bones down to a tapering chin.

One more pass over all the clothing gets it all in place and comfortable. You hike your shoulders, and realize you're tense all over. But you don't relax.

"Are you done yet over there, Confucius?" Caleb wearily calls.

Something taut and heavy, like a piano wire, snaps inside your head. "Confucius" is almost as bad as "fortune cookie" or "fried lice." Inside of four steps you're in Caleb's face and inside his defenses before he can bat feebly back. You jam him back against the wall and punch a hole in his gut; and since you've got a fistful of his hair in the other hand he can't bend double to cover the sudden pain.

You're about to deliver a second blow when you catch yourself; and though your muscles blaze with undischarged flame, you force yourself to release him, and your best friend sinks to the ground, groaning and puffing.

"Okay, I'm sorry about that," you say, but your tone is clipped, for that wave of anger is still receding; and you're also mortified at having let yourself be carried away by it. "But don't call me shit like that, okay? Instinct kind of takes over, I guess." Caleb glares up at you from under his eyebrows. "But, uh, I guess that's one reason Chen is such an asshole. Because for as long as he can remember people have been calling him names like that, thinking it's funny."

"No, I think he's just an asshole," Caleb retorts.

"Yeah, maybe," you admit. You flex and relax your fist thoughtfully. That sense of bifurcation is back, now that Chen has receded. You doubt he'd ever say it aloud, but you say it aloud for him as you retake control: "When you're always in a bad mood, it doesn't take much to set you off, you know? Anyway, yeah, I'm all set now." You look down at him, and can't help grinning. "Think I could pass as Chen now, you pudding-faced little shit?"

Caleb doesn't reply as he struggles to his feet. You step back, keeping out of range, tensing for a blow that you doubt will come, but you never know. Caleb gives you a sidelong glance as he returns to the desk where he's got the stuff set out.

You tch over the busted lock, but carefully study the contents. It looks like everything Dwayne promised, and he's never cheated his customers yet. But of course you'll have to double-check it. And after that?

"What are you going to do with it?" Caleb's question is your own.

And you let Chen answer for you: "I got my customer list, I can clear ninety percent of it by Wednesday, rest by the end of the month."

"Who buys that much?"
